[The family of [Dashwood]84-miss dashwood]242-the family of dashwood had long been settled in [Sussex]1-sussex . [[Their]242-the family of dashwood estate]243-their estate was large , and [[their]242-the family of dashwood residence]244-their residence was at [Norland Park]2-norland park , in the centre of [[their]242-the family of dashwood property]245-their property , where , for many generations , [they]242-the family of dashwood had lived in so respectable a manner as to engage the general good opinion of [[their]242-the family of dashwood surrounding acquaintance]246-their surrounding acquaintance . [The late owner of [this estate]248-this estate]247-the late owner of this estate was [a single man]249-a single man , who lived to a very advanced age , and who for many years of [his]247-the late owner of this estate life , had [a constant companion and housekeeper in [[his]247-the late owner of this estate sister]251-his sister]250-a constant companion and housekeeper in his sister . But [her]251-his sister death , which happened ten years before [his]247-the late owner of this estate own , produced a great alteration in [[his]247-the late owner of this estate home]252-his home ; for to supply [her]251-his sister loss , [he]247-the late owner of this estate invited and received into [his]247-the late owner of this estate house [the family of [[his]247-the late owner of this estate nephew]254-his nephew [Mr. Henry Dashwood]85-mr. dashwood , [the legal inheritor of [the Norland estate]256-the norland estate]255-the legal inheritor of the norland estate , and [the person to whom [he]247-the late owner of this estate intended to bequeath [it]256-the norland estate]257-the person to whom he intended to bequeath it . In the society of [[his]247-the late owner of this estate nephew]254-his nephew and [niece]259-niece , and [[their]260-their children]261-their children]253-the family of his nephew mr. henry dashwood , the legal inheritor of the norland estate , and the person to whom he intended to bequeath it . in the society of his nephew and niece , and their children , [the old Gentleman]262-the old gentleman ’s days were comfortably spent . [His]247-the late owner of this estate attachment to [them]260-their all increased . The constant attention of [Mr.]263-mr. and [Mrs. Henry Dashwood]86-mrs. henry dashwood to [his]247-the late owner of this estate wishes , which proceeded not merely from interest , but from goodness of heart , gave [him]247-the late owner of this estate every degree of solid comfort which [his]247-the late owner of this estate age could receive ; and the cheerfulness of [the children]264-the children added a relish to [his]247-the late owner of this estate existence . By a former marriage , [Mr. Henry Dashwood]85-mr. dashwood had [one son]265-one son : by [[his]247-the late owner of this estate present lady]266-his present lady , [three daughters]267-three daughters . [The son]268-the son , [a steady respectable young man]269-a steady respectable young man , was amply provided for by the fortune of [[his]268-the son mother]270-his mother , which had been large , and half of which devolved on [him]268-the son on [his]268-the son coming of age . By [his]247-the late owner of this estate own marriage , likewise , which happened soon afterwards , [he]247-the late owner of this estate added to [his]247-the late owner of this estate wealth . To [him]247-the late owner of this estate therefore the succession to [the Norland estate]256-the norland estate was not so really important as to [[his]247-the late owner of this estate sisters]272-his sisters ; for [their]272-his sisters fortune , independent of what might arise to [them]272-his sisters from [[their]272-his sisters father]273-their father ’s inheriting that property , could be but small . [[Their]272-his sisters mother]274-their mother had nothing , and [[their]272-his sisters father]273-their father only seven thousand pounds in [his]247-the late owner of this estate own disposal ; for the remaining moiety of [[his]247-the late owner of this estate first wife]276-his first wife ’s fortune was also secured to [[her]276-his first wife child]277-her child , and [he]247-the late owner of this estate had only a life - interest in it . [The old gentleman]262-the old gentleman died : [his]247-the late owner of this estate will was read , and like almost every other will , gave as much disappointment as pleasure . [He]247-the late owner of this estate was neither so unjust , nor so ungrateful , as to leave [his]247-the late owner of this estate estate from [[his]247-the late owner of this estate nephew;—but]279-his nephew;—but [he]247-the late owner of this estate left it to [him]279-his nephew;—but on such terms as destroyed half the value of the bequest . [Mr. Dashwood]85-mr. dashwood had wished for it more for the sake of [[his]85-mr. dashwood wife]280-his wife and [daughters]281-daughters than for [himself]85-mr. dashwood or [[his]85-mr. dashwood son;—but]282-his son;—but to [[his]85-mr. dashwood son]283-his son , and [[[his]85-mr. dashwood son]283-his son ’s son]285-his son ’s son , [a child of four years old]286-a child of four years old , it was secured , in such a way , as to leave to [himself]85-mr. dashwood no power of providing for [those who were most dear to [him]85-mr. dashwood , and who most needed a provision by any charge on [the estate]288-the estate , or by any sale of [its]288-the estate valuable woods]287-those who were most dear to him , and who most needed a provision by any charge on the estate , or by any sale of its valuable woods . The whole was tied up for the benefit of [this child]289-this child , who , in occasional visits with [[his]289-this child father]290-his father and mother at [Norland]3-norland , had so far gained on the affections of [[his]289-this child uncle]291-his uncle , by such attractions as are by no means unusual in [children of two or three years old]292-children of two or three years old ; an imperfect articulation , an earnest desire of having [his]289-this child own way , many cunning tricks , and a great deal of noise , as to outweigh all the value of all the attention which , for years , [he]85-mr. dashwood had received from [[his]85-mr. dashwood niece]293-his niece and [[her]293-his niece daughters]294-her daughters . [He]85-mr. dashwood meant not to be unkind , however , and , as a mark of [his]85-mr. dashwood affection for [the three girls]295-the three girls , [he]85-mr. dashwood left [them]295-the three girls a thousand pounds a - piece . [Mr. Dashwood]85-mr. dashwood ’s disappointment was , at first , severe ; but [his]85-mr. dashwood temper was cheerful and sanguine ; and [he]85-mr. dashwood might reasonably hope to live many years , and by living economically , lay by a considerable sum from the produce of an estate already large , and capable of almost immediate improvement . But the fortune , which had been so tardy in coming , was [his]85-mr. dashwood only one twelvemonth . [He]85-mr. dashwood survived [[his]85-mr. dashwood uncle]291-his uncle no longer ; and ten thousand pounds , including the late legacies , was all that remained for [[his]85-mr. dashwood widow]297-his widow and [daughters]281-daughters . [[His]85-mr. dashwood son]283-his son was sent for as soon as [his]283-his son danger was known , and to [him]283-his son [Mr. Dashwood]85-mr. dashwood recommended , with all the strength and urgency which illness could command , the interest of [[his]283-his son mother - in - law]300-his mother - in - law and [sisters]301-sisters . [Mr. John Dashwood]87-mr. john dashwood had not the strong feelings of [the rest of [the family]303-the family]302-the rest of the family ; but [he]87-mr. john dashwood was affected by a recommendation of such a nature at such a time , and [he]87-mr. john dashwood promised to do every thing in [his]87-mr. john dashwood power to make [them]302-the rest of the family comfortable . [[His]283-his son father]290-his father was rendered easy by such an assurance , and [Mr. John Dashwood]87-mr. john dashwood had then leisure to consider how much there might prudently be in [his]87-mr. john dashwood power to do for [them]302-the rest of the family . [He]87-mr. john dashwood was not [an ill - disposed young man]305-an ill - disposed young man , unless to be rather cold hearted and rather selfish is to be ill - disposed : but [he]87-mr. john dashwood was , in general , well respected ; for [he]87-mr. john dashwood conducted [himself]87-mr. john dashwood with propriety in the discharge of [his]87-mr. john dashwood ordinary duties . Had [he]87-mr. john dashwood married [a more amiable woman]306-a more amiable woman , [he]87-mr. john dashwood might have been made still more respectable than [he]87-mr. john dashwood was:—he might even have been made amiable [himself]87-mr. john dashwood ; for [he]87-mr. john dashwood was very young when [he]87-mr. john dashwood married , and very fond of [[his]87-mr. john dashwood wife]280-his wife . But [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood was a strong caricature of [himself;—more]308-himself;—more narrow - minded and selfish . When [he]87-mr. john dashwood gave [his]87-mr. john dashwood promise to [[his]87-mr. john dashwood father]290-his father , [he]87-mr. john dashwood meditated within [himself]87-mr. john dashwood to increase the fortunes of [[his]87-mr. john dashwood sisters]272-his sisters by the present of a thousand pounds a - piece . [He]87-mr. john dashwood then really thought [himself]87-mr. john dashwood equal to it . The prospect of four thousand a - year , in addition to [his]87-mr. john dashwood present income , besides the remaining half of [[his]87-mr. john dashwood own mother]311-his own mother ’s fortune , warmed [his]87-mr. john dashwood heart , and made [him]87-mr. john dashwood feel capable of generosity . “ Yes , [he]290-his father would give [them]272-his sisters three thousand pounds : it would be liberal and handsome ! It would be enough to make [them]272-his sisters completely easy . Three thousand pounds ! [he]290-his father could spare so considerable a sum with little inconvenience . ”[87-mr. john dashwood] [He]87-mr. john dashwood thought of it all day long , and for many days successively , and [he]87-mr. john dashwood did not repent . No sooner was [[his]87-mr. john dashwood father]290-his father ’s funeral over , than [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , without sending any notice of [her]88-mrs. dashwood intention to [[her]88-mrs. dashwood mother - in - law]313-her mother - in - law , arrived with [[her]88-mrs. dashwood child]277-her child and [[their]315-their attendants]316-their attendants . [No one]317-no one could dispute [her]88-mrs. dashwood right to come ; [the house]318-the house was [[her]88-mrs. dashwood husband]319-her husband ’s from the moment of [[his]87-mr. john dashwood father]290-his father ’s decease ; but the indelicacy of [her]88-mrs. dashwood conduct was so much the greater , and to [a woman in [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood]321-a woman in mrs. dashwood ’s situation , with only common feelings , must have been highly unpleasing;—but in _ [her]88-mrs. dashwood _ mind there was a sense of honor so keen , a generosity so romantic , that any offence of the kind , by whomsoever given or received , was to [her]88-mrs. dashwood a source of immovable disgust . [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood had never been a favourite with [any of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood husband ’s family]323-her husband ’s family]322-any of her husband ’s family ; but [she]88-mrs. dashwood had had no opportunity , till the present , of showing [them]322-any of her husband ’s family with how little attention to the comfort of other people [she]88-mrs. dashwood could act when occasion required it . So acutely did [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood feel this ungracious behaviour , and so earnestly did [she]88-mrs. dashwood despise [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughter - in - law]324-her daughter - in - law for it , that , on the arrival of [the latter]325-the latter , [she]88-mrs. dashwood would have quitted [the house]318-the house for ever , had not the entreaty of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood eldest girl]327-her eldest girl induced [her]88-mrs. dashwood first to reflect on the propriety of going , and [her]88-mrs. dashwood own tender love for [all [her]88-mrs. dashwood three children]328-all her three children determined [her]88-mrs. dashwood afterwards to stay , and for [their]328-all her three children sakes avoid a breach with [[their]328-all her three children brother]329-their brother . [Elinor]89-elinor , [this eldest daughter , whose advice was so effectual , possessed a strength of understanding]330-this eldest daughter , whose advice was so effectual , possessed a strength of understanding , and coolness of judgment , which qualified [her]89-elinor , though only nineteen , to be [the counsellor of [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother]331-the counsellor of her mother , and enabled [her]89-elinor frequently to counteract , to the advantage of [them]328-all her three children all , that eagerness of mind in [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood which must generally have led to imprudence . [She]89-elinor had an excellent heart;—her disposition was affectionate , and [her]89-elinor feelings were strong ; but [she]89-elinor knew how to govern them : it was a knowledge which [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother had yet to learn ; and which one of [[her]89-elinor sisters]334-her sisters had resolved never to be taught . [Marianne]90-marianne ’s abilities were , in many respects , quite equal to [Elinor]89-elinor ’s . [She]90-marianne was sensible and clever ; but eager in everything : [her]90-marianne sorrows , [her]90-marianne joys , could have no moderation . [She]90-marianne was generous , amiable , interesting : [she]90-marianne was everything but prudent . The resemblance between [her]90-marianne and [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother was strikingly great . [Elinor]89-elinor saw , with concern , the excess of [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister ’s sensibility ; but by [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood it was valued and cherished . [They]337-they encouraged [each other]338-each other now in the violence of [their]337-they affliction . The agony of grief which overpowered [them]337-they at first , was voluntarily renewed , was sought for , was created again and again . [They]337-they gave [themselves]337-they up wholly to [their]337-they sorrow , seeking increase of wretchedness in every reflection that could afford it , and resolved against ever admitting consolation in future . [Elinor]89-elinor , too , was deeply afflicted ; but still [she]89-elinor could struggle , [she]89-elinor could exert [herself]89-elinor . [She]89-elinor could consult with [[her]89-elinor brother]339-her brother , could receive [[her]89-elinor sister - in - law]340-her sister - in - law on [her]89-elinor arrival , and treat [her]89-elinor with proper attention ; and could strive to rouse [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother to similar exertion , and encourage [her]332-her mother to similar forbearance . [Margaret]91-margaret , [the other sister]342-the other sister , was [a good - humored , well - disposed girl]343-a good - humored , well - disposed girl ; but as [she]91-margaret had already imbibed a good deal of [Marianne]90-marianne ’s romance , without having much of [her]91-margaret sense , [she]91-margaret did not , at thirteen , bid fair to equal [[her]91-margaret sisters]334-her sisters at a more advanced period of life . CHAPTER II . [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood now installed [herself]88-mrs. dashwood [mistress of [Norland]3-norland]345-mistress of norland ; and [[her]88-mrs. dashwood mother]332-her mother and [sisters - in - law]347-sisters - in - law were degraded to the condition of [visitors]348-visitors . As such , however , [they]334-her sisters were treated by [her]88-mrs. dashwood with quiet civility ; and by [[her]88-mrs. dashwood husband]319-her husband with as much kindness as [he]319-her husband could feel towards anybody beyond [himself]319-her husband , [[his]319-her husband wife]280-his wife , and [[their]351-their child]352-their child . [He]319-her husband really pressed [them]334-her sisters , with some earnestness , to consider [Norland]3-norland as [[their]334-her sisters home]353-their home ; and , as no plan appeared so eligible to [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood as remaining [there]354-there till [she]88-mrs. dashwood could accommodate [herself]88-mrs. dashwood with [a house in [the neighbourhood]356-the neighbourhood]355-a house in the neighbourhood , [his]319-her husband invitation was accepted . A continuance in a place where everything reminded [her]88-mrs. dashwood of former delight , was exactly what suited [her]88-mrs. dashwood mind . In seasons of cheerfulness , no temper could be more cheerful than [hers]88-mrs. dashwood , or possess , in a greater degree , that sanguine expectation of happiness which is happiness itself . But in sorrow [she]88-mrs. dashwood must be equally carried away by [her]88-mrs. dashwood fancy , and as far beyond consolation as in pleasure [she]88-mrs. dashwood was beyond alloy . [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood did not at all approve of what [[her]88-mrs. dashwood husband]319-her husband intended to do for [[his]319-her husband sisters]272-his sisters . To take three thousand pounds from the fortune of [[their]359-their dear little boy]360-their dear little boy would be impoverishing [him]360-their dear little boy to the most dreadful degree . [She]88-mrs. dashwood begged [him]319-her husband to think again on the subject . How could [he]319-her husband answer it to [himself]319-her husband to rob [[his]319-her husband child]361-his child , and [[his]319-her husband only child]362-his only child too , of so large a sum ? And what possible claim could [the Miss Dashwoods]92-the miss dashwoods , who were related to [him]319-her husband only by half blood , which [she]88-mrs. dashwood considered as no relationship at all , have on [his]319-her husband generosity to so large an amount . It was very well known that no affection was ever supposed to exist between [the children of [any man]364-any man]363-the children of any man by different marriages ; and why was [he]319-her husband to ruin [himself]319-her husband , and [[their]359-their poor little [Harry]85-mr. dashwood]365-their poor little harry , by giving away all [his]319-her husband money to [[his]319-her husband half sisters]366-his half sisters ? “ It was [[my]319-her husband father]2746-my father ’s last request to [me]319-her husband , ”[319-her husband] replied [[her]88-mrs. dashwood husband]319-her husband , “ that [I]319-her husband should assist [[his]319-her husband widow]297-his widow and [daughters]281-daughters . ”[319-her husband] “ [He]319-her husband did not know what [he]319-her husband was talking of , [I]319-her husband dare say ; ten to one but [he]319-her husband was light - headed at the time . Had [he]319-her husband been in [his]319-her husband right senses , [he]319-her husband could not have thought of such a thing as begging [you]319-her husband to give away half [your]319-her husband fortune from [[your]319-her husband own child]2749-your own child . ”[319-her husband] “ [He]319-her husband did not stipulate for any particular sum , [[my]319-her husband dear]2750-my dear [Fanny]93-fanny ; [he]319-her husband only requested [me]319-her husband , in general terms , to assist [them]281-daughters , and make [their]281-daughters situation more comfortable than it was in [his]319-her husband power to do . Perhaps it would have been as well if [he]319-her husband had left it wholly to [myself]319-her husband . [He]319-her husband could hardly suppose [I]319-her husband should neglect [them]281-daughters . But as [he]319-her husband required the promise , [I]319-her husband could not do less than give it ; at least [I]319-her husband thought so at the time . The promise , therefore , was given , and must be performed . Something must be done for [them]281-daughters whenever [they]281-daughters leave [Norland]3-norland and settle in [a new home]2751-a new home . ”[319-her husband] “ Well , then , _ let _ something be done for [them]281-daughters ; but _ that _ something need not be three thousand pounds . Consider , ”[368-i] [she]368-i added , “ that when the money is once parted with , it never can return . [[Your]2752-your sisters]2753-your sisters will marry , and it will be gone for ever . If , indeed , it could be restored to [[our]2754-our poor little boy]2755-our poor little boy — ”[368-i] “ Why , to be sure , ”[319-her husband] said [[her]368-i husband]319-her husband , very gravely , “ that would make great difference . The time may come when [Harry]85-mr. dashwood will regret that so large a sum was parted with . If [he]85-mr. dashwood should have [a numerous family]2756-a numerous family , for instance , it would be a very convenient addition . ”[368-i] “ To be sure it would . ”[319-her husband] “ Perhaps , then , it would be better for [all parties]2757-all parties , if the sum were diminished one half.—Five hundred pounds would be a prodigious increase to [their]2757-all parties fortunes ! ”[368-i] “ Oh ! beyond anything great ! What [brother on earth]2758-brother on earth would do half so much for [[his]2758-brother on earth sisters]272-his sisters , even if _ really _ [[his]2758-brother on earth sisters]272-his sisters ! And as it is — only half blood!—But [you]319-her husband have such a generous spirit ! ”[368-i] “ [I]319-her husband would not wish to do any thing mean , ”[319-her husband] [he]319-her husband replied . “ [One]2761-one had rather , on such occasions , do too much than too little . [No one]317-no one , at least , can think [I]319-her husband have not done enough for [them]272-his sisters : even [themselves]272-his sisters , [they]272-his sisters can hardly expect more . ”[319-her husband] “ There is no knowing what _ [they]272-his sisters _ may expect , ”[370-the lady] said [the lady]370-the lady , “ but [we]2763-we are not to think of [their]272-his sisters expectations : the question is , what [you]319-her husband can afford to do . ”[370-the lady] “ Certainly — and [I]368-i think [I]368-i may afford to give [them]272-his sisters five hundred pounds a - piece . As it is , without any addition of [mine]368-i , [they]272-his sisters will each have about three thousand pounds on [[their]272-his sisters mother]274-their mother ’s death — a very comfortable fortune for [any young woman]2765-any young woman . ”[368-i] “ To be sure it is ; and , indeed , it strikes [me]319-her husband that [they]272-his sisters can want no addition at all . [They]272-his sisters will have ten thousand pounds divided amongst [them]272-his sisters . If [they]272-his sisters marry , [they]272-his sisters will be sure of doing well , and if [they]272-his sisters do not , [they]272-his sisters may all live very comfortably together on the interest of ten thousand pounds . ”[319-her husband] “ That is very true , and , therefore , [I]370-the lady do not know whether , upon the whole , it would not be more advisable to do something for [[their]272-his sisters mother]274-their mother while [she]274-their mother lives , rather than for [them]272-his sisters — something of the annuity kind [I]370-the lady mean.—My [sisters]301-sisters would feel the good effects of it as well as [herself]301-sisters . A hundred a year would make [them]272-his sisters all perfectly comfortable . ”[370-the lady] [[His]371-his wife]280-his wife hesitated a little , however , in giving [her]280-his wife consent to this plan . “ To be sure , ”[280-his wife] said [she]280-his wife , “ it is better than parting with fifteen hundred pounds at once . But , then , if [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood should live fifteen years [we]2768-we shall be completely taken in . ”[280-his wife] “ Fifteen years ! [[my]319-her husband dear]2750-my dear [Fanny]93-fanny ; [her]88-mrs. dashwood life can not be worth half that purchase . ”[319-her husband] “ Certainly not ; but if [you]93-fanny observe , [people]2770-people always live for ever when there is an annuity to be paid [them]2770-people ; and [she]88-mrs. dashwood is very stout and healthy , and hardly forty . An annuity is a very serious business ; it comes over and over every year , and there is no getting rid of it . [You]93-fanny are not aware of what [you]93-fanny are doing . [I]319-her husband have known a great deal of the trouble of annuities ; for [[my]319-her husband mother]2771-my mother was clogged with the payment of three to [old superannuated servants]2772-old superannuated servants by [[my]319-her husband father]2746-my father ’s will , and it is amazing how disagreeable [she]2771-my mother found it . Twice every year these annuities were to be paid ; and then there was the trouble of getting it to [them]2770-people ; and then [one of [them]2770-people]2774-one of them was said to have died , and afterwards it turned out to be no such thing . [[My]319-her husband mother]2771-my mother was quite sick of it . [Her]2771-my mother income was not [her]2771-my mother own , [she]2771-my mother said , with such perpetual claims on it ; and it was the more unkind in [[my]319-her husband father]2746-my father , because , otherwise , the money would have been entirely at [[my]319-her husband mother]2771-my mother ’s disposal , without any restriction whatever . It has given [me]319-her husband such an abhorrence of annuities , that [I]319-her husband am sure [I]319-her husband would not pin [myself]319-her husband down to the payment of one for all [the world]2778-the world . ”[319-her husband] “ It is certainly an unpleasant thing , ”[85-mr. dashwood] replied [Mr. Dashwood]85-mr. dashwood , “ to have those kind of yearly drains on [one]2761-one ’s income . [One]2761-one ’s fortune , as [[your]319-her husband mother]2781-your mother justly says , is _ not _ one ’s own . To be tied down to the regular payment of such a sum , on every rent day , is by no means desirable : it takes away [one]2761-one ’s independence . ”[85-mr. dashwood] “ Undoubtedly ; and after all [you]319-her husband have no thanks for it . [They]2783-them think [themselves]2783-them secure , [you]319-her husband do no more than what is expected , and it raises no gratitude at all . If [I]319-her husband were [you]319-her husband , whatever [I]319-her husband did should be done at [my]319-her husband own discretion entirely . [I]319-her husband would not bind [myself]319-her husband to allow [them]2783-them any thing yearly . It may be very inconvenient some years to spare a hundred , or even fifty pounds from [our]2784-our own expenses . ”[319-her husband] “ [I]319-her husband believe [you]319-her husband are right , [[my]319-her husband love]2785-my love ; it will be better that there should be no annuity in the case ; whatever [I]319-her husband may give [them]2783-them occasionally will be of far greater assistance than a yearly allowance , because [they]2783-them would only enlarge [their]2783-them style of living if [they]2783-them felt sure of a larger income , and would not be sixpence the richer for it at the end of the year . It will certainly be much the best way . A present of fifty pounds , now and then , will prevent [their]2783-them ever being distressed for money , and will , [I]319-her husband think , be amply discharging [my]319-her husband promise to [[my]319-her husband father]2746-my father . ”[319-her husband] “ To be sure it will . Indeed , to say the truth , [I]85-mr. dashwood am convinced within [myself]85-mr. dashwood that [[your]319-her husband father]2787-your father had no idea of [your]319-her husband giving [them]2783-them any money at all . The assistance [he]2787-your father thought of , [I]85-mr. dashwood dare say , was only such as might be reasonably expected of [you]319-her husband ; for instance , such as looking out for [a comfortable small house]2788-a comfortable small house for [them]2783-them , helping [them]2783-them to move [their]2783-them things , and sending [them]2783-them presents of fish and game , and so forth , whenever [they]2783-them are in season . [I]85-mr. dashwood ’ll lay [my]85-mr. dashwood life that [he]2787-your father meant nothing farther ; indeed , it would be very strange and unreasonable if [he]2787-your father did . Do but consider , [[my]85-mr. dashwood dear]2750-my dear [Mr. Dashwood]85-mr. dashwood , how excessively comfortable [[[your]319-her husband mother]2781-your mother - in - law and [[her]2781-your mother daughters]294-her daughters]2791-your mother - in - law and her daughters may live on the interest of seven thousand pounds , besides the thousand pounds belonging to [each of [the girls]2794-the girls]2793-each of the girls , which brings [them]2794-the girls in fifty pounds a year a - piece , and , of course , [they]2794-the girls will pay [[their]2794-the girls mother]274-their mother for [their]2794-the girls board out of it . Altogether , [they]2794-the girls will have five hundred a - year amongst [them]2794-the girls , and what on earth can [four women]2796-four women want for more than that?—They will live so cheap ! [Their]2794-the girls housekeeping will be nothing at all . [They]2794-the girls will have [no carriage]2797-no carriage , no horses , and hardly any [servants]2798-servants ; [they]2794-the girls will keep no company , and can have no expenses of any kind ! Only conceive how comfortable [they]2794-the girls will be ! Five hundred a year ! [I]85-mr. dashwood am sure [I]85-mr. dashwood can not imagine how [they]2794-the girls will spend half of it ; and as to [your]85-mr. dashwood giving [them]2794-the girls more , it is quite absurd to think of it . [They]2794-the girls will be much more able to give _ [you]85-mr. dashwood _ something . ”[85-mr. dashwood] “ Upon [my]85-mr. dashwood word , ”[85-mr. dashwood] said [Mr. Dashwood]85-mr. dashwood , “ [I]85-mr. dashwood believe [you]85-mr. dashwood are perfectly right . [[My]85-mr. dashwood father]2746-my father certainly could mean nothing more by [his]2746-my father request to [me]85-mr. dashwood than what [you]85-mr. dashwood say . [I]85-mr. dashwood clearly understand it now , and [I]85-mr. dashwood will strictly fulfil [my]85-mr. dashwood engagement by such acts of assistance and kindness to [them]2794-the girls as [you]85-mr. dashwood have described . When [[my]85-mr. dashwood mother]2771-my mother removes into [another house]2801-another house [my]85-mr. dashwood services shall be readily given to accommodate [her]2771-my mother as far as [I]85-mr. dashwood can . Some little present of furniture too may be acceptable then . ”[85-mr. dashwood] “ Certainly , ”[88-mrs. dashwood] returned [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood . “ But , however , _ one _ thing must be considered . When [[your]85-mr. dashwood father]2787-your father and [mother]2803-mother moved to [Norland]3-norland , though the furniture of [Stanhill]4-stanhill was sold , all the china , plate , and linen was saved , and is now left to [[your]85-mr. dashwood mother]2781-your mother . [[Her]2781-your mother house]2805-her house will therefore be almost completely fitted up as soon as [she]2781-your mother takes [it]2805-her house . ”[88-mrs. dashwood] “ That is a material consideration undoubtedly . A valuable legacy indeed ! And yet some of the plate would have been a very pleasant addition to [our]2806-our own stock here . ”[85-mr. dashwood] “ Yes ; and the set of breakfast china is twice as handsome as what belongs to [this house]2807-this house . A great deal too handsome , in [my]85-mr. dashwood opinion , for any place _ [they]2808-them _ can ever afford to live in . But , however , so it is . [[Your]85-mr. dashwood father]2787-your father thought only of _ [them]2808-them _ . And [I]85-mr. dashwood must say this : that [you]85-mr. dashwood owe no particular gratitude to [him]373-his , nor attention to [his]373-his wishes ; for [we]2806-our very well know that if [he]373-his could , [he]373-his would have left almost everything in [the world]2778-the world to _ [them]2808-them _ . ”[85-mr. dashwood] This argument was irresistible . It gave to [his]373-his intentions whatever of decision was wanting before ; and [he]373-his finally resolved , that it would be absolutely unnecessary , if not highly indecorous , to do more for [the widow and children of [[his]373-his father]290-his father]374-the widow and children of his father , than such kind of neighbourly acts as [[his]373-his own wife]376-his own wife pointed out . CHAPTER III . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood remained at [Norland]3-norland several months ; not from any disinclination to move when the sight of [every well known spot]377-every well known spot ceased to raise the violent emotion which it produced for a while ; for when [her]88-mrs. dashwood spirits began to revive , and [her]88-mrs. dashwood mind became capable of some other exertion than that of heightening its affliction by melancholy remembrances , [she]88-mrs. dashwood was impatient to be gone , and indefatigable in [her]88-mrs. dashwood inquiries for [a suitable dwelling in [the neighbourhood of [Norland]3-norland]379-the neighbourhood of norland]378-a suitable dwelling in the neighbourhood of norland ; for to remove far from [that beloved spot]380-that beloved spot was impossible . But [she]88-mrs. dashwood could hear of no situation that at once answered [her]88-mrs. dashwood notions of comfort and ease , and suited the prudence of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood eldest daughter]381-her eldest daughter , whose steadier judgment rejected [several houses]382-several houses as too large for [their]383-their income , which [[her]381-her eldest daughter mother]332-her mother would have approved . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood had been informed by [[her]88-mrs. dashwood husband]319-her husband of the solemn promise on the part of [[his]319-her husband son]283-his son in [their]383-their favour , which gave comfort to [his]319-her husband last earthly reflections . [She]88-mrs. dashwood doubted the sincerity of this assurance no more than [he]319-her husband had doubted it [himself]319-her husband , and [she]88-mrs. dashwood thought of it for [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughters]294-her daughters ’ sake with satisfaction , though as for [herself]88-mrs. dashwood [she]88-mrs. dashwood was persuaded that a much smaller provision than 7000 £ would support [her]88-mrs. dashwood in affluence . For [[their]383-their brother]329-their brother ’s sake , too , for the sake of [his]319-her husband own heart , [she]88-mrs. dashwood rejoiced ; and [she]88-mrs. dashwood reproached [herself]88-mrs. dashwood for being unjust to [his]319-her husband merit before , in believing [him]319-her husband incapable of generosity . [His]319-her husband attentive behaviour to [herself]88-mrs. dashwood and [[his]319-her husband sisters]272-his sisters convinced [her]88-mrs. dashwood that [their]383-their welfare was dear to [him]319-her husband , and , for a long time , [she]88-mrs. dashwood firmly relied on the liberality of [his]319-her husband intentions . The contempt which [she]88-mrs. dashwood had , very early in [their]383-their acquaintance , felt for [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughter - in - law]324-her daughter - in - law , was very much increased by the farther knowledge of [her]88-mrs. dashwood character , which half a year ’s residence in [[her]88-mrs. dashwood family]391-her family afforded ; and perhaps in spite of every consideration of politeness or maternal affection on the side of [the former]392-the former , [the two ladies]393-the two ladies might have found it impossible to have lived together so long , had not a particular circumstance occurred to give still greater eligibility , according to the opinions of [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , to [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughters]294-her daughters ’ continuance at [Norland]3-norland . This circumstance was a growing attachment between [[her]88-mrs. dashwood eldest girl]327-her eldest girl and [the brother of [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood]396-the brother of mrs. john dashwood , [a gentleman - like and pleasing young man]397-a gentleman - like and pleasing young man , who was introduced to [their]383-their acquaintance soon after [[his]397-a gentleman - like and pleasing young man sister]251-his sister ’s establishment at [Norland]3-norland , and who had since spent the greatest part of [his]397-a gentleman - like and pleasing young man time [there]354-there . [Some mothers]400-some mothers might have encouraged the intimacy from motives of interest , for [Edward Ferrars]94-edward was [the eldest son of [a man who had died very rich]402-a man who had died very rich ; and some might have repressed it from motives of prudence , for , except a trifling sum , the whole of [his]94-edward fortune depended on the will of [[his]94-edward mother]270-his mother]401-the eldest son of a man who had died very rich ; and some might have repressed it from motives of prudence , for , except a trifling sum , the whole of his fortune depended on the will of his mother . But [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood was alike uninfluenced by either consideration . It was enough for [her]88-mrs. dashwood that [he]94-edward appeared to be amiable , that [he]94-edward loved [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughter]404-her daughter , and that [Elinor]89-elinor returned the partiality . It was contrary to every doctrine of [hers]88-mrs. dashwood that difference of fortune should keep [any couple asunder who were attracted by resemblance of disposition]405-any couple asunder who were attracted by resemblance of disposition ; and that [Elinor]89-elinor ’s merit should not be acknowledged by [every one who knew [her]89-elinor]406-every one who knew her , was to [her]88-mrs. dashwood comprehension impossible . [Edward Ferrars]94-edward was not recommended to [their]407-they good opinion by any peculiar graces of person or address . [He]94-edward was not handsome , and [his]94-edward manners required intimacy to make [them]407-they pleasing . [He]94-edward was too diffident to do justice to [himself]94-edward ; but when [his]94-edward natural shyness was overcome , [his]94-edward behaviour gave every indication of an open , affectionate heart . [His]94-edward understanding was good , and [his]94-edward education had given it solid improvement . But [he]94-edward was neither fitted by abilities nor disposition to answer the wishes of [[his]94-edward mother]270-his mother and sister , who longed to see [him]94-edward distinguished — as — [they]407-they hardly knew what . [They]407-they wanted [him]94-edward to make a fine figure in [the world]2778-the world in some manner or other . [[His]94-edward mother]270-his mother wished to interest [him]94-edward in political concerns , to get [him]94-edward into parliament , or to see [him]94-edward connected with [some of [the great men of the day]412-the great men of the day]411-some of the great men of the day . [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood wished it likewise ; but in the mean while , till one of these superior blessings could be attained , it would have quieted [her]88-mrs. dashwood ambition to see [him]94-edward driving [a barouche]413-a barouche . But [Edward]94-edward had no turn for [great men]414-great men or barouches . All [his]94-edward wishes centered in domestic comfort and the quiet of private life . Fortunately [he]94-edward had [a younger brother who was more promising]415-a younger brother who was more promising . [Edward]94-edward had been staying several weeks in [the house]318-the house before [he]94-edward engaged much of [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood ’s attention ; for [she]88-mrs. dashwood was , at that time , in such affliction as rendered [her]88-mrs. dashwood careless of surrounding objects . [She]88-mrs. dashwood saw only that [he]94-edward was quiet and unobtrusive , and [she]88-mrs. dashwood liked [him]94-edward for it . [He]94-edward did not disturb the wretchedness of [her]88-mrs. dashwood mind by ill - timed conversation . [She]88-mrs. dashwood was first called to observe and approve [him]94-edward farther , by a reflection which [Elinor]89-elinor chanced one day to make on the difference between [him]94-edward and [[his]94-edward sister]251-his sister . It was a contrast which recommended [him]94-edward most forcibly to [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother . “ It is enough , ”[88-mrs. dashwood] said [she]88-mrs. dashwood ; “ to say that [he]94-edward is unlike [Fanny]93-fanny is enough . It implies everything amiable . [I]88-mrs. dashwood love [him]94-edward already . ”[88-mrs. dashwood] “ [I]89-elinor think [you]332-her mother will like [him]94-edward , ”[89-elinor] said [Elinor]89-elinor , “ when [you]332-her mother know more of [him]94-edward . ”[89-elinor] “ Like [him]94-edward ! ”[332-her mother] replied [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother with a smile . “ [I]332-her mother feel no sentiment of approbation inferior to love . ”[332-her mother] “ [You]332-her mother may esteem [him]94-edward . ”[89-elinor] “ [I]332-her mother have never yet known what it was to separate esteem and love . ”[332-her mother] [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood now took pains to get acquainted with [him]420-his . [Her]88-mrs. dashwood manners were attaching , and soon banished [his]420-his reserve . [She]88-mrs. dashwood speedily comprehended all [his]420-his merits ; the persuasion of [his]420-his regard for [Elinor]89-elinor perhaps assisted [her]88-mrs. dashwood penetration ; but [she]88-mrs. dashwood really felt assured of [his]420-his worth : and even that quietness of manner , which militated against all [her]88-mrs. dashwood established ideas of what [a young man]421-a young man ’s address ought to be , was no longer uninteresting when [she]88-mrs. dashwood knew [his]420-his heart to be warm and [his]420-his temper affectionate . No sooner did [she]88-mrs. dashwood perceive any symptom of love in [his]420-his behaviour to [Elinor]89-elinor , than [she]88-mrs. dashwood considered [their]422-we serious attachment as certain , and looked forward to [their]422-we marriage as rapidly approaching . “ In a few months , [[my]88-mrs. dashwood dear]2750-my dear [Marianne]90-marianne , ”[88-mrs. dashwood] said [she]88-mrs. dashwood , “ [Elinor]89-elinor will , in all probability be settled for life . [We]422-we shall miss [her]89-elinor ; but _ [she]89-elinor _ will be happy . ”[88-mrs. dashwood] “ Oh ! [Mama]95-mama , how shall [we]422-we do without [her]89-elinor ? ”[88-mrs. dashwood] “ [My]88-mrs. dashwood love , it will be scarcely a separation . [We]422-we shall live within a few miles of [each other]338-each other , and shall meet every day of [our]422-we lives . [You]90-marianne will gain [a brother]2813-a brother , [a real , affectionate brother]2814-a real , affectionate brother . [I]88-mrs. dashwood have the highest opinion in the world of [Edward]94-edward ’s heart . But [you]90-marianne look grave , [Marianne]90-marianne ; do [you]90-marianne disapprove [[your]90-marianne sister]2815-your sister ’s choice ? ”[88-mrs. dashwood] “ Perhaps , ”[90-marianne] said [Marianne]90-marianne , “ [I]90-marianne may consider it with some surprise . [Edward]94-edward is very amiable , and [I]90-marianne love [him]94-edward tenderly . But yet — [he]94-edward is not the kind of [young man]2816-young man — there is something wanting — [his]94-edward figure is not striking ; it has none of that grace which [I]90-marianne should expect in [the man who could seriously attach [[my]90-marianne sister]2818-my sister]2817-the man who could seriously attach my sister . [His]94-edward eyes want all that spirit , that fire , which at once announce virtue and intelligence . And besides all this , [I]90-marianne am afraid , [Mama]95-mama , [he]94-edward has no real taste . [Music]96-music seems scarcely to attract [him]94-edward , and though [he]94-edward admires [Elinor]89-elinor ’s drawings very much , it is not the admiration of [a person who can understand [their]2820-their worth]2819-a person who can understand their worth . It is evident , in spite of [his]94-edward frequent attention to [her]89-elinor while [she]89-elinor draws , that in fact [he]94-edward knows nothing of the matter . [He]94-edward admires as [a lover]2821-a lover , not as [a connoisseur]2822-a connoisseur . To satisfy [me]90-marianne , [those characters]2823-those characters must be united . [I]90-marianne could not be happy with [a man whose taste did not in every point coincide with [my]90-marianne own]2824-a man whose taste did not in every point coincide with my own . [He]94-edward must enter into all [my]90-marianne feelings ; the same books , the same music must charm [us]2825-us both . Oh ! [mama]2826-mama , how spiritless , how tame was [Edward]94-edward ’s manner in reading to [us]2825-us last night ! [I]90-marianne felt for [[my]90-marianne sister]2818-my sister most severely . Yet [she]2818-my sister bore it with so much composure , [she]2818-my sister seemed scarcely to notice it . [I]90-marianne could hardly keep [my]90-marianne seat . To hear those beautiful lines which have frequently almost driven [me]90-marianne wild , pronounced with such impenetrable calmness , such dreadful indifference ! ”[90-marianne] “ [He]94-edward would certainly have done more justice to simple and elegant prose . [I]88-mrs. dashwood thought so at the time ; but [you]90-marianne _ would _ give [him]94-edward [Cowper]97-cowper . ”[88-mrs. dashwood] “ Nay , [Mama]95-mama , if [he]94-edward is not to be animated by [Cowper!—but]2828-cowper!—but [we]2825-us must allow for difference of taste . [Elinor]89-elinor has not [my]90-marianne feelings , and therefore [she]89-elinor may overlook it , and be happy with [him]94-edward . But it would have broke _ [my]90-marianne _ heart , had [I]90-marianne loved [him]94-edward , to hear [him]94-edward read with so little sensibility . [Mama]95-mama , the more [I]90-marianne know of [the world]2778-the world , the more am [I]90-marianne convinced that [I]90-marianne shall never see [a man whom [I]90-marianne can really love]2830-a man whom i can really love . [I]90-marianne require so much ! [He]94-edward must have all [Edward]94-edward ’s virtues , and [his]94-edward person and manners must ornament [his]94-edward goodness with every possible charm . ”[90-marianne] “ Remember , [[my]88-mrs. dashwood love]2785-my love , that [you]2785-my love are not seventeen . It is yet too early in life to despair of such a happiness . Why should [you]2785-my love be less fortunate than [[your]2785-my love mother]2781-your mother ? In one circumstance only , [[my]88-mrs. dashwood Marianne]2833-my marianne , may [your]2785-my love destiny be different from [hers]2781-your mother ! ”[88-mrs. dashwood] CHAPTER IV . “ What a pity it is , [Elinor]89-elinor , ”[90-marianne] said [Marianne]90-marianne , “ that [Edward]94-edward should have no taste for drawing . ”[90-marianne] “ No taste for drawing ! ”[89-elinor] replied [Elinor]89-elinor , “ why should [you]90-marianne think so ? [He]94-edward does not draw [himself]94-edward , indeed , but [he]94-edward has great pleasure in seeing the performances of [other people]2834-other people , and [I]89-elinor assure [you]90-marianne [he]94-edward is by no means deficient in natural taste , though [he]94-edward has not had opportunities of improving it . Had [he]94-edward ever been in the way of learning , [I]89-elinor think [he]94-edward would have drawn very well . [He]94-edward distrusts [his]94-edward own judgment in such matters so much , that [he]94-edward is always unwilling to give [his]94-edward opinion on any picture ; but [he]94-edward has an innate propriety and simplicity of taste , which in general direct [him]94-edward perfectly right . ”[89-elinor] [Marianne]90-marianne was afraid of offending , and said no more on the subject ; but the kind of approbation which [Elinor]89-elinor described as excited in [him]423-him by the drawings of [other people]2834-other people , was very far from that rapturous delight , which , in [her]90-marianne opinion , could alone be called taste . Yet , though smiling within [herself]90-marianne at the mistake , [she]90-marianne honoured [[her]90-marianne sister]336-her sister for that blind partiality to [Edward]94-edward which produced it . “ [I]89-elinor hope , [Marianne]90-marianne , ”[89-elinor] continued [Elinor]89-elinor , “ [you]90-marianne do not consider [him]94-edward as deficient in general taste . Indeed , [I]89-elinor think [I]89-elinor may say that [you]90-marianne can not , for [your]90-marianne behaviour to [him]94-edward is perfectly cordial , and if [_]2835-_ that _ were [your]90-marianne opinion , [I]89-elinor am sure [you]90-marianne could never be civil to [him]94-edward . ”[89-elinor] [Marianne]90-marianne hardly knew what to say . [She]90-marianne would not wound the feelings of [[her]90-marianne sister]336-her sister on any account , and yet to say what [she]90-marianne did not believe was impossible . At length [she]90-marianne replied : “ Do not be offended , [Elinor]89-elinor , if [my]90-marianne praise of [him]94-edward is not in every thing equal to [your]89-elinor sense of [his]94-edward merits . [I]90-marianne have not had so many opportunities of estimating the minuter propensities of [his]94-edward mind , [his]94-edward inclinations and tastes , as [you]89-elinor have ; but [I]90-marianne have the highest opinion in [the world]2778-the world of [his]94-edward goodness and sense . [I]90-marianne think [him]94-edward every thing that is worthy and amiable . ”[90-marianne] “ [I]89-elinor am sure , ”[89-elinor] replied [Elinor]89-elinor , with a smile , “ that [[his]94-edward dearest friends]2837-his dearest friends could not be dissatisfied with such commendation as that . [I]89-elinor do not perceive how [you]90-marianne could express [yourself]90-marianne more warmly . ”[89-elinor] [Marianne]90-marianne was rejoiced to find [[her]90-marianne sister]336-her sister so easily pleased . “ Of [his]94-edward sense and [his]94-edward goodness , ”[89-elinor] continued [Elinor]89-elinor , “ [no one]317-no one can , [I]89-elinor think , be in doubt , who has seen [him]94-edward often enough to engage [him]94-edward in unreserved conversation . The excellence of [his]94-edward understanding and [his]94-edward principles can be concealed only by that shyness which too often keeps [him]94-edward silent . [You]90-marianne know enough of [him]94-edward to do justice to [his]94-edward solid worth . But of [his]94-edward minuter propensities , as [you]90-marianne call them [you]90-marianne have from peculiar circumstances been kept more ignorant than [myself]89-elinor . [He]94-edward and [I]89-elinor have been at times thrown a good deal together , while [you]90-marianne have been wholly engrossed on the most affectionate principle by [[my]89-elinor mother]2771-my mother . [I]89-elinor have seen a great deal of [him]94-edward , have studied [his]94-edward sentiments and heard [his]94-edward opinion on subjects of literature and taste ; and , upon the whole , [I]89-elinor venture to pronounce that [his]94-edward mind is well - informed , enjoyment of books exceedingly great , [his]94-edward imagination lively , [his]94-edward observation just and correct , and [his]94-edward taste delicate and pure . [His]94-edward abilities in every respect improve as much upon acquaintance as [his]94-edward manners and person . At first sight , [his]94-edward address is certainly not striking ; and [his]94-edward person can hardly be called handsome , till the expression of [his]94-edward eyes , which are uncommonly good , and the general sweetness of [his]94-edward countenance , is perceived . At present , [I]89-elinor know [him]94-edward so well , that [I]89-elinor think [him]94-edward really handsome ; or at least , almost so . What say [you]89-elinor , [Marianne]90-marianne ? ”[89-elinor] “ [I]89-elinor shall very soon think [him]94-edward handsome , [Elinor]89-elinor , if [I]89-elinor do not now . When [you]89-elinor tell [me]89-elinor to love [him]94-edward as [a brother]2813-a brother , [I]89-elinor shall no more see imperfection in [his]94-edward face , than [I]89-elinor now do in [his]94-edward heart . ”[89-elinor] [Elinor]89-elinor started at this declaration , and was sorry for the warmth [she]89-elinor had been betrayed into , in speaking of [him]428-him . [She]89-elinor felt that [Edward]94-edward stood very high in [her]89-elinor opinion . [She]89-elinor believed the regard to be mutual ; but [she]89-elinor required greater certainty of it to make [Marianne]90-marianne ’s conviction of [their]429-their attachment agreeable to [her]89-elinor . [She]89-elinor knew that what [Marianne]90-marianne and [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother conjectured one moment , [they]429-their believed the next — that with [them]429-their , to wish was to hope , and to hope was to expect . [She]89-elinor tried to explain the real state of the case to [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister . “ [I]89-elinor do not attempt to deny , ”[89-elinor] said [she]89-elinor , “ that [I]89-elinor think very highly of [him]2841-his — that [I]89-elinor greatly esteem , that [I]89-elinor like [him]2841-his . ”[89-elinor] [Marianne]90-marianne here burst forth with indignation — “ Esteem [him]2841-his ! Like [him]2841-his ! Cold - hearted [Elinor]89-elinor ! Oh ! worse than cold - hearted ! Ashamed of being otherwise . Use those words again , and [I]90-marianne will leave [the room]2842-the room this moment . ”[90-marianne] [Elinor]89-elinor could not help laughing . “ Excuse [me]89-elinor , ”[89-elinor] said [she]89-elinor ; “ and be assured that [I]89-elinor meant no offence to [you]89-elinor , by speaking , in so quiet a way , of [my]89-elinor own feelings . Believe [them]2843-them to be stronger than [I]89-elinor have declared ; believe [them]2843-them , in short , to be such as [his]2841-his merit , and the suspicion — the hope of [his]2841-his affection for [me]89-elinor may warrant , without imprudence or folly . But farther than this [you]89-elinor must _ not _ believe . [I]89-elinor am by no means assured of [his]2841-his regard for [me]89-elinor . There are moments when the extent of it seems doubtful ; and till [his]2841-his sentiments are fully known , [you]89-elinor can not wonder at [my]89-elinor wishing to avoid any encouragement of [my]89-elinor own partiality , by believing or calling it more than it is . In [my]89-elinor heart [I]89-elinor feel little — scarcely any doubt of [his]2841-his preference . But there are other points to be considered besides [his]2841-his inclination . [He]2841-his is very far from being independent . What [[his]2841-his mother]270-his mother really is [we]2845-we can not know ; but , from [Fanny]93-fanny ’s occasional mention of [her]93-fanny conduct and opinions , [we]2845-we have never been disposed to think [her]93-fanny amiable ; and [I]89-elinor am very much mistaken if [Edward]94-edward is not [himself]94-edward aware that there would be many difficulties in [his]2841-his way , if [he]2841-his were to wish to marry [a woman who had not either a great fortune or high rank]2846-a woman who had not either a great fortune or high rank . ”[89-elinor] [Marianne]90-marianne was astonished to find how much the imagination of [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother and [herself]90-marianne had outstripped the truth . “ And [you]90-marianne really are not engaged to [him]2841-his ! ”[90-marianne] said [she]90-marianne . “ Yet it certainly soon will happen . But two advantages will proceed from this delay . _ [I]90-marianne _ shall not lose [you]90-marianne so soon , and [Edward]94-edward will have greater opportunity of improving that natural taste for [your]90-marianne favourite pursuit which must be so indispensably necessary to [your]90-marianne future felicity . Oh ! if [he]94-edward should be so far stimulated by [your]90-marianne genius as to learn to draw [himself]94-edward , how delightful it would be ! ”[90-marianne] [Elinor]89-elinor had given [her]89-elinor real opinion to [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister . [She]89-elinor could not consider [her]89-elinor partiality for [Edward]94-edward in so prosperous a state as [Marianne]90-marianne had believed it . There was , at times , a want of spirits about [him]94-edward which , if it did not denote indifference , spoke of something almost as unpromising . A doubt of [her]89-elinor regard , supposing [him]94-edward to feel it , need not give [him]94-edward more than inquietude . It would not be likely to produce that dejection of mind which frequently attended [him]94-edward . A more reasonable cause might be found in the dependent situation which forbade the indulgence of [his]94-edward affection . [She]89-elinor knew that [[his]94-edward mother]270-his mother neither behaved to [him]94-edward so as to make [[his]94-edward home]252-his home comfortable at present , nor to give [him]94-edward any assurance that [he]94-edward might form [a home]436-a home for [himself]94-edward , without strictly attending to [her]89-elinor views for [his]94-edward aggrandizement . With such a knowledge as this , it was impossible for [Elinor]89-elinor to feel easy on the subject . [She]89-elinor was far from depending on that result of [his]94-edward preference of [her]89-elinor , which [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother and [sister]438-sister still considered as certain . Nay , the longer [they]439-they were together the more doubtful seemed the nature of [his]94-edward regard ; and sometimes , for a few painful minutes , [she]89-elinor believed it to be no more than friendship . But , whatever might really be its limits , it was enough , when perceived by [[his]94-edward sister]251-his sister , to make [her]89-elinor uneasy , and at the same time , ( which was still more common , ) to make [her]89-elinor uncivil . [She]89-elinor took the first opportunity of affronting [[her]89-elinor mother - in - law]313-her mother - in - law on the occasion , talking to [her]313-her mother - in - law so expressively of [[her]89-elinor brother]339-her brother ’s great expectations , of [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward ’s resolution that both [[her]98-edward sons]443-her sons should marry well , and of the danger attending [any young woman who attempted to _ draw [him]94-edward in]444-any young woman who attempted to _ draw him in ; _ that [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood could neither pretend to be unconscious , nor endeavor to be calm . [She]89-elinor gave [her]89-elinor an answer which marked [her]89-elinor contempt , and instantly left [the room]2842-the room , resolving that , whatever might be the inconvenience or expense of so sudden a removal , [[her]89-elinor beloved]446-her beloved [Elinor]89-elinor should not be exposed another week to such insinuations . In this state of [her]89-elinor spirits , a letter was delivered to [her]89-elinor from the post , which contained a proposal particularly well timed . It was the offer of [a small house]447-a small house , on very easy terms , belonging to [a relation of [her]89-elinor own]448-a relation of her own , [a gentleman of consequence and property in [Devonshire]5-devonshire]449-a gentleman of consequence and property in devonshire . The letter was from [this gentleman]450-this gentleman [himself]450-this gentleman , and written in the true spirit of friendly accommodation . [He]94-edward understood that [she]89-elinor was in need of [a dwelling]451-a dwelling ; and though [the house [he]94-edward now offered [her]89-elinor]452-the house he now offered her was merely [a cottage]453-a cottage , [he]94-edward assured [her]89-elinor that everything should be done to [it]452-the house he now offered her which [she]89-elinor might think necessary , if the situation pleased [her]89-elinor . [He]94-edward earnestly pressed [her]89-elinor , after giving the particulars of [the house]318-the house and [garden]455-garden , to come with [[her]89-elinor daughters]294-her daughters to [Barton Park]6-barton park , [the place of [[his]94-edward own residence]458-his own residence]457-the place of his own residence , from whence [she]89-elinor might judge , [herself]89-elinor , whether [Barton Cottage]7-barton cottage , for [the houses]459-the houses were in [the same parish]460-the same parish , could , by any alteration , be made comfortable to [her]89-elinor . [He]94-edward seemed really anxious to accommodate [them]294-her daughters and the whole of [his]94-edward letter was written in so friendly a style as could not fail of giving pleasure to [[his]94-edward cousin]461-his cousin ; more especially at a moment when [she]89-elinor was suffering under the cold and unfeeling behaviour of [[her]89-elinor nearer connections]462-her nearer connections . [She]89-elinor needed no time for deliberation or inquiry . [Her]89-elinor resolution was formed as [she]89-elinor read . The situation of [Barton]8-barton , in [a county so far distant from]463-a county so far distant from [Sussex]1-sussex as [Devonshire]5-devonshire , which , but a few hours before , would have been a sufficient objection to outweigh every possible advantage belonging to [the place]464-the place , was now its first recommendation . To quit [the neighbourhood of Norland]379-the neighbourhood of norland was no longer an evil ; it was an object of desire ; it was a blessing , in comparison of the misery of continuing [[[her]89-elinor daughter]404-her daughter - in - law ’s guest]467-her daughter - in - law ’s guest ; and to remove for ever from [that beloved place]468-that beloved place would be less painful than to inhabit or visit [it]468-that beloved place while [such a woman]469-such a woman was [its mistress]470-its mistress . [She]89-elinor instantly wrote [Sir John]99-sir john Middleton [her]89-elinor acknowledgment of [his]99-sir john kindness , and [her]89-elinor acceptance of [his]99-sir john proposal ; and then hastened to show both letters to [[her]89-elinor daughters]294-her daughters , that [she]89-elinor might be secure of [their]294-her daughters approbation before [her]89-elinor answer were sent . [Elinor]89-elinor had always thought it would be more prudent for [them]294-her daughters to settle at some distance from [Norland]3-norland , than immediately amongst [[their]294-her daughters present acquaintance]472-their present acquaintance . On _ that _ head , therefore , it was not for [her]89-elinor to oppose [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother ’s intention of removing into [Devonshire]5-devonshire . [The house]318-the house , too , as described by [Sir John]99-sir john , was on so simple a scale , and the rent so uncommonly moderate , as to leave [her]89-elinor no right of objection on either point ; and , therefore , though it was not a plan which brought any charm to [her]89-elinor fancy , though it was a removal from [the vicinity of [Norland]3-norland]475-the vicinity of norland beyond [her]89-elinor wishes , [she]89-elinor made no attempt to dissuade [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother from sending a letter of acquiescence . CHAPTER V. No sooner was [her]89-elinor answer dispatched , than [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood indulged [herself]88-mrs. dashwood in the pleasure of announcing to [[her]88-mrs. dashwood son - in - law]477-her son - in - law and [[his]477-her son - in - law wife]280-his wife that [she]88-mrs. dashwood was provided with [a house]479-a house , and should incommode [them]480-them no longer than till every thing were ready for [her]88-mrs. dashwood inhabiting [it]479-a house . [They]480-them heard [her]88-mrs. dashwood with surprise . [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood said nothing ; but [[her]88-mrs. dashwood husband]319-her husband civilly hoped that [she]88-mrs. dashwood would not be settled far from [Norland]3-norland . [She]88-mrs. dashwood had great satisfaction in replying that [she]88-mrs. dashwood was going into [Devonshire.—Edward]9-devonshire.—edward turned hastily towards [her]88-mrs. dashwood , on hearing this , and , in a voice of surprise and concern , which required no explanation to [her]88-mrs. dashwood , repeated , “ [Devonshire]5-devonshire ! Are [you]88-mrs. dashwood , indeed , going [there]354-there ? So far from hence ! And to what part of it ? ”[88-mrs. dashwood] [She]88-mrs. dashwood explained the situation . [It]479-a house was within [four miles northward of [Exeter]10-exeter]482-four miles northward of exeter . “ [It]479-a house is but [a cottage]453-a cottage , ”[88-mrs. dashwood] [she]88-mrs. dashwood continued , “ but [I]88-mrs. dashwood hope to see [many of [[my]88-mrs. dashwood friends]2850-my friends in [it]479-a house]2849-many of my friends in it . [A room or two]2851-a room or two can easily be added ; and if [[my]88-mrs. dashwood friends]2850-my friends find no difficulty in travelling so far to see [me]88-mrs. dashwood , [I]88-mrs. dashwood am sure [I]88-mrs. dashwood will find none in accommodating [them]2850-my friends . ”[88-mrs. dashwood] [She]88-mrs. dashwood concluded with a very kind invitation to [Mr.]483-mr. and [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood to visit [her]88-mrs. dashwood at [Barton]8-barton ; and to [Edward]98-edward [she]88-mrs. dashwood gave one with still greater affection . Though [her]88-mrs. dashwood late conversation with [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughter - in - law]324-her daughter - in - law had made [her]88-mrs. dashwood resolve on remaining at [Norland]3-norland no longer than was unavoidable , it had not produced the smallest effect on [her]88-mrs. dashwood in that point to which it principally tended . To separate [Edward]98-edward and [Elinor]89-elinor was as far from being [her]88-mrs. dashwood object as ever ; and [she]88-mrs. dashwood wished to show [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , by this pointed invitation to [[her]88-mrs. dashwood brother]339-her brother , how totally [she]88-mrs. dashwood disregarded [her]88-mrs. dashwood disapprobation of the match . [Mr. John Dashwood]87-mr. john dashwood told [[his]87-mr. john dashwood mother]270-his mother again and again how exceedingly sorry [he]87-mr. john dashwood was that [she]270-his mother had taken [a house at such a distance from [Norland]3-norland]487-a house at such a distance from norland as to prevent [his]87-mr. john dashwood being of any service to [her]270-his mother in removing [her]270-his mother furniture . [He]87-mr. john dashwood really felt conscientiously vexed on the occasion ; for the very exertion to which [he]87-mr. john dashwood had limited the performance of [his]87-mr. john dashwood promise to [[his]87-mr. john dashwood father]290-his father was by this arrangement rendered impracticable.—The furniture was all sent around by water . It chiefly consisted of household linen , plate , china , and books , with a handsome pianoforte of [Marianne]90-marianne ’s . [Mrs. John Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood saw the packages depart with a sigh : [she]88-mrs. dashwood could not help feeling it hard that as [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood ’s income would be so trifling in comparison with [their]489-their own , [she]88-mrs. dashwood should have any handsome article of furniture . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood took [the house]318-the house for a twelvemonth ; [it]318-the house was ready furnished , and [she]88-mrs. dashwood might have immediate possession . No difficulty arose on either side in the agreement ; and [she]88-mrs. dashwood waited only for the disposal of [her]88-mrs. dashwood effects at [Norland]3-norland , and to determine [[her]88-mrs. dashwood future household]491-her future household , before [she]88-mrs. dashwood set off for [the west]492-the west ; and this , as [she]88-mrs. dashwood was exceedingly rapid in the performance of everything that interested [her]88-mrs. dashwood , was soon done.—The horses which were left [her]88-mrs. dashwood by [[her]88-mrs. dashwood husband]319-her husband had been sold soon after [his]319-her husband death , and an opportunity now offering of disposing of [her]88-mrs. dashwood carriage , [she]88-mrs. dashwood agreed to sell that likewise at the earnest advice of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood eldest daughter]381-her eldest daughter . For the comfort of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood children]495-her children , had [she]88-mrs. dashwood consulted only [her]88-mrs. dashwood own wishes , [she]88-mrs. dashwood would have kept it ; but the discretion of [Elinor]89-elinor prevailed . _ [Her]88-mrs. dashwood _ wisdom too limited the number of [[their]496-their servants]497-their servants to three ; [two maids]498-two maids and [a man]499-a man , with whom [they]496-their were speedily provided from amongst [those who had formed [[their]496-their establishment at [Norland]3-norland]501-their establishment at norland]500-those who had formed their establishment at norland . [The man]502-the man and [one of [the maids]504-the maids]503-one of the maids were sent off immediately into [Devonshire]5-devonshire , to prepare [the house]318-the house for [[their]496-their mistress]506-their mistress ’s arrival ; for as [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton was entirely unknown to [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , [she]100-lady middleton preferred going directly to [the cottage]507-the cottage to being [a visitor at [Barton Park]6-barton park]508-a visitor at barton park ; and [she]100-lady middleton relied so undoubtingly on [Sir John]99-sir john ’s description of [the house]318-the house , as to feel no curiosity to examine [it]318-the house [herself]100-lady middleton till [she]100-lady middleton entered [it]318-the house as [her]100-lady middleton own . [Her]100-lady middleton eagerness to be gone from [Norland]3-norland was preserved from diminution by the evident satisfaction of [[her]100-lady middleton daughter - in - law]324-her daughter - in - law in the prospect of [her]100-lady middleton removal ; a satisfaction which was but feebly attempted to be concealed under a cold invitation to [her]100-lady middleton to defer [her]100-lady middleton departure . Now was the time when [[her]100-lady middleton son - in - law]477-her son - in - law ’s promise to [[his]477-her son - in - law father]290-his father might with particular propriety be fulfilled . Since [he]290-his father had neglected to do it on first coming to [the estate]288-the estate , [their]514-their quitting [[his]290-his father house]515-his house might be looked on as the most suitable period for its accomplishment . But [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood began shortly to give over every hope of the kind , and to be convinced , from the general drift of [his]290-his father discourse , that [his]290-his father assistance extended no farther than [their]514-their maintenance for six months at [Norland]3-norland . [He]290-his father so frequently talked of the increasing expenses of housekeeping , and of the perpetual demands upon [his]290-his father purse , which [a man of any consequence]516-a man of any consequence in [the world]2778-the world was beyond calculation exposed to , that [he]290-his father seemed rather to stand in need of more money [himself]290-his father than to have any design of giving money away . In a very few weeks from the day which brought [Sir John Middleton]99-sir john ’s first letter to [Norland]3-norland , every thing was so far settled in [[their]514-their future abode]518-their future abode as to enable [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood and [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughters]294-her daughters to begin [their]514-their journey . Many were the tears shed by [them]514-their in [their]514-their last adieus to a place so much beloved . “ Dear , [dear Norland]3-norland ! ”[90-marianne] said [Marianne]90-marianne , as [she]90-marianne wandered alone before [the house]318-the house , on the last evening of [their]514-their being [there]354-there ; “ when shall [I]90-marianne cease to regret you!—when learn to feel [a home]436-a home elsewhere!—Oh ! [happy house]2854-happy house , could [you]3-norland know what [I]90-marianne suffer in now viewing [you]3-norland from [this spot]2855-this spot , from whence perhaps [I]90-marianne may view [you]3-norland no more!—And [you]3-norland , [ye]3-norland well - known trees!—but [you]3-norland will continue the same.—No leaf will decay because [we]522-they are removed , nor any branch become motionless although [we]522-they can observe [you]3-norland no longer!—No ; [you]3-norland will continue the same ; unconscious of the pleasure or the regret [you]3-norland occasion , and insensible of any change in those who walk under [your]3-norland shade!—But who will remain to enjoy [you]3-norland ? ”[90-marianne] CHAPTER VI . The first part of [their]522-they journey was performed in too melancholy a disposition to be otherwise than tedious and unpleasant . But as [they]522-they drew towards the end of it , [their]522-they interest in the appearance of [a country which [they]522-they were to inhabit]523-a country which they were to inhabit overcame [their]522-they dejection , and a view of [Barton Valley]11-barton valley as [they]522-they entered [it]11-barton valley gave [them]522-they cheerfulness . [It]11-barton valley was [a pleasant fertile spot]524-a pleasant fertile spot , well wooded , and rich in pasture . After winding along [it]11-barton valley for more than a mile , [they]522-they reached [[their]522-they own house]525-their own house . [A small green court]526-a small green court was the whole of [[its]525-their own house demesne]527-its demesne in front ; and a neat wicket gate admitted [them]522-they into [it]525-their own house . As [a house]479-a house , [Barton Cottage]7-barton cottage , though small , was comfortable and compact ; but as [a cottage]453-a cottage [it]7-barton cottage was defective , for [the building]530-the building was regular , the roof was tiled , the window shutters were not painted green , nor were the walls covered with honeysuckles . A narrow passage led directly through [the house]318-the house into [the garden]532-the garden behind . On each side of the entrance was [a sitting room]533-a sitting room , about sixteen feet square ; and beyond [them]533-a sitting room were [the offices]534-the offices and the stairs . [Four bed - rooms]535-four bed - rooms and two garrets formed the rest of [the house]318-the house . [It]318-the house had not been built many years and was in good repair . In comparison of [Norland]3-norland , [it]318-the house was poor and small indeed!—but the tears which recollection called forth as [they]522-they entered [the house]318-the house were soon dried away . [They]522-they were cheered by the joy of [the servants]538-the servants on [their]522-they arrival , and each for the sake of [the others]539-the others resolved to appear happy . It was very early in September ; the season was fine , and from first seeing [the place]464-the place under the advantage of good weather , [they]522-they received an impression in [its]318-the house favour which was of material service in recommending [it]318-the house to [their]522-they lasting approbation . The situation of [the house]318-the house was good . [High hills]542-high hills rose immediately behind , and at no great distance on each side ; some of which were open downs , the others cultivated and woody . [The village of [Barton]8-barton]543-the village of barton was chiefly on [one of these hills]544-one of these hills , and formed a pleasant view from [the cottage]507-the cottage windows . The prospect in front was more extensive ; it commanded [the whole of [the valley]547-the valley]546-the whole of the valley , and reached into [the country beyond]548-the country beyond . [The hills which surrounded [the cottage]507-the cottage]549-the hills which surrounded the cottage terminated [the valley]547-the valley in that direction ; under another name , and in another course , [it]549-the hills which surrounded the cottage branched out again between two of [the steepest of [them]549-the hills which surrounded the cottage]552-the steepest of them . With the size and furniture of [the house]318-the house [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood was upon the whole well satisfied ; for though [her]88-mrs. dashwood former style of life rendered many additions to the latter indispensable , yet to add and improve was a delight to [her]88-mrs. dashwood ; and [she]88-mrs. dashwood had at this time ready money enough to supply all that was wanted of greater elegance to [the apartments]554-the apartments . “ As for [the house itself]2856-the house itself , to be sure , ”[88-mrs. dashwood] said [she]88-mrs. dashwood , “ it is too small for [[our]2857-our family]2858-our family , but [we]2857-our will make [ourselves]2857-our tolerably comfortable for the present , as it is too late in the year for improvements . Perhaps in the spring , if [I]88-mrs. dashwood have plenty of money , as [I]88-mrs. dashwood dare say [I]88-mrs. dashwood shall , [we]2857-our may think about building . [These parlors]2859-these parlors are both too small for such parties of [[our]2857-our friends]2860-our friends as [I]88-mrs. dashwood hope to see often collected [here]2861-here ; and [I]88-mrs. dashwood have some thoughts of throwing [the passage]2862-the passage into one of them with perhaps a part of the other , and so leave the remainder of that other for an entrance ; this , with [a new drawing room]2863-a new drawing room which may be easily added , and a bed - chamber and garret above , will make it [a very snug little cottage]2864-a very snug little cottage . [I]88-mrs. dashwood could wish the stairs were handsome . But [one]2761-one must not expect every thing ; though [I]88-mrs. dashwood suppose it would be no difficult matter to widen them . [I]88-mrs. dashwood shall see how much [I]88-mrs. dashwood am before - hand with [the world]2778-the world in the spring , and [we]2867-we will plan [our]2867-we improvements accordingly . ”[88-mrs. dashwood] In the mean time , till all these alterations could be made from the savings of an income of five hundred a - year by [a woman who never saved in [her]555-a woman who never saved in her life life]555-a woman who never saved in her life , [they]556-their were wise enough to be contented with [the house]318-the house as [it]318-the house was ; and [each of [them]556-their]558-each of them was busy in arranging [their]556-their particular concerns , and endeavoring , by placing around [them]556-their books and other possessions , to form [themselves]556-their a home . [Marianne]90-marianne ’s pianoforte was unpacked and properly disposed of ; and [Elinor]89-elinor ’s drawings were affixed to the walls of [[their]556-their sitting room]559-their sitting room . In such employments as these [they]556-their were interrupted soon after breakfast the next day by the entrance of [[their]556-their landlord]560-their landlord , who called to welcome [them]556-their to [Barton]8-barton , and to offer [them]556-their every accommodation from [[his]560-their landlord own house]561-his own house and garden in which [theirs]556-their might at present be deficient . [Sir John Middleton]99-sir john was [a good looking man about forty]562-a good looking man about forty . [He]99-sir john had formerly visited at [Stanhill]4-stanhill , but it was too long for [[his]99-sir john young cousins]563-his young cousins to remember [him]99-sir john . [His]99-sir john countenance was thoroughly good - humoured ; and [his]99-sir john manners were as friendly as the style of [his]99-sir john letter .
