[Their]556-their arrival seemed to afford [him]99-sir john real satisfaction , and [their]556-their comfort to be an object of real solicitude to [him]99-sir john . [He]99-sir john said much of [his]99-sir john earnest desire of [their]556-their living in the most sociable terms with [[his]99-sir john family]564-his family , and pressed [them]556-their so cordially to dine at [Barton Park]6-barton park every day till [they]556-their were better settled at [home]565-home , that , though [his]99-sir john entreaties were carried to a point of perseverance beyond civility , [they]556-their could not give offence . [His]99-sir john kindness was not confined to words ; for within an hour after [he]99-sir john left [them]556-their , a large basket full of garden stuff and fruit arrived from [the park]566-the park , which was followed before the end of the day by a present of game . [He]99-sir john insisted , moreover , on conveying all [their]556-their letters to and from the post for [them]556-their , and would not be denied the satisfaction of sending [them]556-their [his]99-sir john newspaper every day . [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton had sent a very civil message by [him]99-sir john , denoting [her]100-lady middleton intention of waiting on [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood as soon as [she]100-lady middleton could be assured that [her]100-lady middleton visit would be no inconvenience ; and as this message was answered by an invitation equally polite , [[her]100-lady middleton ladyship]567-her ladyship was introduced to [them]556-their the next day . [They]556-their were , of course , very anxious to see [a person on whom so much of [their]556-their comfort at [Barton]8-barton]568-a person on whom so much of their comfort at barton must depend ; and the elegance of [her]100-lady middleton appearance was favourable to [their]556-their wishes . [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton was not more than six or seven and twenty ; [her]100-lady middleton face was handsome , [her]100-lady middleton figure tall and striking , and [her]100-lady middleton address graceful . [Her]100-lady middleton manners had all the elegance which [[her]100-lady middleton husband]319-her husband ’s wanted . But they would have been improved by some share of [his]319-her husband frankness and warmth ; and [her]100-lady middleton visit was long enough to detract something from [their]556-their first admiration , by showing that , though perfectly well - bred , [she]100-lady middleton was reserved , cold , and had nothing to say for [herself]100-lady middleton beyond the most common - place inquiry or remark . Conversation however was not wanted , for [Sir John]99-sir john was very chatty , and [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton had taken the wise precaution of bringing with [her]100-lady middleton [[their]556-their eldest child]570-their eldest child , [a fine little boy about six years old]571-a fine little boy about six years old , by which means there was one subject always to be recurred to by [the ladies]572-the ladies in case of extremity , for [they]572-the ladies had to enquire [his]319-her husband name and age , admire [his]319-her husband beauty , and ask [him]319-her husband questions which [[his]319-her husband mother]270-his mother answered for [him]319-her husband , while [he]319-her husband hung about [her]100-lady middleton and held down [his]319-her husband head , to the great surprise of [[her]100-lady middleton ladyship]567-her ladyship , who wondered at [his]319-her husband being so shy before company , as [he]319-her husband could make noise enough at [home]565-home . On every formal visit [a child]576-a child ought to be of [the party]577-the party , by way of provision for discourse . In the present case it took up ten minutes to determine whether [the boy]578-the boy were most like [[his]578-the boy father]290-his father or [mother]2803-mother , and in what particular [he]578-the boy resembled either , for of course every body differed , and [every body]581-every body was astonished at the opinion of [the others]539-the others . An opportunity was soon to be given to the Dashwoods of debating on [the rest of [the children]264-the children]583-the rest of the children , as [Sir John]99-sir john would not leave [the house]318-the house without securing [their]264-the children promise of dining at [the park]566-the park the next day . CHAPTER VII . [Barton Park]6-barton park was about half a mile from [the cottage]507-the cottage . [The ladies]572-the ladies had passed near [it]6-barton park in [their]572-the ladies way along [the valley]547-the valley , but [it]6-barton park was screened from [their]572-the ladies view at [home]565-home by the projection of [a hill]591-a hill . [The house]318-the house was large and handsome ; and [the Middletons]102-the middletons lived in a style of equal hospitality and elegance . The former was for [Sir John]99-sir john ’s gratification , the latter for that of [[his]99-sir john lady]593-his lady . [They]264-the children were scarcely ever without [some friends]594-some friends staying with [them]264-the children in [the house]318-the house , and [they]264-the children kept more company of every kind than [any other family in [the neighbourhood]356-the neighbourhood]596-any other family in the neighbourhood . It was necessary to the happiness of both ; for however dissimilar in temper and outward behaviour , [they]264-the children strongly resembled [each other]338-each other in that total want of talent and taste which confined [their]264-the children employments , unconnected with such as society produced , within a very narrow compass . [Sir John]99-sir john was [a sportsman]599-a sportsman , [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton [a mother]600-a mother . [He]99-sir john hunted and shot , and [she]100-lady middleton humoured [[her]100-lady middleton children]495-her children ; and these were [their]264-the children only resources . [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton had the advantage of being able to spoil [[her]100-lady middleton children]495-her children all the year round , while [Sir John]99-sir john ’s independent employments were in existence only half the time . Continual engagements at [home]565-home and abroad , however , supplied all the deficiencies of nature and education ; supported the good spirits of [Sir John]99-sir john , and gave exercise to the good breeding of [[his]99-sir john wife]280-his wife . [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton piqued [herself]100-lady middleton upon the elegance of [her]100-lady middleton table , and of all [her]100-lady middleton domestic arrangements ; and from this kind of vanity was [her]100-lady middleton greatest enjoyment in any of [their]605-their parties . But [Sir John]99-sir john ’s satisfaction in society was much more real ; [he]99-sir john delighted in collecting about [him]99-sir john [more young people than [[his]99-sir john house]515-his house would hold]606-more young people than his house would hold , and the noisier [they]606-more young people than his house would hold were the better was [he]99-sir john pleased . [He]99-sir john was a blessing to [all the juvenile part of [the neighbourhood]356-the neighbourhood]608-all the juvenile part of the neighbourhood , for in summer [he]99-sir john was for ever forming parties to eat cold ham and chicken out of doors , and in winter [his]99-sir john private balls were numerous enough for [any young lady who was not suffering under the unsatiable appetite of fifteen]610-any young lady who was not suffering under the unsatiable appetite of fifteen . The arrival of [a new family]611-a new family in [the country]612-the country was always a matter of joy to [him]99-sir john , and in every point of view [he]99-sir john was charmed with [the inhabitants [he]99-sir john had now procured for [[his]99-sir john cottage at [Barton]8-barton]614-his cottage at barton]613-the inhabitants he had now procured for his cottage at barton . [The Miss Dashwoods]92-the miss dashwoods were young , pretty , and unaffected . It was enough to secure [his]99-sir john good opinion ; for to be unaffected was all that [a pretty girl]615-a pretty girl could want to make [her]615-a pretty girl mind as captivating as [[her]615-a pretty girl person]616-her person . The friendliness of [his]99-sir john disposition made [him]99-sir john happy in accommodating those , whose situation might be considered , in comparison with the past , as unfortunate . In showing kindness to [[his]99-sir john cousins]617-his cousins therefore [he]99-sir john had the real satisfaction of a good heart ; and in settling [a family of females]618-a family of females only in [[his]99-sir john cottage]619-his cottage , [he]99-sir john had all the satisfaction of [a sportsman]599-a sportsman ; for [a sportsman]599-a sportsman , though [he]599-a sportsman esteems only those of [his]599-a sportsman sex who are [sportsmen]622-sportsmen likewise , is not often desirous of encouraging [their]617-his cousins taste by admitting [them]617-his cousins to [a residence within [[his]599-a sportsman own manor]624-his own manor]623-a residence within his own manor . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood and [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughters]294-her daughters were met at the door of [the house]318-the house by [Sir John]99-sir john , who welcomed [them]617-his cousins to [Barton Park]6-barton park with unaffected sincerity ; and as [he]99-sir john attended [them]617-his cousins to [the drawing room]627-the drawing room repeated to [the young ladies]628-the young ladies the concern which the same subject had drawn from [him]99-sir john the day before , at being unable to get [any smart young men]629-any smart young men to meet [them]617-his cousins . [They]628-the young ladies would see , [he]99-sir john said , only [one gentleman there besides [himself]99-sir john]630-one gentleman there besides himself ; [a particular friend who was staying at [the park]566-the park , but who was neither very young nor very gay]631-a particular friend who was staying at the park , but who was neither very young nor very gay . [He]99-sir john hoped [they]628-the young ladies would all excuse the smallness of the party , and could assure [them]628-the young ladies it should never happen so again . [He]99-sir john had been to [several families]633-several families that morning in hopes of procuring some addition to [[their]628-the young ladies number]634-their number , but it was moonlight and every body was full of engagements . [[Luckily Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton ’s mother]635-luckily lady middleton ’s mother had arrived at [Barton]8-barton within the last hour , and as [she]635-luckily lady middleton ’s mother was [a very cheerful agreeable woman]636-a very cheerful agreeable woman , [he]99-sir john hoped [the young ladies]628-the young ladies would not find it so very dull as [they]628-the young ladies might imagine . [The young ladies]628-the young ladies , as well as [[their]628-the young ladies mother]274-their mother , were perfectly satisfied with having [two entire strangers of the party]640-two entire strangers of the party , and wished for no more . [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings , [[Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton ’s mother]641-lady middleton ’s mother , was [a good - humoured , merry , fat , elderly woman , who talked a great deal , seemed very happy , and rather vulgar]642-a good - humoured , merry , fat , elderly woman , who talked a great deal , seemed very happy , and rather vulgar . [She]641-lady middleton ’s mother was full of jokes and laughter , and before dinner was over had said many witty things on the subject of [lovers]643-lovers and [husbands]644-husbands ; hoped [they]628-the young ladies had not left [their]628-the young ladies hearts behind [them]628-the young ladies in [Sussex]1-sussex , and pretended to see [them]628-the young ladies blush whether [they]628-the young ladies did or not . [Marianne]90-marianne was vexed at it for [[her]90-marianne sister]336-her sister ’s sake , and turned [her]90-marianne eyes towards [Elinor]89-elinor to see how [she]89-elinor bore these attacks , with an earnestness which gave [Elinor]89-elinor far more pain than could arise from such common - place raillery as [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings ’s . [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon , [the friend of [Sir John]99-sir john]646-the friend of sir john , seemed no more adapted by resemblance of manner to be [[his]104-colonel brandon friend]647-his friend , than [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton was to be [[his]104-colonel brandon wife]280-his wife , or [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings to be [[Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton ’s mother]641-lady middleton ’s mother . [He]104-colonel brandon was silent and grave . [His]104-colonel brandon appearance however was not unpleasing , in spite of [his]104-colonel brandon being in the opinion of [Marianne]90-marianne and [Margaret]91-margaret [an absolute old bachelor]650-an absolute old bachelor , for [he]104-colonel brandon was on the wrong side of five and thirty ; but though [his]104-colonel brandon face was not handsome , [his]104-colonel brandon countenance was sensible , and [his]104-colonel brandon address was particularly gentlemanlike . There was nothing in any of the party which could recommend [them]651-them as [companions to [the Dashwoods]92-the miss dashwoods]652-companions to the dashwoods ; but the cold insipidity of [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton was so particularly repulsive , that in comparison of it the gravity of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon , and even the boisterous mirth of [Sir John]99-sir john and [[his]99-sir john mother - in - law]300-his mother - in - law was interesting . [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton seemed to be roused to enjoyment only by the entrance of [[her]100-lady middleton four noisy children]654-her four noisy children after dinner , who pulled [her]100-lady middleton about , tore [her]100-lady middleton clothes , and put an end to every kind of discourse except what related to [themselves]654-her four noisy children . In the evening , as [Marianne]90-marianne was discovered to be musical , [she]90-marianne was invited to play . The instrument was unlocked , every body prepared to be charmed , and [Marianne]90-marianne , who sang very well , at [their]654-her four noisy children request went through the chief of the songs which [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton had brought into [the family]303-the family on [her]100-lady middleton marriage , and which perhaps had lain ever since in the same position on the pianoforte , for [[her]90-marianne ladyship]567-her ladyship had celebrated that event by giving up music , although by [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother ’s account , [she]90-marianne had played extremely well , and by [her]90-marianne own was very fond of it . [Marianne]90-marianne ’s performance was highly applauded . [Sir John]99-sir john was loud in [his]99-sir john admiration at the end of every song , and as loud in [his]99-sir john conversation with [the others]539-the others while every song lasted . [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton frequently called [him]99-sir john to order , wondered how [any one]659-any one ’s attention could be diverted from music for a moment , and asked [Marianne]90-marianne to sing a particular song which [Marianne]90-marianne had just finished . [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon alone , of [all the party]660-all the party , heard [her]90-marianne without being in raptures . [He]104-colonel brandon paid [her]90-marianne only the compliment of attention ; and [she]90-marianne felt a respect for [him]104-colonel brandon on the occasion , which [the others]539-the others had reasonably forfeited by [their]539-the others shameless want of taste . [His]104-colonel brandon pleasure in music , though it amounted not to that ecstatic delight which alone could sympathize with [her]90-marianne own , was estimable when contrasted against the horrible insensibility of [the others]539-the others ; and [she]90-marianne was reasonable enough to allow that [a man of five and thirty]663-a man of five and thirty might well have outlived all acuteness of feeling and every exquisite power of enjoyment . [She]90-marianne was perfectly disposed to make every allowance for [the colonel]664-the colonel ’s advanced state of life which humanity required . CHAPTER VIII . [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings was [a widow with an ample jointure]665-a widow with an ample jointure . [She]103-mrs. jennings had only [two daughters , both of whom [she]103-mrs. jennings had lived to see respectably married]666-two daughters , both of whom she had lived to see respectably married , and [she]103-mrs. jennings had now therefore nothing to do but to marry all [the rest of [the world]2778-the world]667-the rest of the world . In the promotion of this object [she]103-mrs. jennings was zealously active , as far as [her]103-mrs. jennings ability reached ; and missed no opportunity of projecting weddings among [all the young people of [her]103-mrs. jennings acquaintance]669-all the young people of her acquaintance . [She]103-mrs. jennings was remarkably quick in the discovery of attachments , and had enjoyed the advantage of raising the blushes and the vanity of many [a young lady]670-a young lady by insinuations of [her]103-mrs. jennings power over [such a young man]671-such a young man ; and this kind of discernment enabled [her]103-mrs. jennings soon after [her]103-mrs. jennings arrival at [Barton]8-barton decisively to pronounce that [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon was very much in love with [Marianne Dashwood]90-marianne . [She]103-mrs. jennings rather suspected it to be so , on the very first evening of [their]672-them being together , from [his]104-colonel brandon listening so attentively while [she]103-mrs. jennings sang to [them]672-them ; and when the visit was returned by [the Middletons]102-the middletons ’ dining at [the cottage]507-the cottage , the fact was ascertained by [his]104-colonel brandon listening to [her]103-mrs. jennings again . It must be so . [She]103-mrs. jennings was perfectly convinced of it . It would be an excellent match , for _ [he]104-colonel brandon _ was rich , and _ [she]103-mrs. jennings _ was handsome . [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings had been anxious to see [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon well married , ever since [her]103-mrs. jennings connection with [Sir John]99-sir john first brought [him]104-colonel brandon to [her]103-mrs. jennings knowledge ; and [she]103-mrs. jennings was always anxious to get [a good husband for [every pretty girl]675-every pretty girl]674-a good husband for every pretty girl . The immediate advantage to [herself]103-mrs. jennings was by no means inconsiderable , for it supplied [her]103-mrs. jennings with endless jokes against [them]672-them both . At [the park]566-the park [she]103-mrs. jennings laughed at [the colonel]664-the colonel , and in [the cottage]507-the cottage at [Marianne]90-marianne . To the former [her]103-mrs. jennings raillery was probably , as far as it regarded only [himself]104-colonel brandon , perfectly indifferent ; but to the latter it was at first incomprehensible ; and when its object was understood , [she]103-mrs. jennings hardly knew whether most to laugh at its absurdity , or censure [its]679-its impertinence , for [she]103-mrs. jennings considered it as an unfeeling reflection on [the colonel]664-the colonel ’s advanced years , and on [his]104-colonel brandon forlorn condition as [an old bachelor]681-an old bachelor . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , who could not think [a man five years younger than [herself]88-mrs. dashwood , so exceedingly ancient as [he]104-colonel brandon appeared to the youthful fancy of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughter]404-her daughter]682-a man five years younger than herself , so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of her daughter , ventured to clear [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings from the probability of wishing to throw ridicule on [his]104-colonel brandon age . “ But at least , [Mama]95-mama , [you]95-mama can not deny the absurdity of the accusation , though [you]95-mama may not think it intentionally ill - natured . [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon is certainly younger than [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings , but [he]104-colonel brandon is old enough to be _ [[my]103-mrs. jennings _ father]2868-my _ father ; and if [he]104-colonel brandon were ever animated enough to be in love , must have long outlived every sensation of the kind . It is too ridiculous ! When is [a man]499-a man to be safe from such wit , if age and infirmity will not protect [him]499-a man ? ”[103-mrs. jennings] “ Infirmity ! ”[89-elinor] said [Elinor]89-elinor , “ do [you]95-mama call [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon infirm ? [I]89-elinor can easily suppose that [his]104-colonel brandon age may appear much greater to [you]95-mama than to [[my]89-elinor mother]2771-my mother ; but [you]95-mama can hardly deceive [yourself]95-mama as to [his]104-colonel brandon having the use of [his]104-colonel brandon limbs ! ”[89-elinor] “ Did not [you]332-her mother hear [him]104-colonel brandon complain of the rheumatism ? and is not that the commonest infirmity of declining life ? ”[103-mrs. jennings] “ [[My]332-her mother dearest child]2871-my dearest child , ”[332-her mother] said [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother , laughing , “ at this rate [you]2871-my dearest child must be in continual terror of _ [my]332-her mother _ decay ; and it must seem to [you]2871-my dearest child a miracle that [my]332-her mother life has been extended to the advanced age of forty . ”[332-her mother] “ [Mama]95-mama , [you]95-mama are not doing [me]103-mrs. jennings justice . [I]103-mrs. jennings know very well that [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon is not old enough to make [[his]104-colonel brandon friends]2872-his friends yet apprehensive of losing [him]104-colonel brandon in the course of nature . [He]104-colonel brandon may live twenty years longer . But thirty - five has nothing to do with matrimony . ”[103-mrs. jennings] “ Perhaps , ”[89-elinor] said [Elinor]89-elinor , “ thirty - five and seventeen had better not have any thing to do with matrimony together . But if there should by any chance happen to be [a woman who is single at seven and twenty]2873-a woman who is single at seven and twenty , [I]89-elinor should not think [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ’s being thirty - five any objection to [his]104-colonel brandon marrying _ [her]2873-a woman who is single at seven and twenty _ . ”[89-elinor] “ [A woman of seven and twenty]2874-a woman of seven and twenty , ”[90-marianne] said [Marianne]90-marianne , after pausing a moment , “ can never hope to feel or inspire affection again , and if [her]2874-a woman of seven and twenty home be uncomfortable , or [her]2874-a woman of seven and twenty fortune small , [I]90-marianne can suppose that [she]2874-a woman of seven and twenty might bring [herself]2874-a woman of seven and twenty to submit to the offices of [a nurse]2875-a nurse , for the sake of the provision and security of [a wife]2876-a wife . In [his]104-colonel brandon marrying [such a woman]469-such a woman therefore there would be nothing unsuitable . It would be a compact of convenience , and [the world]2778-the world would be satisfied . In [my]90-marianne eyes it would be no marriage at all , but that would be nothing . To [me]90-marianne it would seem only a commercial exchange , in which each wished to be benefited at the expense of the other . ”[90-marianne] “ It would be impossible , [I]89-elinor know , ”[89-elinor] replied [Elinor]89-elinor , “ to convince [you]2879-you that [a woman of seven and twenty]2874-a woman of seven and twenty could feel for [a man of thirty - five anything near enough to love]2881-a man of thirty - five anything near enough to love , to make [him]104-colonel brandon [a desirable companion to [her]2874-a woman of seven and twenty]2882-a desirable companion to her . But [I]89-elinor must object to [your]2879-you dooming [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon and [[his]104-colonel brandon wife]280-his wife to the constant confinement of [a sick chamber]2884-a sick chamber , merely because [he]104-colonel brandon chanced to complain yesterday ( a very cold damp day ) of a slight rheumatic feel in one of [his]104-colonel brandon shoulders . ”[89-elinor] “ But [he]104-colonel brandon talked of flannel waistcoats , ”[90-marianne] said [Marianne]90-marianne ; “ and with [me]90-marianne a flannel waistcoat is invariably connected with aches , cramps , rheumatisms , and every species of ailment that can afflict [the old]2885-the old and the feeble . ”[90-marianne] “ Had [he]104-colonel brandon been only in a violent fever , [you]2879-you would not have despised [him]104-colonel brandon half so much . [Confess]106-confess , [Marianne]90-marianne , is not there something interesting to [you]2879-you in the flushed cheek , hollow eye , and quick pulse of a fever ? ”[89-elinor] Soon after this , upon [Elinor]89-elinor ’s leaving [the room]2842-the room , “ [Mama]95-mama , ”[90-marianne] said [Marianne]90-marianne , “ [I]90-marianne have an alarm on the subject of illness which [I]90-marianne can not conceal from [you]95-mama . [I]90-marianne am sure [Edward Ferrars]98-edward is not well . [We]2886-we have now been [here]2861-here almost a fortnight , and yet [he]104-colonel brandon does not come . Nothing but real indisposition could occasion this extraordinary delay . What else can detain [him]104-colonel brandon at [Norland]3-norland ? ”[90-marianne] “ Had [you]2879-you any idea of [his]104-colonel brandon coming so soon ? ”[88-mrs. dashwood] said [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood . “ _ [I]88-mrs. dashwood _ had none . On the contrary , if [I]88-mrs. dashwood have felt any anxiety at all on the subject , it has been in recollecting that [he]104-colonel brandon sometimes showed a want of pleasure and readiness in accepting [my]88-mrs. dashwood invitation , when [I]88-mrs. dashwood talked of [his]104-colonel brandon coming to [Barton]8-barton . Does [Elinor]89-elinor expect [him]104-colonel brandon already ? ”[88-mrs. dashwood] “ [I]90-marianne have never mentioned it to [her]89-elinor , but of course [she]89-elinor must . ”[90-marianne] “ [I]90-marianne rather think [you]2879-you are mistaken , for when [I]90-marianne was talking to [her]89-elinor yesterday of getting a new grate for the spare bedchamber , [she]89-elinor observed that there was no immediate hurry for it , as it was not likely that [the room]2842-the room would be wanted for some time . ”[90-marianne] “ How strange this is ! what can be the meaning of it ! But the whole of [their]2889-their behaviour to [each other]338-each other has been unaccountable ! How cold , how composed were [their]2889-their last adieus ! How languid [their]2889-their conversation the last evening of [their]2889-their being together ! In [Edward]98-edward ’s farewell there was no distinction between [Elinor]89-elinor and [me]88-mrs. dashwood : it was the good wishes of [an affectionate brother]2891-an affectionate brother to [both]2892-both . Twice did [I]88-mrs. dashwood leave [them]2889-their purposely together in the course of the last morning , and each time did [he]2891-an affectionate brother most unaccountably follow [me]88-mrs. dashwood out of [the room]2842-the room . And [Elinor]89-elinor , in quitting [Norland]3-norland and [Edward]98-edward , cried not as [I]88-mrs. dashwood did . Even now [her]89-elinor self - command is invariable . When is [she]89-elinor dejected or melancholy ? When does [she]89-elinor try to avoid society , or appear restless and dissatisfied in it ? ”[88-mrs. dashwood] CHAPTER IX . [The Dashwoods]92-the miss dashwoods were now settled at [Barton]8-barton with tolerable comfort to [themselves]92-the miss dashwoods . [The house]318-the house and [the garden]532-the garden , with all the objects surrounding [them]688-them , were now become familiar , and the ordinary pursuits which had given to [Norland]3-norland half [its]3-norland charms were engaged in again with far greater enjoyment than [Norland]3-norland had been able to afford , since the loss of [[their]688-them father]273-their father . [Sir John Middleton]99-sir john , who called on [them]688-them every day for the first fortnight , and who was not in the habit of seeing much occupation at [home]565-home , could not conceal [his]99-sir john amazement on finding [them]688-them always employed . [[Their]688-them visitors]691-their visitors , except [those from [Barton Park]6-barton park]692-those from barton park , were not many ; for , in spite of [Sir John]99-sir john ’s urgent entreaties that [they]688-them would mix more in [the neighbourhood]356-the neighbourhood , and repeated assurances of [[his]99-sir john carriage]694-his carriage being always at [their]688-them service , the independence of [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood ’s spirit overcame the wish of society for [[her]88-mrs. dashwood children]495-her children ; and [she]88-mrs. dashwood was resolute in declining to visit [any family beyond the distance of a walk]696-any family beyond the distance of a walk . There were but [few who could be so classed]697-few who could be so classed ; and it was not all of [them]697-few who could be so classed that were attainable . About a mile and a half from [the cottage]507-the cottage , along [the narrow winding valley of [Allenham]12-allenham , which issued from that of [Barton]8-barton]699-the narrow winding valley of allenham , which issued from that of barton , as formerly described , [the girls]2794-the girls had , in one of [their]2794-the girls earliest walks , discovered [an ancient respectable looking mansion]701-an ancient respectable looking mansion which , by reminding [them]2794-the girls a little of [Norland]3-norland , interested [their]2794-the girls imagination and made [them]2794-the girls wish to be better acquainted with it . But [they]2794-the girls learnt , on enquiry , that [its possessor]702-its possessor , [an elderly lady of very good character]703-an elderly lady of very good character , was unfortunately too infirm to mix with [the world]2778-the world , and never stirred from [home]565-home . [The whole country]706-the whole country about [them]2794-the girls abounded in [beautiful walks]707-beautiful walks . [The high downs]708-the high downs which invited [them]2794-the girls from almost every window of [the cottage]507-the cottage to seek the exquisite enjoyment of air on [their]2794-the girls summits , were a happy alternative when the dirt of [the valleys beneath]710-the valleys beneath shut up [their]2794-the girls superior beauties ; and towards [one of these hills]544-one of these hills did [Marianne]90-marianne and [Margaret]91-margaret one memorable morning direct [their]2794-the girls steps , attracted by the partial sunshine of a showery sky , and unable longer to bear the confinement which the settled rain of the two preceding days had occasioned . The weather was not tempting enough to draw [the two others]712-the two others from [their]2794-the girls pencil and [their]2794-the girls book , in spite of [Marianne]90-marianne ’s declaration that the day would be lastingly fair , and that every threatening cloud would be drawn off from [[their]2794-the girls hills]713-their hills ; and [the two girls]714-the two girls set off together . [They]2794-the girls gaily ascended [the downs]715-the downs , rejoicing in [their]2794-the girls own penetration at every glimpse of blue sky ; and when [they]2794-the girls caught in [their]2794-the girls faces the animating gales of a high south - westerly wind , [they]2794-the girls pitied the fears which had prevented [[their]2794-the girls mother]274-their mother and [Elinor]89-elinor from sharing such delightful sensations . “ Is there a felicity in [the world]2778-the world , ”[90-marianne] said [Marianne]90-marianne , “ superior to this?—Margaret , [we]2794-the girls will walk [here]2861-here at least two hours . ”[90-marianne] [Margaret]91-margaret agreed , and [they]2794-the girls pursued [their]2794-the girls way against the wind , resisting it with laughing delight for about twenty minutes longer , when suddenly the clouds united over [their]2794-the girls heads , and a driving rain set full in [their]2794-the girls face . Chagrined and surprised , [they]2794-the girls were obliged , though unwillingly , to turn back , for no shelter was nearer than [[their]2794-the girls own house]525-their own house . One consolation however remained for [them]2794-the girls , to which the exigence of the moment gave more than usual propriety,—it was that of running with all possible speed down the steep side of [the hill]718-the hill which led immediately to [[their]2794-the girls garden gate]719-their garden gate . [They]2794-the girls set off . [Marianne]90-marianne had at first the advantage , but a false step brought [her]90-marianne suddenly to the ground ; and [Margaret]91-margaret , unable to stop [herself]91-margaret to assist [her]90-marianne , was involuntarily hurried along , and reached the bottom in safety . [A gentleman carrying a gun]720-a gentleman carrying a gun , with two pointers playing round [him]720-a gentleman carrying a gun , was passing up [the hill]718-the hill and within a few yards of [Marianne]90-marianne , when [her]90-marianne accident happened . [He]720-a gentleman carrying a gun put down [his]720-a gentleman carrying a gun gun and ran to [her]90-marianne assistance . [She]90-marianne had raised [herself]90-marianne from the ground , but [her]90-marianne foot had been twisted in [her]90-marianne fall , and [she]90-marianne was scarcely able to stand . [The gentleman]722-the gentleman offered [his]722-the gentleman services ; and perceiving that [her]90-marianne modesty declined what [her]90-marianne situation rendered necessary , took [her]90-marianne up in [his]722-the gentleman arms without farther delay , and carried [her]90-marianne down [the hill]718-the hill . Then passing through [the garden]532-the garden , the gate of which had been left open by [Margaret]91-margaret , [he]722-the gentleman bore [her]90-marianne directly into [the house]318-the house , whither [Margaret]91-margaret was just arrived , and quitted not [his]722-the gentleman hold till [he]722-the gentleman had seated [her]90-marianne in a chair in [the parlour]726-the parlour . [Elinor]89-elinor and [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother rose up in amazement at [their]728-their entrance , and while the eyes of [both]2892-both were fixed on [him]722-the gentleman with an evident wonder and a secret admiration which equally sprung from [his]722-the gentleman appearance , [he]722-the gentleman apologized for [his]722-the gentleman intrusion by relating its cause , in a manner so frank and so graceful that [[his]722-the gentleman person]730-his person , which was uncommonly handsome , received additional charms from [his]722-the gentleman voice and expression . Had [he]722-the gentleman been even old , ugly , and vulgar , the gratitude and kindness of [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood would have been secured by any act of attention to [[her]88-mrs. dashwood child]277-her child ; but the influence of youth , beauty , and elegance , gave an interest to the action which came home to [her]88-mrs. dashwood feelings . [She]88-mrs. dashwood thanked [him]722-the gentleman again and again ; and , with a sweetness of address which always attended [her]88-mrs. dashwood , invited [him]722-the gentleman to be seated . But this [he]722-the gentleman declined , as [he]722-the gentleman was dirty and wet . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood then begged to know to whom [she]88-mrs. dashwood was obliged . [His]722-the gentleman name , [he]722-the gentleman replied , was [Willoughby]107-willoughby , and [[his]722-the gentleman present home]732-his present home was at [Allenham]12-allenham , from whence [he]722-the gentleman hoped [she]88-mrs. dashwood would allow [him]722-the gentleman the honour of calling tomorrow to enquire after [Miss Dashwood]84-miss dashwood . The honour was readily granted , and [he]722-the gentleman then departed , to make [himself]722-the gentleman still more interesting , in the midst of a heavy rain . [His]722-the gentleman manly beauty and more than common gracefulness were instantly the theme of general admiration , and the laugh which [his]722-the gentleman gallantry raised against [Marianne]90-marianne received particular spirit from [his]722-the gentleman exterior attractions . [Marianne]90-marianne [herself]90-marianne had seen less of [his]722-the gentleman person than the rest , for the confusion which crimsoned over [her]90-marianne face , on [his]722-the gentleman lifting [her]90-marianne up , had robbed [her]90-marianne of the power of regarding [him]722-the gentleman after [their]733-their entering [the house]318-the house . But [she]90-marianne had seen enough of [him]722-the gentleman to join in all the admiration of [the others]539-the others , and with an energy which always adorned [her]90-marianne praise . [His]722-the gentleman person and air were equal to what [her]90-marianne fancy had ever drawn for [the hero of a favourite story]736-the hero of a favourite story ; and in [his]722-the gentleman carrying [her]90-marianne into [the house]318-the house with so little previous formality , there was a rapidity of thought which particularly recommended the action to [her]90-marianne . Every circumstance belonging to [him]722-the gentleman was interesting . [His]722-the gentleman name was good , [[his]722-the gentleman residence]738-his residence was in [[their]733-their favourite village]739-their favourite village , and [she]90-marianne soon found out that of all manly dresses a shooting - jacket was the most becoming . [Her]90-marianne imagination was busy , [her]90-marianne reflections were pleasant , and the pain of a sprained ankle was disregarded . [Sir John]99-sir john called on [them]733-their as soon as the next interval of fair weather that morning allowed [him]99-sir john to get out of [doors]740-doors ; and [Marianne]90-marianne ’s accident being related to [him]99-sir john , [he]99-sir john was eagerly asked whether [he]99-sir john knew [any gentleman of the name of [Willoughby]107-willoughby at [Allenham]12-allenham]741-any gentleman of the name of willoughby at allenham . “ [Willoughby]107-willoughby ! ”[99-sir john] cried [Sir John]99-sir john ; “ what , is _ [he]107-willoughby _ in [the country]612-the country ? That is good news however ; [I]99-sir john will ride over tomorrow , and ask [him]107-willoughby to dinner on Thursday . ”[99-sir john] “ [You]99-sir john know [him]107-willoughby then , ”[88-mrs. dashwood] said [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood . “ Know [him]107-willoughby ! to be sure [I]88-mrs. dashwood do . Why , [he]107-willoughby is down here every year . ”[88-mrs. dashwood] “ And what sort of [a young man]421-a young man is [he]107-willoughby ? ”[99-sir john] “ [As good a kind of fellow as ever lived]2898-as good a kind of fellow as ever lived , [I]99-sir john assure [you]99-sir john . [A very decent shot]2899-a very decent shot , and there is [not a bolder rider]2900-not a bolder rider in [England]14-england . ”[99-sir john] “ And is _ that _ all [you]99-sir john can say for [him]107-willoughby ? ”[90-marianne] cried [Marianne]90-marianne , indignantly . “ But what are [his]107-willoughby manners on more intimate acquaintance ? What [his]107-willoughby pursuits , [his]107-willoughby talents , and genius ? ”[90-marianne] [Sir John]99-sir john was rather puzzled . “ Upon [my]99-sir john soul , ”[99-sir john] said [he]99-sir john , “ [I]99-sir john do not know much about [him]107-willoughby as to all _ that _ . But [he]107-willoughby is [a pleasant , good humoured fellow]2901-a pleasant , good humoured fellow , and has got [the nicest little black bitch of a pointer [I]99-sir john ever saw]2902-the nicest little black bitch of a pointer i ever saw . Was [she]2902-the nicest little black bitch of a pointer i ever saw out with [him]107-willoughby today ? ”[99-sir john] But [Marianne]90-marianne could no more satisfy [him]99-sir john as to the colour of [Mr. Willoughby]107-willoughby ’s pointer , than [he]99-sir john could describe to [her]90-marianne the shades of [his]99-sir john mind . “ But who is [he]107-willoughby ? ”[89-elinor] said [Elinor]89-elinor . “ Where does [he]107-willoughby come from ? Has [he]107-willoughby [a house at [Allenham]12-allenham]2903-a house at allenham ? ”[89-elinor] On this point [Sir John]99-sir john could give more certain intelligence ; and [he]99-sir john told [them]742-you that [Mr. Willoughby]107-willoughby had no property of [[his]107-willoughby own]743-his own in [the country]612-the country ; that [he]107-willoughby resided [there]354-there only while [he]107-willoughby was visiting [the old lady at [Allenham Court]15-allenham court , to whom [he]107-willoughby was related , and whose possessions [he]107-willoughby was to inherit]746-the old lady at allenham court , to whom he was related , and whose possessions he was to inherit ; adding , “ Yes , yes , [he]107-willoughby is very well worth catching [I]99-sir john can tell [you]742-you , [Miss Dashwood]84-miss dashwood ; [he]107-willoughby has [a pretty little estate of [his]107-willoughby own]2904-a pretty little estate of his own in [Somersetshire]16-somersetshire besides ; and if [I]99-sir john were [you]742-you , [I]99-sir john would not give [him]107-willoughby up to [[my]99-sir john younger sister]2905-my younger sister , in spite of all this tumbling down [hills]2906-hills . [Miss Marianne]90-marianne must not expect to have [all the men]2907-all the men to [herself]90-marianne . [Brandon]104-colonel brandon will be jealous , if [she]90-marianne does not take care . ”[99-sir john] “ [I]88-mrs. dashwood do not believe , ”[88-mrs. dashwood] said [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , with a good humoured smile , “ that [Mr. Willoughby]107-willoughby will be incommoded by the attempts of [either of [_ [my]88-mrs. dashwood _ daughters]2909-_ my _ daughters]2908-either of _ my _ daughters towards what [you]742-you call _ catching [him]107-willoughby _ . It is not an employment to which [they]2909-_ my _ daughters have been brought up . [Men]2910-men are very safe with [us]2911-us , let [them]2910-men be ever so rich . [I]88-mrs. dashwood am glad to find , however , from what [you]742-you say , that [he]107-willoughby is [a respectable young man]2912-a respectable young man , and [one whose acquaintance will not be ineligible]2913-one whose acquaintance will not be ineligible . ”[88-mrs. dashwood] “ [He]107-willoughby is as good [a sort of fellow]2914-a sort of fellow , [I]99-sir john believe , as ever lived , ”[99-sir john] repeated [Sir John]99-sir john . “ [I]99-sir john remember last Christmas at a little hop at [the park]566-the park , [he]107-willoughby danced from eight o’clock till four , without once sitting down . ”[99-sir john] “ Did [he]107-willoughby indeed ? ”[90-marianne] cried [Marianne]90-marianne with sparkling eyes , “ and with elegance , with spirit ? ”[90-marianne] “ Yes ; and [he]107-willoughby was up again at eight to ride to covert . ”[99-sir john] “ That is what [I]90-marianne like ; that is what [a young man]421-a young man ought to be . Whatever be [his]421-a young man pursuits , [his]421-a young man eagerness in them should know no moderation , and leave [him]421-a young man no sense of fatigue . ”[90-marianne] “ Aye , aye , [I]99-sir john see how it will be , ”[99-sir john] said [Sir John]99-sir john , “ [I]99-sir john see how it will be . [You]99-sir john will be setting [your]99-sir john cap at [him]107-willoughby now , and never think of [poor Brandon]104-colonel brandon . ”[99-sir john] “ That is an expression , [Sir John]99-sir john , ”[90-marianne] said [Marianne]90-marianne , warmly , “ which [I]90-marianne particularly dislike . [I]90-marianne abhor every common - place phrase by which wit is intended ; and ‘ setting one ’s cap at [a man]499-a man , ’ or ‘ making a conquest , ’ are the most odious of all . [Their]2918-their tendency is gross and illiberal ; and if [their]2918-their construction could ever be deemed clever , time has long ago destroyed all its ingenuity . ”[90-marianne] [Sir John]99-sir john did not much understand this reproof ; but [he]99-sir john laughed as heartily as if [he]99-sir john did , and then replied , “ Ay , [you]99-sir john will make conquests enough , [I]99-sir john dare say , one way or other . [Poor Brandon]108-poor brandon ! [he]108-poor brandon is quite smitten already , and [he]108-poor brandon is very well worth setting [your]99-sir john cap at , [I]99-sir john can tell [you]99-sir john , in spite of all this tumbling about and spraining of ankles . ”[99-sir john] CHAPTER X. [[Marianne]90-marianne ’s preserver]747-marianne ’s preserver , as [Margaret]91-margaret , with more elegance than precision , styled [Willoughby]107-willoughby , called at [the cottage]507-the cottage early the next morning to make [his]107-willoughby personal enquiries . [He]107-willoughby was received by [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood with more than politeness ; with a kindness which [Sir John]99-sir john ’s account of [him]107-willoughby and [her]88-mrs. dashwood own gratitude prompted ; and every thing that passed during the visit tended to assure [him]107-willoughby of the sense , elegance , mutual affection , and domestic comfort of [the family to whom accident had now introduced [him]107-willoughby]749-the family to whom accident had now introduced him . Of [their]750-their personal charms [he]107-willoughby had not required a second interview to be convinced . [Miss Dashwood]84-miss dashwood had a delicate complexion , regular features , and a remarkably pretty figure . [Marianne]90-marianne was still handsomer . [Her]90-marianne form , though not so correct as [[her]90-marianne sister]336-her sister ’s , in having the advantage of height , was more striking ; and [her]90-marianne face was so lovely , that when in the common ca nt of praise , [she]90-marianne was called [a beautiful girl]752-a beautiful girl , truth was less violently outraged than usually happens . [Her]90-marianne skin was very brown , but , from its transparency , [her]90-marianne complexion was uncommonly brilliant ; [her]90-marianne features were all good ; [her]90-marianne smile was sweet and attractive ; and in [her]90-marianne eyes , which were very dark , there was a life , a spirit , an eagerness , which could hardly be seen without delight . From [Willoughby]107-willoughby [their]750-their expression was at first held back , by the embarrassment which the remembrance of [his]107-willoughby assistance created . But when this passed away , when [her]90-marianne spirits became collected , when [she]90-marianne saw that to the perfect good - breeding of [the gentleman]722-the gentleman , [he]722-the gentleman united frankness and vivacity , and above all , when [she]90-marianne heard [him]722-the gentleman declare , that of music and dancing [he]722-the gentleman was passionately fond , [she]90-marianne gave [him]722-the gentleman such a look of approbation as secured the largest share of [his]722-the gentleman discourse to [herself]90-marianne for the rest of [his]722-the gentleman stay . It was only necessary to mention any favourite amusement to engage [her]90-marianne to talk . [She]90-marianne could not be silent when such points were introduced , and [she]90-marianne had neither shyness nor reserve in [their]750-their discussion . [They]750-their speedily discovered that [their]750-their enjoyment of dancing and music was mutual , and that it arose from a general conformity of judgment in all that related to either . Encouraged by this to a further examination of [his]722-the gentleman opinions , [she]90-marianne proceeded to question [him]722-the gentleman on the subject of books ; [[her]90-marianne favourite authors]754-her favourite authors were brought forward and dwelt upon with so rapturous a delight , that [any young man of five and twenty]755-any young man of five and twenty must have been insensible indeed , not to become [an immediate convert to the excellence of such works]756-an immediate convert to the excellence of such works , however disregarded before . [Their]750-their taste was strikingly alike . The same books , the same passages were idolized by each — or if any difference appeared , any objection arose , it lasted no longer than till the force of [her]90-marianne arguments and the brightness of [her]90-marianne eyes could be displayed . [He]722-the gentleman acquiesced in all [her]90-marianne decisions , caught all [her]90-marianne enthusiasm ; and long before [his]722-the gentleman visit concluded , [they]750-their conversed with the familiarity of [a long - established acquaintance]757-a long - established acquaintance . “ Well , [Marianne]90-marianne , ”[89-elinor] said [Elinor]89-elinor , as soon as [he]722-the gentleman had left [them]750-their , “ for _ one _ morning [I]89-elinor think [you]90-marianne have done pretty well . [You]90-marianne have already ascertained [Mr. Willoughby]107-willoughby ’s opinion in almost every matter of importance . [You]90-marianne know what [he]107-willoughby thinks of [Cowper]97-cowper and [Scott]109-scott ; [you]90-marianne are certain of [his]107-willoughby estimating [their]750-their beauties as [he]107-willoughby ought , and [you]90-marianne have received every assurance of [his]107-willoughby admiring Pope no more than is proper . But how is [your]90-marianne acquaintance to be long supported , under such extraordinary despatch of every subject for discourse ? [You]90-marianne will soon have exhausted each favourite topic . Another meeting will suffice to explain [his]107-willoughby sentiments on picturesque beauty , and second marriages , and then [you]90-marianne can have nothing farther to ask . ”[89-elinor] “ [Elinor]89-elinor , ”[90-marianne] cried [Marianne]90-marianne , “ is this fair ? is this just ? are [my]90-marianne ideas so scanty ? But [I]90-marianne see what [you]90-marianne mean . [I]90-marianne have been too much at [my]90-marianne ease , too happy , too frank . [I]90-marianne have erred against every common - place notion of decorum ; [I]90-marianne have been open and sincere where [I]90-marianne ought to have been reserved , spiritless , dull , and deceitful — had [I]90-marianne talked only of the weather and [the roads]2919-the roads , and had [I]90-marianne spoken only once in ten minutes , this reproach would have been spared . ”[90-marianne] “ [My]332-her mother love , ”[332-her mother] said [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother , “ [you]90-marianne must not be offended with [Elinor]89-elinor — [she]89-elinor was only in jest . [I]332-her mother should scold [her]89-elinor [myself]332-her mother , if [she]89-elinor were capable of wishing to check the delight of [your]90-marianne conversation with [[our]759-they new friend]2920-our new friend . ”[332-her mother] [Marianne]90-marianne was softened in a moment . [Willoughby]107-willoughby , on [his]107-willoughby side , gave every proof of [his]107-willoughby pleasure in [their]759-they acquaintance , which an evident wish of improving it could offer . [He]107-willoughby came to [them]759-they every day . To enquire after [Marianne]90-marianne was at first [his]107-willoughby excuse ; but the encouragement of [his]107-willoughby reception , to which every day gave greater kindness , made such an excuse unnecessary before it had ceased to be possible , by [Marianne]90-marianne ’s perfect recovery . [She]90-marianne was confined for some days to [the house]318-the house ; but never had any confinement been less irksome . [Willoughby]107-willoughby was [a young man of good abilities , quick imagination , lively spirits , and open , affectionate manners]761-a young man of good abilities , quick imagination , lively spirits , and open , affectionate manners . [He]107-willoughby was exactly formed to engage [Marianne]90-marianne ’s heart , for with all this , [he]107-willoughby joined not only [a captivating person]762-a captivating person , but a natural ardour of mind which was now roused and increased by the example of [her]90-marianne own , and which recommended [him]107-willoughby to [her]90-marianne affection beyond every thing else . [His]107-willoughby society became gradually [her]90-marianne most exquisite enjoyment . [They]759-they read , [they]759-they talked , [they]759-they sang together ; [his]107-willoughby musical talents were considerable ; and [he]107-willoughby read with all the sensibility and spirit which [Edward]98-edward had unfortunately wanted . In [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood ’s estimation [he]107-willoughby was as faultless as in [Marianne]90-marianne ’s ; and [Elinor]89-elinor saw nothing to censure in [him]107-willoughby but a propensity , in which [he]107-willoughby strongly resembled and peculiarly delighted [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister , of saying too much what [he]107-willoughby thought on every occasion , without attention to [persons]764-persons or circumstances . In hastily forming and giving [his]107-willoughby opinion of [other people]2834-other people , in sacrificing general politeness to the enjoyment of undivided attention where [his]107-willoughby heart was engaged , and in slighting too easily the forms of worldly propriety , [he]107-willoughby displayed a want of caution which [Elinor]89-elinor could not approve , in spite of all that [he]107-willoughby and [Marianne]90-marianne could say in its support . [Marianne]90-marianne began now to perceive that the desperation which had seized [her]90-marianne at sixteen and a half , of ever seeing [a man who could satisfy [her]90-marianne ideas of perfection]766-a man who could satisfy her ideas of perfection , had been rash and unjustifiable . [Willoughby]107-willoughby was all that [her]90-marianne fancy had delineated in that unhappy hour and in every brighter period , as capable of attaching [her]90-marianne ; and [his]107-willoughby behaviour declared [his]107-willoughby wishes to be in that respect as earnest , as [his]107-willoughby abilities were strong . [[Her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother too , in whose mind not one speculative thought of [their]768-their marriage had been raised , by [his]107-willoughby prospect of riches , was led before the end of a week to hope and expect it ; and secretly to congratulate [herself]332-her mother on having gained [two such sons]769-two such sons - in - law as [Edward]98-edward and [Willoughby]107-willoughby . [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ’s partiality for [Marianne]90-marianne , which had so early been discovered by [[his]104-colonel brandon friends]2872-his friends , now first became perceptible to [Elinor]89-elinor , when it ceased to be noticed by [them]2872-his friends . [Their]2872-his friends attention and wit were drawn off to [[his]104-colonel brandon more fortunate rival]771-his more fortunate rival ; and the raillery which [the other]772-the other had incurred before any partiality arose , was removed when [his]104-colonel brandon feelings began really to call for the ridicule so justly annexed to sensibility . [Elinor]89-elinor was obliged , though unwillingly , to believe that the sentiments which [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings had assigned [him]107-willoughby for [her]103-mrs. jennings own satisfaction , were now actually excited by [[her]103-mrs. jennings sister]336-her sister ; and that however a general resemblance of disposition between [the parties]774-the parties might forward the affection of [Mr. Willoughby]107-willoughby , an equally striking opposition of character was no hindrance to the regard of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon . [She]89-elinor saw it with concern ; for what could [a silent man of five and thirty]775-a silent man of five and thirty hope , when opposed to [a very lively one of five and twenty]776-a very lively one of five and twenty ? and as [she]89-elinor could not even wish [him]107-willoughby successful , [she]89-elinor heartily wished [him]107-willoughby indifferent . [She]89-elinor liked [him]107-willoughby — in spite of [his]107-willoughby gravity and reserve , [she]89-elinor beheld in [him]107-willoughby an object of interest . [His]107-willoughby manners , though serious , were mild ; and [his]107-willoughby reserve appeared rather the result of some oppression of spirits than of any natural gloominess of temper . [Sir John]99-sir john had dropped hints of past injuries and disappointments , which justified [her]89-elinor belief of [his]107-willoughby being [an unfortunate man]777-an unfortunate man , and [she]89-elinor regarded [him]107-willoughby with respect and compassion . Perhaps [she]89-elinor pitied and esteemed [him]107-willoughby the more because [he]107-willoughby was slighted by [Willoughby]107-willoughby and [Marianne]90-marianne , who , prejudiced against [him]107-willoughby for being neither lively nor young , seemed resolved to undervalue [his]107-willoughby merits . “ [Brandon]104-colonel brandon is just [the kind of man]2921-the kind of man , ”[107-willoughby] said [Willoughby]107-willoughby one day , when [they]778-they were talking of [him]107-willoughby together , “ whom every body speaks well of , and [nobody]2922-nobody cares about ; whom [all are]2923-all are delighted to see , and [nobody remembers to talk to]2924-nobody remembers to talk to . ”[107-willoughby] “ That is exactly what [I]90-marianne think of [him]107-willoughby , ”[90-marianne] cried [Marianne]90-marianne . “ Do not boast of it , however , ”[89-elinor] said [Elinor]89-elinor , “ for it is injustice in both of [you]778-they . [He]107-willoughby is highly esteemed by [all [the family]303-the family at [the park]566-the park]2925-all the family at the park , and [I]89-elinor never see [him]107-willoughby [myself]89-elinor without taking pains to converse with [him]107-willoughby . ”[89-elinor] “ That [he]107-willoughby is patronised by _ [you]90-marianne _ , ”[107-willoughby] replied [Willoughby]107-willoughby , “ is certainly in [his]107-willoughby favour ; but as for the esteem of [the others]539-the others , it is a reproach in itself . Who would submit to the indignity of being approved by [such a woman]469-such a woman as [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton and [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings , that could command the indifference of [any body else]2930-any body else ? ”[107-willoughby] “ But perhaps the abuse of [such people]2931-such people as [yourself]90-marianne and [Marianne]90-marianne will make amends for the regard of [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton and [[her]100-lady middleton mother]332-her mother . If [their]2931-such people praise is censure , [your]90-marianne censure may be praise , for [they]2931-such people are not more undiscerning , than [you]90-marianne are prejudiced and unjust . ”[107-willoughby] “ In defence of [your]90-marianne _ protégé _ [you]90-marianne can even be saucy . ”[107-willoughby] “ [My]107-willoughby _ protégé _ , as [you]90-marianne call [him]107-willoughby , is [a sensible man]2933-a sensible man ; and sense will always have attractions for [me]107-willoughby . Yes , [Marianne]90-marianne , even in [a man between thirty and forty]2934-a man between thirty and forty . [He]107-willoughby has seen a great deal of [the world]2778-the world ; has been abroad , has read , and has a thinking mind . [I]107-willoughby have found [him]107-willoughby capable of giving [me]107-willoughby much information on various subjects ; and [he]107-willoughby has always answered [my]107-willoughby inquiries with readiness of good - breeding and good nature . ”[107-willoughby] “ That is to say , ”[90-marianne] cried [Marianne]90-marianne contemptuously , “ [he]107-willoughby has told [you]90-marianne , that in [the East Indies]17-the east indies the climate is hot , and the mosquitoes are troublesome . ”[107-willoughby] “ [He]107-willoughby _ would _ have told [me]107-willoughby so , [I]107-willoughby doubt not , had [I]107-willoughby made any such inquiries , but they happened to be points on which [I]107-willoughby had been previously informed . ”[107-willoughby] “ Perhaps , ”[107-willoughby] said [Willoughby]107-willoughby , “ [his]107-willoughby observations may have extended to the existence of nabobs , gold mohrs , and palanquins . ”[107-willoughby] “ [I]107-willoughby may venture to say that _ [his]107-willoughby _ observations have stretched much further than _ [your]90-marianne _ candour . But why should [you]90-marianne dislike [him]107-willoughby ? ”[107-willoughby] “ [I]107-willoughby do not dislike [him]107-willoughby . [I]107-willoughby consider [him]107-willoughby , on the contrary , as [a very respectable man]2936-a very respectable man , who has every body ’s good word , and [nobody]2922-nobody ’s notice ; who has more money than [he]107-willoughby can spend , more time than [he]107-willoughby knows how to employ , and two new coats every year . ”[107-willoughby] “ Add to which , ”[90-marianne] cried [Marianne]90-marianne , “ that [he]107-willoughby has neither genius , taste , nor spirit . That [his]107-willoughby understanding has no brilliancy , [his]107-willoughby feelings no ardour , and [his]107-willoughby voice no expression . ”[90-marianne] “ [You]90-marianne decide on [his]107-willoughby imperfections so much in the mass , ”[89-elinor] replied [Elinor]89-elinor , “ and so much on the strength of [your]90-marianne own imagination , that the commendation _ [I]89-elinor _ am able to give of [him]107-willoughby is comparatively cold and insipid . [I]89-elinor can only pronounce [him]107-willoughby to be [a sensible man , well - bred , well - informed , of gentle address]2938-a sensible man , well - bred , well - informed , of gentle address , and , [I]89-elinor believe , possessing an amiable heart . ”[89-elinor] “ [Miss Dashwood]84-miss dashwood , ”[107-willoughby] cried [Willoughby]107-willoughby , “ [you]84-miss dashwood are now using [me]107-willoughby unkindly . [You]84-miss dashwood are endeavouring to disarm [me]107-willoughby by reason , and to convince [me]107-willoughby against [my]107-willoughby will . But it will not do . [You]84-miss dashwood shall find [me]107-willoughby as stubborn as [you]84-miss dashwood can be artful . [I]107-willoughby have three unanswerable reasons for disliking [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ; [he]107-willoughby threatened [me]107-willoughby with rain when [I]107-willoughby wanted it to be fine ; [he]107-willoughby has found fault with the hanging of [my]107-willoughby curricle , and [I]107-willoughby can not persuade [him]107-willoughby to buy [my]107-willoughby brown mare . If it will be any satisfaction to [you]84-miss dashwood , however , to be told , that [I]107-willoughby believe [his]107-willoughby character to be in other respects irreproachable , [I]107-willoughby am ready to confess it . And in return for an acknowledgment , which must give [me]107-willoughby some pain , [you]84-miss dashwood can not deny [me]107-willoughby the privilege of disliking [him]107-willoughby as much as ever . ”[107-willoughby] CHAPTER XI . [Little]110-little had [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood or [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughters]294-her daughters imagined when [they]780-they first came into [Devonshire]5-devonshire , that so many engagements would arise to occupy [their]780-they time as shortly presented [themselves]780-they , or that [they]780-they should have such frequent invitations and such constant visitors as to leave [them]780-they little leisure for serious employment . Yet such was the case . When [Marianne]90-marianne was recovered , the schemes of amusement at [home]565-home and abroad , which [Sir John]99-sir john had been previously forming , were put into execution . The private balls at [the park]566-the park then began ; and parties on [the water]783-the water were made and accomplished as often as a showery October would allow . In every meeting of the kind [Willoughby]107-willoughby was included ; and the ease and familiarity which naturally attended these parties were exactly calculated to give increasing intimacy to [his]107-willoughby acquaintance with [the Dashwoods]92-the miss dashwoods , to afford [him]107-willoughby opportunity of witnessing the excellencies of [Marianne]90-marianne , of marking [his]107-willoughby animated admiration of [her]90-marianne , and of receiving , in [her]90-marianne behaviour to [himself]107-willoughby , the most pointed assurance of [her]90-marianne affection . [Elinor]89-elinor could not be surprised at [their]784-their attachment . [She]89-elinor only wished that it were less openly shown ; and once or twice did venture to suggest the propriety of some self - command to [Marianne]90-marianne . But [Marianne]90-marianne abhorred all concealment where no real disgrace could attend unreserve ; and to aim at the restraint of sentiments which were not in themselves illaudable , appeared to [her]89-elinor not merely an unnecessary effort , but a disgraceful subjection of reason to common - place and mistaken notions . [Willoughby]107-willoughby thought the same ; and [their]784-their behaviour at all times , was an illustration of [their]784-their opinions . When [he]107-willoughby was present [she]89-elinor had no eyes for [any one else]785-any one else . Every thing [he]107-willoughby did , was right . Every thing [he]107-willoughby said , was clever . If [their]784-their evenings at [the park]566-the park were concluded with cards , [he]107-willoughby cheated [himself]107-willoughby and all the rest of [the party]577-the party to get [her]89-elinor a good hand . If dancing formed the amusement of the night , [they]784-their were [partners]788-partners for half the time ; and when obliged to separate for a couple of dances , were careful to stand together and scarcely spoke a word to [any body else]2930-any body else . Such conduct made [them]784-their of course most exceedingly laughed at ; but ridicule could not shame , and seemed hardly to provoke [them]784-their . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood entered into all [their]784-their feelings with a warmth which left [her]88-mrs. dashwood no inclination for checking this excessive display of them . To [her]88-mrs. dashwood it was but the natural consequence of a strong affection in [a young and ardent mind]790-a young and ardent mind . This was the season of happiness to [Marianne]90-marianne . [Her]88-mrs. dashwood heart was devoted to [Willoughby]107-willoughby , and the fond attachment to [Norland]3-norland , which [she]88-mrs. dashwood brought with [her]88-mrs. dashwood from [Sussex]1-sussex , was more likely to be softened than [she]88-mrs. dashwood had thought it possible before , by the charms which [his]107-willoughby society bestowed on [[her]88-mrs. dashwood present home]791-her present home . [Elinor]89-elinor ’s happiness was not so great . [Her]89-elinor heart was not so much at ease , nor [her]89-elinor satisfaction in [their]784-their amusements so pure . [They]784-their afforded [her]89-elinor [no companion that could make amends for what [she]89-elinor had left behind]792-no companion that could make amends for what she had left behind , nor that could teach [her]89-elinor to think of [Norland]3-norland with less regret than ever . [Neither Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton nor [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings could supply to [her]89-elinor the conversation [she]89-elinor missed ; although [the latter]325-the latter was [an everlasting talker]794-an everlasting talker , and from the first had regarded [her]89-elinor with a kindness which ensured [her]89-elinor a large share of [her]89-elinor discourse . [She]89-elinor had already repeated [her]89-elinor own history to [Elinor]89-elinor three or four times ; and had [Elinor]89-elinor ’s memory been equal to [her]89-elinor means of improvement , [she]89-elinor might have known very early in [their]795-them acquaintance all the particulars of [Mr. Jennings]111-mr. jennings ’s last illness , and what [he]111-mr. jennings said to [[his]111-mr. jennings wife]280-his wife a few minutes before [he]111-mr. jennings died . [Lady Middleton]100-lady middleton was more agreeable than [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother only in being more silent . [Elinor]89-elinor needed little observation to perceive that [her]89-elinor reserve was a mere calmness of manner with which sense had nothing to do . Towards [[her]89-elinor husband]319-her husband and [mother]2803-mother [she]89-elinor was the same as to [them]795-them ; and intimacy was therefore neither to be looked for nor desired . [She]89-elinor had nothing to say one day that [she]89-elinor had not said the day before . [Her]89-elinor insipidity was invariable , for even [her]89-elinor spirits were always the same ; and though [she]89-elinor did not oppose the parties arranged by [[her]89-elinor husband]319-her husband , provided every thing were conducted in style and [[her]89-elinor two eldest children]801-her two eldest children attended [her]89-elinor , [she]89-elinor never appeared to receive more enjoyment from [them]795-them than [she]89-elinor might have experienced in sitting at home;—and so little did [her]89-elinor presence add to the pleasure of [the others]539-the others , by any share in [their]539-the others conversation , that [they]539-the others were sometimes only reminded of [her]89-elinor being amongst [them]539-the others by [her]89-elinor solicitude about [[her]89-elinor troublesome boys]803-her troublesome boys . In [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon alone , of all [her]89-elinor new acquaintance , did [Elinor]89-elinor find [a person who could in any degree claim the respect of abilities , excite the interest of friendship]804-a person who could in any degree claim the respect of abilities , excite the interest of friendship , or give pleasure as [a companion]805-a companion . [Willoughby]107-willoughby was out of the question . [Her]89-elinor admiration and regard , even [her]89-elinor sisterly regard , was all [his]104-colonel brandon own ; but [he]104-colonel brandon was [a lover]2821-a lover ; [his]104-colonel brandon attentions were wholly [Marianne]90-marianne ’s , and [a far less agreeable man]807-a far less agreeable man might have been more generally pleasing . [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon , unfortunately for [himself]104-colonel brandon , had no such encouragement to think only of [Marianne]90-marianne , and in conversing with [Elinor]89-elinor [he]104-colonel brandon found the greatest consolation for the indifference of [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister . [Elinor]89-elinor ’s compassion for [him]104-colonel brandon increased , as [she]89-elinor had reason to suspect that the misery of disappointed love had already been known to [him]104-colonel brandon . This suspicion was given by some words which accidentally dropped from [him]104-colonel brandon one evening at [the park]566-the park , when [they]810-they were sitting down together by mutual consent , while [the others]539-the others were dancing . [His]104-colonel brandon eyes were fixed on [Marianne]90-marianne , and , after a silence of some minutes , [he]104-colonel brandon said , with a faint smile , “ [[Your]89-elinor sister]2815-your sister , [I]104-colonel brandon understand , does not approve of second attachments . ”[104-colonel brandon] “ No , ”[89-elinor] replied [Elinor]89-elinor , “ [her]2815-your sister opinions are all romantic . ”[104-colonel brandon] “ Or rather , as [I]104-colonel brandon believe , [she]2815-your sister considers them impossible to exist . ”[104-colonel brandon] “ [I]104-colonel brandon believe [she]2815-your sister does . But how [she]2815-your sister contrives it without reflecting on the character of [[her]2815-your sister own father]2940-her own father , who had [[himself]2940-her own father two wives]2941-himself two wives , [I]104-colonel brandon know not . A few years however will settle [her]2815-your sister opinions on the reasonable basis of common sense and observation ; and then they may be more easy to define and to justify than they now are , by any body but [herself]2815-your sister . ”[104-colonel brandon] “ This will probably be the case , ”[104-colonel brandon] [he]104-colonel brandon replied ; “ and yet there is something so amiable in the prejudices of [a young mind]2942-a young mind , that [one]2761-one is sorry to see [them]2942-a young mind give way to the reception of more general opinions . ”[104-colonel brandon] “ [I]89-elinor can not agree with [you]104-colonel brandon there , ”[89-elinor] said [Elinor]89-elinor . “ There are inconveniences attending such feelings as [Marianne]90-marianne ’s , which all the charms of enthusiasm and ignorance of [the world]2778-the world can not atone for . [Her]2815-your sister systems have all the unfortunate tendency of setting propriety at nought ; and a better acquaintance with [the world]2778-the world is what [I]104-colonel brandon look forward to as [her]2815-your sister greatest possible advantage . ”[104-colonel brandon] After a short pause [he]104-colonel brandon resumed the conversation by saying , — “ Does [[your]104-colonel brandon sister]2815-your sister make no distinction in [her]2815-your sister objections against a second attachment ? or is it equally criminal in every body ? Are those who have been disappointed in [their]2947-their first choice , whether from the inconstancy of its object , or the perverseness of circumstances , to be equally indifferent during the rest of [their]2947-their lives ? ”[104-colonel brandon] “ Upon [my]104-colonel brandon word , [I]104-colonel brandon am not acquainted with the minutiae of [her]2815-your sister principles . [I]104-colonel brandon only know that [I]104-colonel brandon never yet heard [her]2815-your sister admit any instance of a second attachment ’s being pardonable . ”[104-colonel brandon] “ This , ”[104-colonel brandon] said [he]104-colonel brandon , “ can not hold ; but a change , a total change of sentiments — No , no , do not desire it ; for when the romantic refinements of a young mind are obliged to give way , how frequently are [they]2948-they succeeded by such opinions as are but too common , and too dangerous ! [I]104-colonel brandon speak from experience . [I]104-colonel brandon once knew [a lady who in temper and mind]2949-a lady who in temper and mind greatly resembled [[your]104-colonel brandon sister]2815-your sister , who thought and judged like [her]370-the lady , but [who from an enforced change — from a series of unfortunate circumstances]2951-who from an enforced change — from a series of unfortunate circumstances — ”[104-colonel brandon] Here [he]104-colonel brandon stopt suddenly ; appeared to think that [he]104-colonel brandon had said too much , and by [his]104-colonel brandon countenance gave rise to conjectures , which might not otherwise have entered [Elinor]89-elinor ’s head . [The lady]370-the lady would probably have passed without suspicion , had [he]104-colonel brandon not convinced [Miss Dashwood]84-miss dashwood that what concerned [her]370-the lady ought not to escape [his]104-colonel brandon lips . As it was , it required but a slight effort of fancy to connect [his]104-colonel brandon emotion with the tender recollection of past regard . [Elinor]89-elinor attempted no more . But [Marianne]90-marianne , in [her]90-marianne place , would not have done so little . The whole story would have been speedily formed under [her]89-elinor active imagination ; and every thing established in the most melancholy order of disastrous love . CHAPTER XII . As [Elinor]89-elinor and [Marianne]90-marianne were walking together the next morning [the latter]325-the latter communicated a piece of news to [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister , which in spite of all that [she]89-elinor knew before of [Marianne]90-marianne ’s imprudence and want of thought , surprised [her]89-elinor by its extravagant testimony of both . [Marianne]90-marianne told [her]89-elinor , with the greatest delight , that [Willoughby]107-willoughby had given [her]89-elinor a horse , one that [he]107-willoughby had bred [himself]107-willoughby on [[his]107-willoughby estate in [Somersetshire]16-somersetshire]815-his estate in somersetshire , and which was exactly calculated to carry [a woman]816-a woman . Without considering that it was not in [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother ’s plan to keep any horse , that if [she]89-elinor were to alter [her]89-elinor resolution in favour of this gift , [she]89-elinor must buy another for [the servant]818-the servant , and keep [a servant to ride it]819-a servant to ride it , and after all , build [a stable to receive]820-a stable to receive [them]821-them , [she]89-elinor had accepted the present without hesitation , and told [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister of it in raptures . “ [He]107-willoughby intends to send [[his]107-willoughby groom]2952-his groom into [Somersetshire]16-somersetshire immediately for it , ”[89-elinor] [she]89-elinor added , “ and when it arrives [we]2953-we will ride every day . [You]89-elinor shall share its use with [me]89-elinor . Imagine to [yourself]89-elinor , [[my]89-elinor dear]2750-my dear [Elinor]89-elinor , the delight of a gallop on some of [these downs]2955-these downs . ”[89-elinor] Most unwilling was [she]89-elinor to awaken from such a dream of felicity to comprehend all the unhappy truths which attended the affair ; and for some time [she]89-elinor refused to submit to them . As to [an additional servant]823-an additional servant , the expense would be a trifle ; [Mama]95-mama [she]95-mama was sure would never object to it ; and any horse would do for _ [him]824-him ; _ [he]824-him might always get one at [the park]566-the park ; as to [a stable]826-a stable , the merest shed would be sufficient . [Elinor]89-elinor then ventured to doubt the propriety of [her]89-elinor receiving such a present from [a man so little]827-a man so little , or at least so lately known to [her]89-elinor . This was too much . “ [You]89-elinor are mistaken , [Elinor]89-elinor , ”[89-elinor] said [she]89-elinor warmly , “ in supposing [I]89-elinor know very little of [Willoughby]107-willoughby . [I]89-elinor have not known [him]107-willoughby long indeed , but [I]89-elinor am much better acquainted with [him]107-willoughby , than [I]89-elinor am with [any other creature in [the world]2778-the world]2956-any other creature in the world , except [yourself]89-elinor and [mama]2826-mama . It is not time or opportunity that is to determine intimacy;—it is disposition alone . Seven years would be insufficient to make [some people]2959-some people acquainted with [each other]338-each other , and seven days are more than enough for [others]2961-others . [I]89-elinor should hold [myself]89-elinor guilty of greater impropriety in accepting a horse from [[my]89-elinor brother]2962-my brother , than from [Willoughby]107-willoughby . Of [John]88-mrs. dashwood [I]89-elinor know very little , though [we]2963-we have lived together for years ; but of [Willoughby]107-willoughby [my]89-elinor judgment has long been formed . ”[89-elinor] [Elinor]89-elinor thought it wisest to touch that point no more .
