Not aware of [their]2436-their being in [town]2984-town , however , [I]0-i blundered on [Sir John]99-sir john , [I]0-i believe , the first day of [his]99-sir john coming , and the day after [I]0-i had called at [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings ’s . [He]99-sir john asked [me]0-i to a party , a dance at [[his]99-sir john house]515-his house in the evening . Had [he]99-sir john _ not _ told [me]0-i as an inducement that [you]2427-you and [[your]2427-you sister]2815-your sister were to be [there]354-there , [I]0-i should have felt it too certain a thing , to trust [myself]0-i near [him]99-sir john . The next morning brought another short note from [Marianne]90-marianne — still affectionate , open , artless , confiding — everything that could make _ [my]0-i _ conduct most hateful . [I]0-i could not answer it . [I]0-i tried — but could not frame a sentence . But [I]0-i thought of [her]90-marianne , [I]0-i believe , every moment of the day . If [you]2427-you _ can _ pity [me]0-i , [Miss Dashwood]84-miss dashwood , pity [my]0-i situation as it was _ then _ . With [my]0-i head and heart full of [[your]2427-you sister]2815-your sister , [I]0-i was forced to play [the happy lover]2442-the happy lover to [another woman]2443-another woman ! Those three or four weeks were worse than all . Well , at last , as [I]0-i need not tell [you]2427-you , [you]2427-you were forced on [me]0-i ; and what a sweet figure [I]0-i cut ! what an evening of agony it was ! [Marianne]90-marianne , beautiful as [an angel]2065-an angel on one side , calling [me]0-i [Willoughby]107-willoughby in such a tone ! Oh , [God]154-god ! holding out [her]90-marianne hand to [me]0-i , asking [me]0-i for an explanation , with those bewitching eyes fixed in such speaking solicitude on [my]0-i face ! and [Sophia]228-sophia , jealous as [the devil on the other hand , looking all that was — Well]2445-the devil on the other hand , looking all that was — well , it does not signify ; it is over now . Such an evening ! [I]0-i ran away from [you]2427-you all as soon as [I]0-i could ; but not before [I]0-i had seen [Marianne]90-marianne ’s sweet face as white as death . _ That _ was the last , last look [I]0-i ever had of [her]90-marianne ; the last manner in which [she]90-marianne appeared to [me]0-i . It was a horrid sight ! yet when [I]0-i thought of [her]90-marianne to - day as really dying , it was a kind of comfort to [me]0-i to imagine that [I]0-i knew exactly how [she]90-marianne would appear to those , who saw [her]90-marianne last in [this world]2446-this world . [She]90-marianne was before [me]0-i , constantly before [me]0-i , as [I]0-i travelled , in the same look and hue . ” A short pause of mutual thoughtfulness succeeded . [Willoughby]107-willoughby first rousing [himself]107-willoughby , broke it thus : “[90-marianne] Well , let [me]0-i make haste and be gone . [[Your]0-i sister]2815-your sister is certainly better , certainly out of danger ? ” “[2448-we] [We]2448-we are assured of it . ” “[2449-your poor mother] [[Your]0-i poor mother]2449-your poor mother , too!—doting on [Marianne]90-marianne . ” “[2449-your poor mother] But the letter , [Mr. Willoughby]107-willoughby , [your]107-willoughby own letter ; have [you]107-willoughby any thing to say about that ? ” “[107-willoughby] Yes , yes , _ that _ in particular . [[Your]0-i sister]2815-your sister wrote to [me]0-i again , [you]0-i know , the very next morning . [You]0-i saw what [she]2815-your sister said . [I]0-i was breakfasting at [the Ellisons,—and]2451-the ellisons,—and [her]2815-your sister letter , with some others , was brought to [me]0-i [there]354-there from [[my]0-i lodgings]2453-my lodgings . It happened to catch [Sophia]228-sophia ’s eye before it caught [mine]0-i — and its size , the elegance of the paper , the hand - writing altogether , immediately gave [her]228-sophia a suspicion . Some vague report had reached [her]228-sophia before of [my]0-i attachment to [some young lady in [Devonshire]5-devonshire]2454-some young lady in devonshire , and what had passed within [her]228-sophia observation the preceding evening had marked who [the young lady]2455-the young lady was , and made [her]228-sophia more jealous than ever . Affecting that air of playfulness , therefore , which is delightful in [a woman one loves]2456-a woman one loves , [she]228-sophia opened the letter directly , and read its contents . [She]228-sophia was well paid for [her]228-sophia impudence . [She]228-sophia read what made [her]228-sophia wretched . [Her]228-sophia wretchedness [I]0-i could have borne , but [her]228-sophia passion — [her]228-sophia malice — At all events it must be appeased . And , in short — what do [you]0-i think of [[my]0-i wife]3334-my wife ’s style of letter - writing?—delicate — tender — truly feminine — was it not ? ” “[0-i] [Your]0-i wife!—The letter was in [your]0-i own hand - writing . ” “[0-i] Yes , but [I]0-i had only the credit of servilely copying such sentences as [I]0-i was ashamed to put [my]0-i name to . The original was all [her]228-sophia own — [her]228-sophia own happy thoughts and gentle diction . But what could [I]0-i do!—we were engaged , every thing in preparation , the day almost fixed — But [I]0-i am talking like [a fool]2373-a fool . Preparation ! Day ! In honest words , [her]228-sophia money was necessary to [me]0-i , and in a situation like [mine]0-i , any thing was to be done to prevent a rupture . And after all , what did it signify to [my]0-i character in the opinion of [Marianne]90-marianne and [[her]90-marianne friends]1633-her friends , in what language [my]0-i answer was couched ? It must have been only to one end . [My]0-i business was to declare [myself]0-i [a scoundrel]2460-a scoundrel , and whether [I]0-i did it with a bow or a bluster was of little importance . ‘ [I]0-i am ruined for ever in [their]2461-their opinion , ’ said [I]0-i to [myself]0-i : ‘ [I]0-i am shut out for ever from [[their]2461-their society]2462-their society , [they]2461-their already think [me]0-i [an unprincipled fellow]2463-an unprincipled fellow , this letter will only make [them]2461-their think [me]0-i [a blackguard one]2464-a blackguard one . ’ Such were [my]0-i reasonings , as , in a sort of desperate carelessness , [I]0-i copied [[my]0-i wife]3334-my wife ’s words , and parted with the last relics of [Marianne]90-marianne . [Her]90-marianne three notes,—unluckily they were all in [my]0-i pocketbook , or [I]0-i should have denied [their]2461-their existence , and hoarded [them]2461-their for ever,—I was forced to put them up , and could not even kiss [them]2461-their . And the lock of hair — that too [I]0-i had always carried about [me]0-i in the same pocket - book , which was now searched by [Madam]190-madam with the most ingratiating virulence,—the dear lock,—all , every memento was torn from [me]0-i . ” “[2466-you] [You]2466-you are very wrong , [Mr. Willoughby]107-willoughby , very blamable , ” said [Elinor]89-elinor , while [her]0-i voice , in spite of [herself]0-i , betrayed [her]0-i compassionate emotion ; “[107-willoughby] [you]2466-you ought not to speak in this way , either of [Mrs. Willoughby]173-mrs. willoughby or [[my]0-i sister]2818-my sister . [You]2466-you had made [your]2466-you own choice . It was not forced on [you]2466-you . [[Your]2466-you wife]2468-your wife has a claim to [your]2466-you politeness , to [your]2466-you respect , at least . [She]2468-your wife must be attached to [you]2466-you , or [she]2468-your wife would not have married [you]2466-you . To treat [her]2468-your wife with unkindness , to speak of [her]2468-your wife slightingly is no atonement to [Marianne]90-marianne — nor can [I]0-i suppose it a relief to [your]2466-you own conscience . ” “[0-i] Do not talk to [me]0-i of [[my]0-i wife]3334-my wife , ” said [he]2466-you with a heavy sigh ; “[2468-your wife] [she]2468-your wife does not deserve [your]2466-you compassion . [She]2468-your wife knew [I]0-i had no regard for [her]2468-your wife when [we]2470-we married . Well , married [we]2470-we were , and came down to [Combe Magna]35-combe magna to be happy , and afterwards returned to [town]2984-town to be gay . And now do [you]2466-you pity [me]0-i , [Miss Dashwood]84-miss dashwood ? Or have [I]0-i said all this to no purpose ? Am [I,—be]2472-i,—be it only one degree,—am [I]0-i less guilty in [your]2466-you opinion than [I]0-i was before ? [My]0-i intentions were not always wrong . Have [I]0-i explained away any part of [my]0-i guilt ? ” “[0-i] Yes , [you]2466-you have certainly removed something — a little . [You]2466-you have proved [yourself]2466-you , on the whole , less faulty than [I]0-i had believed [you]2466-you . [You]2466-you have proved [your]2466-you heart less wicked , much less wicked . But [I]0-i hardly know — the misery that [you]2466-you have inflicted — [I]0-i hardly know what could have made it worse . ” “[2466-you] Will [you]2466-you repeat to [[your]2466-you sister]2815-your sister when [she]2815-your sister is recovered , what [I]0-i have been telling you?—Let [me]0-i be a little lightened too in [her]2815-your sister opinion as well as in [yours]2466-you . [You]2466-you tell [me]0-i that [she]2815-your sister has forgiven [me]0-i already . Let [me]0-i be able to fancy that a better knowledge of [my]0-i heart , and of [my]0-i present feelings , will draw from [her]2815-your sister a more spontaneous , more natural , more gentle , less dignified , forgiveness . Tell [her]2815-your sister of [my]0-i misery and [my]0-i penitence — tell [her]2815-your sister that [my]0-i heart was never inconstant to [her]2815-your sister , and if [you]2466-you will , that at this moment [she]2815-your sister is dearer to [me]0-i than ever . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i will tell [her]2815-your sister all that is necessary to what may comparatively be called , [your]2466-you justification . But [you]2466-you have not explained to [me]0-i the particular reason of [your]2466-you coming now , nor how [you]2466-you heard of [her]2815-your sister illness . ” “[2466-you] Last night , in [Drury Lane lobby]77-drury lane lobby , [I]0-i ran against [Sir John Middleton]99-sir john , and when [he]99-sir john saw who [I]0-i was , for the first time these two months , [he]99-sir john spoke to [me]0-i . That [he]99-sir john had cut [me]0-i ever since [my]0-i marriage , [I]0-i had seen without surprise or resentment . Now , however , [his]99-sir john good - natured , honest , stupid soul , full of indignation against [me]0-i , and concern for [[your]2466-you sister]2815-your sister , could not resist the temptation of telling [me]0-i what [he]99-sir john knew ought to , though probably [he]99-sir john did not think it _ would _ , vex [me]0-i horridly . As bluntly as [he]99-sir john could speak it , therefore , [he]99-sir john told [me]0-i that [Marianne Dashwood]90-marianne was dying of a putrid fever at [Cleveland]32-cleveland — a letter that morning received from [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings declared [her]90-marianne danger most imminent — [the Palmers]126-the palmers are all gone off in a fright , & c. [I]0-i was too much shocked to be able to pass [myself]0-i off as insensible even to the undiscerning [Sir John]99-sir john . [His]99-sir john heart was softened in seeing [mine]0-i suffer ; and so much of [his]99-sir john ill - will was done away , that when [we]2475-we parted , [he]99-sir john almost shook [me]0-i by the hand while [he]99-sir john reminded [me]0-i of an old promise about a pointer puppy . What [I]0-i felt on hearing that [[your]2476-your sister]2815-your sister was dying , and dying too , believing [me]0-i [the greatest villain upon [earth]2479-earth]2478-the greatest villain upon earth , scorning , hating [me]0-i in [her]2815-your sister latest moments — for how could [I]0-i tell what horrid projects might not have been imputed ? _ [One _ person [I]0-i was sure]2480-one _ person i was sure would represent [me]0-i as capable of anything — What [I]0-i felt was dreadful ! [My]0-i resolution was soon made , and at eight o’clock this morning [I]0-i was in [[my]0-i carriage]2481-my carriage . Now [you]2476-your know all . ” [Elinor]89-elinor made no answer . [Her]89-elinor thoughts were silently fixed on the irreparable injury which too early an independence and its consequent habits of idleness , dissipation , and luxury , had made in the mind , the character , the happiness , of [a man who , to every advantage of person and talents]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents , united a disposition naturally open and honest , and a feeling , affectionate temper . [The world]2778-the world had made [him]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents extravagant and vain — Extravagance and vanity had made [him]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents cold - hearted and selfish . [Vanity]229-vanity , while seeking [its]229-vanity own guilty triumph at the expense of another , had involved [him]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents in a real attachment , which extravagance , or at least its offspring , necessity , had required to be sacrificed . Each faulty propensity in leading [him]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents to evil , had led [him]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents likewise to punishment . The attachment , from which against honour , against feeling , against every better interest [he]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents had outwardly torn [himself]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents , now , when no longer allowable , governed every thought ; and the connection , for the sake of which [he]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents had , with little scruple , left [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister to misery , was likely to prove a source of unhappiness to [himself]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents of a far more incurable nature . From a reverie of this kind [she]89-elinor was recalled at the end of some minutes by [Willoughby]107-willoughby , who , rousing [himself]107-willoughby from a reverie at least equally painful , started up in preparation for going , and said — “[2476-your] There is no use in staying [here]2861-here ; [I]0-i must be off . ” “[0-i] Are [you]0-i going back to [town]2984-town ? ” “[0-i] No — to [Combe Magna]35-combe magna . [I]0-i have business [there]354-there ; from thence to [town]2984-town in a day or two . Good bye . ” [He]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents held out [his]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents hand . [She]89-elinor could not refuse to give [him]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents [hers;—he]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents pressed it with affection . “[2486-you] And [you]2486-you _ do _ think something better of [me]0-i than [you]2486-you did ? ” said [he]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents , letting it fall , and leaning against the mantel - piece as if forgetting [he]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents was to go . [Elinor]89-elinor assured [him]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents that [she]89-elinor did;—that [she]89-elinor forgave , pitied , wished [him]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents well — was even interested in [his]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents happiness — and added some gentle counsel as to the behaviour most likely to promote it . [His]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents answer was not very encouraging . “[2486-you] As to that , ” said [he]4410-a man who , to every advantage of person and talents , “[2486-you] [I]0-i must rub through [the world]2778-the world as well as [I]0-i can . Domestic happiness is out of the question . If , however , [I]0-i am allowed to think that [you]2486-you and [yours]2486-you feel an interest in [my]0-i fate and actions , it may be the means — it may put [me]0-i on [my]0-i guard — at least , it may be something to live for . [Marianne]90-marianne to be sure is lost to [me]0-i for ever . Were [I]0-i even by any blessed chance at liberty again — ” [Elinor]89-elinor stopped [him]4413-he with a reproof . “[0-i] Well,”—he replied—“once[0-i] more good bye . [I]0-i shall now go away and live in dread of one event . ” “[0-i] What do [you]0-i mean ? ” “[0-i] [[Your]0-i sister]2815-your sister ’s marriage . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i are very wrong . [She]2815-your sister can never be more lost to [you]0-i than [she]2815-your sister is now . ” “[2815-your sister] But [she]2815-your sister will be gained by [some one else]2489-some one else . And if that [some one]2490-some one should be the very [he]2491-he whom , of all others , [I]0-i could least bear — but [I]0-i will not stay to rob [myself]0-i of all [your]0-i compassionate goodwill , by showing that where [I]0-i have most injured [I]0-i can least forgive . Good bye,—God bless [you]0-i ! ” And with these words , [he]4413-he almost ran out of [the room]2842-the room . CHAPTER XLV . [Elinor]89-elinor , for some time after [he]4413-he left [her]89-elinor , for some time even after the sound of [[his]4413-he carriage]694-his carriage had died away , remained too much oppressed by [a crowd of ideas , widely differing in themselves , but of which sadness was the general result]4416-a crowd of ideas , widely differing in themselves , but of which sadness was the general result , to think even of [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister . [Willoughby]107-willoughby , [he]107-willoughby , whom only half an hour ago [she]89-elinor had abhorred as the most worthless of [men]2910-men , [Willoughby]107-willoughby , in spite of all [his]107-willoughby faults , excited a degree of commiseration for the sufferings produced by [them]4419-them , which made [her]89-elinor think of [him]107-willoughby as now separated for ever from [[her]89-elinor family]391-her family , with a tenderness , a regret , rather in proportion , as [she]89-elinor soon acknowledged within [herself]89-elinor — to [his]107-willoughby wishes than to [his]107-willoughby merits . [She]89-elinor felt that [his]107-willoughby influence over [her]89-elinor mind was heightened by circumstances which ought not in reason to have weight ; by [that person of uncommon attraction , that open , affectionate , and lively manner which it was no merit to possess]4421-that person of uncommon attraction , that open , affectionate , and lively manner which it was no merit to possess ; and by that still ardent love for [Marianne]90-marianne , which it was not even innocent to indulge . But [she]89-elinor felt that it was so , long , long before [she]89-elinor could feel [his]107-willoughby influence less . When at last [she]89-elinor returned to the unconscious [Marianne]90-marianne , [she]89-elinor found [her]90-marianne just awaking , refreshed by so long and sweet a sleep to the extent of [her]89-elinor hopes . [Elinor]89-elinor ’s heart was full . The past , the present , the future , [Willoughby]107-willoughby ’s visit , [Marianne]90-marianne ’s safety , and [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother ’s expected arrival , threw [her]89-elinor altogether into an agitation of spirits which kept off every indication of fatigue , and made [her]89-elinor only fearful of betraying [herself]89-elinor to [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister . Short was the time , however , in which that fear could affect [her]89-elinor , for within half an hour after [Willoughby]107-willoughby ’s leaving [the house]318-the house , [she]89-elinor was again called down stairs by the sound of another carriage.—Eager to save [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother from every unnecessary moment ’s horrible suspense , [she]89-elinor ran immediately into [the hall]4426-the hall , and reached the outward door just in time to receive and support [her]332-her mother as [she]89-elinor entered [it]4426-the hall . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , whose terror as [they]4427-they drew near [the house]318-the house had produced almost the conviction of [Marianne]90-marianne ’s being no more , had no voice to inquire after [her]332-her mother , no voice even for [Elinor]89-elinor ; but _ [she]332-her mother _ , waiting neither for salutation nor inquiry , instantly gave the joyful relief ; and [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother , catching it with all [her]332-her mother usual warmth , was in a moment as much overcome by [her]332-her mother happiness , as [she]332-her mother had been before by [her]332-her mother fears . [She]332-her mother was supported into [the drawing - room]1150-the drawing - room between [[her]332-her mother daughter]404-her daughter and [[her]332-her mother friend]1021-her friend ; and there , shedding tears of joy , though still unable to speak , embraced [Elinor]89-elinor again and again , turning from [her]332-her mother at intervals to press [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ’s hand , with a look which spoke at once [her]89-elinor gratitude , and [her]89-elinor conviction of [his]104-colonel brandon sharing with [herself]89-elinor in the bliss of the moment . [He]104-colonel brandon shared it , however , in a silence even greater than [her]89-elinor own . As soon as [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood had recovered [herself]88-mrs. dashwood , to see [Marianne]90-marianne was [her]88-mrs. dashwood first desire ; and in two minutes [she]88-mrs. dashwood was with [[her]88-mrs. dashwood beloved child]4433-her beloved child , rendered dearer to [her]88-mrs. dashwood than ever by absence , unhappiness , and danger . [Elinor]89-elinor ’s delight , as [she]89-elinor saw what each felt in the meeting , was only checked by an apprehension of its robbing [Marianne]90-marianne of farther sleep : but [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood could be calm , could be even prudent , when the life of [a child]576-a child was at stake , and [Marianne]90-marianne , satisfied in knowing [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother was near [her]90-marianne , and conscious of being too weak for conversation , submitted readily to the silence and quiet prescribed by [every nurse around [her]90-marianne]4436-every nurse around her . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood _ would _ sit up with [her]90-marianne all night ; and [Elinor]89-elinor , in compliance with [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother ’s entreaty , went to bed . But the rest , which one night entirely sleepless , and many hours of the most wearing anxiety seemed to make requisite , was kept off by irritation of spirits . [Willoughby]107-willoughby , [“[107-willoughby] poor [Willoughby]107-willoughby , ” as [she]88-mrs. dashwood now allowed [herself]88-mrs. dashwood to call [him]107-willoughby]107-willoughby , was constantly in [her]88-mrs. dashwood thoughts ; [she]88-mrs. dashwood would not but have heard [his]107-willoughby vindication for [the world]2778-the world , and now blamed , now acquitted [herself]88-mrs. dashwood for having judged [him]107-willoughby so harshly before . But [her]88-mrs. dashwood promise of relating it to [[her]88-mrs. dashwood sister]336-her sister was invariably painful . [She]88-mrs. dashwood dreaded the performance of it , dreaded what its effect on [Marianne]90-marianne might be ; doubted whether after such an explanation [she]88-mrs. dashwood could ever be happy with another ; and for a moment wished [Willoughby]107-willoughby [a widower]4440-a widower . Then , remembering [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon , reproved [herself]88-mrs. dashwood , felt that to _ [his]107-willoughby _ sufferings and _ [his]107-willoughby _ constancy far more than to [[his]107-willoughby rival]1407-his rival ’s , the reward of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood sister]336-her sister was due , and wished any thing rather than [Mrs. Willoughby]173-mrs. willoughby ’s death . The shock of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ’s errand at [Barton]8-barton had been much softened to [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood by [her]88-mrs. dashwood own previous alarm ; for so great was [her]88-mrs. dashwood uneasiness about [Marianne]90-marianne , that [she]88-mrs. dashwood had already determined to set out for [Cleveland]32-cleveland on that very day , without waiting for any further intelligence , and had so far settled [her]88-mrs. dashwood journey before [his]107-willoughby arrival , that [the Careys]4443-the careys were then expected every moment to fetch [Margaret]91-margaret away , as [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother was unwilling to take [her]90-marianne where there might be infection . [Marianne]90-marianne continued to mend every day , and the brilliant cheerfulness of [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood ’s looks and spirits proved [her]90-marianne to be , as [she]90-marianne repeatedly declared [herself]90-marianne , [one of [the happiest women in [the world]2778-the world]4446-the happiest women in the world]4445-one of the happiest women in the world . [Elinor]89-elinor could not hear the declaration , nor witness its proofs without sometimes wondering whether [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother ever recollected [Edward]147-edward . But [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , trusting to the temperate account of [her]88-mrs. dashwood own disappointment which [Elinor]89-elinor had sent [her]88-mrs. dashwood , was led away by the exuberance of [her]88-mrs. dashwood joy to think only of what would increase it . [Marianne]90-marianne was restored to [her]88-mrs. dashwood from a danger in which , as [she]90-marianne now began to feel , [her]90-marianne own mistaken judgment in encouraging the unfortunate attachment to [Willoughby]107-willoughby , had contributed to place [her;—and]4449-her;—and in [her]90-marianne recovery [she]90-marianne had yet another source of joy unthought of by [Elinor]89-elinor . It was thus imparted to [her]90-marianne , as soon as any opportunity of private conference between [them]2492-them occurred . “[107-willoughby] At last [we]2492-them are alone . [[My]0-i [Elinor]89-elinor]3098-my elinor , [you]89-elinor do not yet know all [my]0-i happiness . [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon loves [Marianne]90-marianne . [He]104-colonel brandon has told [me]0-i so [himself]104-colonel brandon . ” [[Her]0-i daughter]404-her daughter , feeling by turns both pleased and pained , surprised and not surprised , was all silent attention . “[104-colonel brandon] [You]89-elinor are never like [me]0-i , [dear Elinor]89-elinor , or [I]0-i should wonder at [your]89-elinor composure now . Had [I]0-i sat down to wish for any possible good to [[my]0-i family]3220-my family , [I]0-i should have fixed on [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ’s marrying one of [you]89-elinor as the object most desirable . And [I]0-i believe [Marianne]90-marianne will be the most happy with [him]104-colonel brandon of the two . ” [Elinor]89-elinor was half inclined to ask [her]89-elinor reason for thinking so , because satisfied that none founded on an impartial consideration of [their]2495-their age , characters , or feelings , could be given;—but [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother must always be carried away by [her]332-her mother imagination on any interesting subject , and therefore instead of an inquiry , [she]0-i passed it off with a smile . “[104-colonel brandon] [He]104-colonel brandon opened [his]104-colonel brandon whole heart to [me]0-i yesterday as [we]2495-their travelled . It came out quite unawares , quite undesignedly . [I]0-i , [you]89-elinor may well believe , could talk of nothing but [[my]0-i child;—he]2496-my child;—he could not conceal [his]104-colonel brandon distress ; [I]0-i saw that it equalled [my]0-i own , and [he]104-colonel brandon perhaps , thinking that mere friendship , as [the world]2778-the world now goes , would not justify so warm a sympathy — or rather , not thinking at all , [I]0-i suppose — giving way to irresistible feelings , made [me]0-i acquainted with [his]104-colonel brandon earnest , tender , constant , affection for [Marianne]90-marianne . [He]104-colonel brandon has loved [her]90-marianne , [[my]0-i Elinor]3098-my elinor , ever since the first moment of seeing [her]90-marianne . ” Here , however , [Elinor]89-elinor perceived,—not the language , not the professions of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon , but the natural embellishments of [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother ’s active fancy , which fashioned every thing delightful to [her]89-elinor as it chose . “[104-colonel brandon] [His]104-colonel brandon regard for [her]90-marianne , infinitely surpassing anything that [Willoughby]107-willoughby ever felt or feigned , as much more warm , as more sincere or constant — which ever [we]2499-we are to call it — has subsisted through all the knowledge of dear [Marianne]90-marianne ’s unhappy prepossession for [that worthless young man!—and]2500-that worthless young man!—and without selfishness — without encouraging a hope!—could [he]104-colonel brandon have seen [her]90-marianne happy with another — Such a noble mind!—such openness , such sincerity!—no one can be deceived in _ [him]104-colonel brandon _ . ” “[104-colonel brandon] [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ’s character , ” said [Elinor]89-elinor , “[3305-an excellent man] as [an excellent man]3305-an excellent man , is well established . ” “[3305-an excellent man] [I]0-i know it is,”—replied [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother seriously , “[104-colonel brandon] or after such a warning , _ [I]0-i _ should be the last to encourage such affection , or even to be pleased by it . But [his]104-colonel brandon coming for [me]0-i as [he]104-colonel brandon did , with such active , such ready friendship , is enough to prove [him]104-colonel brandon [one of the worthiest of [men]2910-men]2502-one of the worthiest of men . ” “[104-colonel brandon] [His]104-colonel brandon character , however , ” answered [Elinor]89-elinor , “[104-colonel brandon] does not rest on _ one _ act of kindness , to which [his]104-colonel brandon affection for [Marianne]90-marianne , were humanity out of the case , would have prompted [him]104-colonel brandon . To [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings , to [the Middletons]102-the middletons , [he]104-colonel brandon has been long and intimately known ; [they]2504-they equally love and respect [him]104-colonel brandon ; and even [my]0-i own knowledge of [him]104-colonel brandon , though lately acquired , is very considerable ; and so highly do _ [I]0-i _ value and esteem [him]104-colonel brandon , that if [Marianne]90-marianne can be happy with [him]104-colonel brandon , [I]0-i shall be as ready as [yourself]2505-yourself to think [our]2506-our connection the greatest blessing to [us]2506-our in [the world]2778-the world . What answer did [you]0-i give him?—Did [you]0-i allow [him]104-colonel brandon to hope ? ” “[0-i] Oh ! [[my]0-i love]2785-my love , [I]0-i could not then talk of hope to [him]104-colonel brandon or to [myself]0-i . [Marianne]90-marianne might at that moment be dying . But [he]104-colonel brandon did not ask for hope or encouragement . [His]104-colonel brandon was an involuntary confidence , an irrepressible effusion to [a soothing friend]2509-a soothing friend , not an application to [a parent]1563-a parent . Yet after a time [I]0-i _ did _ say , for at first [I]0-i was quite overcome , that if [she]90-marianne lived , as [I]0-i trusted [she]90-marianne might , [my]0-i greatest happiness would lie in promoting [their]2511-our marriage ; and since [our]2511-our arrival , since [our]2511-our delightful security , [I]0-i have repeated it to [him]104-colonel brandon more fully , have given [him]104-colonel brandon every encouragement in [my]0-i power . Time , a very little time , [I]0-i tell [him]104-colonel brandon , will do everything ; [Marianne]90-marianne ’s heart is not to be wasted for ever on [such a man]2979-such a man as [Willoughby]107-willoughby . [His]104-colonel brandon own merits must soon secure it . ” “[104-colonel brandon] To judge from [the Colonel]104-colonel brandon ’s spirits , however , [you]0-i have not yet made [him]104-colonel brandon equally sanguine . ” “[0-i] No . [He]104-colonel brandon thinks [Marianne]90-marianne ’s affection too deeply rooted for any change in it under a great length of time , and even supposing [her]90-marianne heart again free , is too diffident of [himself]104-colonel brandon to believe , that with such a difference of age and disposition [he]104-colonel brandon could ever attach [her]90-marianne . There , however , [he]104-colonel brandon is quite mistaken . [His]104-colonel brandon age is only so much beyond [hers]90-marianne as to be an advantage , as to make [his]104-colonel brandon character and principles fixed ; and [his]104-colonel brandon disposition , [I]0-i am well convinced , is exactly the very one to make [[your]2513-your sister]2815-your sister happy . And [his]104-colonel brandon person , [his]104-colonel brandon manners too , are all in [his]104-colonel brandon favour . [My]0-i partiality does not blind [me]0-i ; [he]104-colonel brandon certainly is not so handsome as [Willoughby]107-willoughby ; but at the same time , there is something much more pleasing in [his]104-colonel brandon countenance . There was always a something , if [you]2513-your remember , in [Willoughby]107-willoughby ’s eyes at times , which [I]0-i did not like . ” [Elinor]89-elinor could _ not _ remember it ; but [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother , without waiting for [her]89-elinor assent , continued , “[104-colonel brandon] And [his]104-colonel brandon manners , [the Colonel]664-the colonel ’s manners are not only more pleasing to [me]0-i than [Willoughby]107-willoughby ’s ever were , but [they]2516-their are of a kind [I]0-i well know to be more solidly attaching to [Marianne]90-marianne . [Their]2516-their gentleness , [their]2516-their genuine attention to [other people]2834-other people , and [their]2516-their manly unstudied simplicity is much more accordant with [her]90-marianne real disposition , than the liveliness , often artificial , and often ill - timed of the other . [I]0-i am very sure [myself]0-i , that had [Willoughby]107-willoughby turned out as really amiable , as [he]107-willoughby has proved [himself]107-willoughby the contrary , [Marianne]90-marianne would yet never have been so happy with _ [him]107-willoughby _ as [she]90-marianne will be with [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon . ” [[She]0-i paused.—Her [daughter]3240-daughter]4455-she paused.—her daughter could not quite agree with [her]0-i , but [her]0-i dissent was not heard , and therefore gave no offence . “[104-colonel brandon] At [Delaford]22-delaford , [she]90-marianne will be within an easy distance of [me]0-i , ” added [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , “[90-marianne] even if [I]0-i remain at [Barton]8-barton ; and in all probability,—for [I]0-i hear it is [a large village,—indeed]2518-a large village,—indeed there certainly _ must _ be [some small house]2519-some small house or [cottage close by]2520-cottage close by , that would suit [us]2521-us quite as well as [our]2521-us present situation . ” [Poor Elinor!—here]230-poor elinor!—here was a new scheme for getting [her]0-i to [Delaford!—but]78-delaford!—but [her]0-i spirit was stubborn . “[2522-his] [His]2522-his fortune too!—for at [my]0-i time of life [you]2523-you know , [everybody]3862-everybody cares about _ that;_—and though [I]0-i neither know nor desire to know , what it really is , [I]0-i am sure it must be a good one . ” Here [they]2521-us were interrupted by the entrance of [a third person]4457-a third person , and [Elinor]89-elinor withdrew to think it all over in private , to wish success to [[her]89-elinor friend]1021-her friend , and yet in wishing it , to feel a pang for [Willoughby]107-willoughby . CHAPTER XLVI . [Marianne]90-marianne ’s illness , though weakening in its kind , had not been long enough to make [her]90-marianne recovery slow ; and with youth , natural strength , and [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother ’s presence in aid , it proceeded so smoothly as to enable [her]90-marianne to remove , within four days after the arrival of [the latter]325-the latter , into [[Mrs. Palmer]128-mrs. palmer ’s dressing - room]4461-mrs. palmer ’s dressing - room . When [there]354-there , at [her]90-marianne own particular request , for [she]90-marianne was impatient to pour forth [her]90-marianne thanks to [him]107-willoughby for fetching [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother , [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon was invited to visit [her]90-marianne . [His]107-willoughby emotion on entering [the room]2842-the room , in seeing [her]90-marianne altered looks , and in receiving the pale hand which [she]90-marianne immediately held out to [him]107-willoughby , was such , as , in [Elinor]89-elinor ’s conjecture , must arise from something more than [his]107-willoughby affection for [Marianne]90-marianne , or the consciousness of its being known to [others]2961-others ; and [she]90-marianne soon discovered in [his]107-willoughby melancholy eye and varying complexion as [he]107-willoughby looked at [[her]90-marianne sister]336-her sister , the probable recurrence of many past scenes of misery to [his]107-willoughby mind , brought back by that resemblance between [Marianne]90-marianne and [Eliza]150-eliza already acknowledged , and now strengthened by the hollow eye , the sickly skin , the posture of reclining weakness , and the warm acknowledgment of peculiar obligation . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , not less watchful of what passed than [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughter]404-her daughter , but with a mind very differently influenced , and therefore watching to very different effect , saw nothing in [the Colonel]664-the colonel ’s behaviour but what arose from the most simple and self - evident sensations , while in the actions and words of [Marianne]90-marianne [she]88-mrs. dashwood persuaded [herself]88-mrs. dashwood to think that something more than gratitude already dawned . At the end of another day or two , [Marianne]90-marianne growing visibly stronger every twelve hours , [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , urged equally by [her]88-mrs. dashwood own and [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughter]404-her daughter ’s wishes , began to talk of removing to [Barton]6-barton park . On _ [her]88-mrs. dashwood _ measures depended those of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood two friends]4470-her two friends ; [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings could not quit [Cleveland]32-cleveland during [the Dashwoods]92-the miss dashwoods ’ stay ; and [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon was soon brought , by [their]4470-her two friends united request , to consider [his]104-colonel brandon own abode there as equally determinate , if not equally indispensable . At [his]104-colonel brandon and [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings ’s united request in return , [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood was prevailed on to accept the use of [[his]104-colonel brandon carriage]694-his carriage on [her]88-mrs. dashwood journey back , for the better accommodation of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood sick child]4472-her sick child ; and [the Colonel]664-the colonel , at the joint invitation of [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood and [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings , whose active good - nature made [her]88-mrs. dashwood friendly and hospitable for [other people]2834-other people as well as [herself]88-mrs. dashwood , engaged with pleasure to redeem it by a visit at [the cottage]507-the cottage , in the course of a few weeks . The day of separation and departure arrived ; and [Marianne]90-marianne , after taking so particular and lengthened a leave of [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings , one so earnestly grateful , so full of respect and kind wishes as seemed due to [her]90-marianne own heart from a secret acknowledgment of past inattention , and bidding [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon farewell with a cordiality of [a friend]1286-a friend , was carefully assisted by [him]104-colonel brandon into [the carriage]1118-the carriage , of which [he]104-colonel brandon seemed anxious that [she]90-marianne should engross at least half . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood and [Elinor]89-elinor then followed , and [the others]539-the others were left by [themselves]539-the others , to talk of [the travellers]4385-the travellers , and feel [their]539-the others own dullness , till [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings was summoned to [her]103-mrs. jennings chaise to take comfort in the gossip of [[her]103-mrs. jennings maid]4318-her maid for the loss of [[her]103-mrs. jennings two young companions]4481-her two young companions ; and [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon immediately afterwards took [his]104-colonel brandon solitary way to [Delaford]22-delaford . [The Dashwoods]92-the miss dashwoods were two days on [the road]976-the road , and [Marianne]90-marianne bore [her]90-marianne journey on both , without essential fatigue . Every thing that the most zealous affection , the most solicitous care could do to render [her]90-marianne comfortable , was the office of [each watchful companion]4483-each watchful companion , and [each]1837-each found [their]1837-each reward in [her]90-marianne bodily ease , and [her]90-marianne calmness of spirits . To [Elinor]89-elinor , the observation of [the latter]325-the latter was particularly grateful . [She]89-elinor , who had seen [her]89-elinor week after week so constantly suffering , oppressed by anguish of heart which [she]89-elinor had neither courage to speak of , nor fortitude to conceal , now saw with a joy , which [no other]3063-no other could equally share , an apparent composure of mind , which , in being the result as [she]89-elinor trusted of serious reflection , must eventually lead [her]89-elinor to contentment and cheerfulness . As [they]1837-each approached [Barton]8-barton , indeed , and entered on scenes of which [every field]4487-every field and every tree brought some peculiar , some painful recollection , [she]89-elinor grew silent and thoughtful , and turning away [her]89-elinor face from [their]1837-each notice , sat earnestly gazing through the window . But here , [Elinor]89-elinor could neither wonder nor blame ; and when [she]89-elinor saw , as [she]89-elinor assisted [Marianne]90-marianne from [the carriage]1118-the carriage , that [she]90-marianne had been crying , [she]89-elinor saw only an emotion too natural in itself to raise any thing less tender than pity , and in its unobtrusiveness entitled to praise . In the whole of [her]89-elinor subsequent manner , [she]89-elinor traced the direction of a mind awakened to reasonable exertion ; for no sooner had [they]1837-each entered [[their]1837-each common sitting - room]4489-their common sitting - room , than [Marianne]90-marianne turned [her]90-marianne eyes around [it]4489-their common sitting - room with a look of resolute firmness , as if determined at once to accustom [herself]90-marianne to the sight of every object with which the remembrance of [Willoughby]107-willoughby could be connected.—She said little , but every sentence aimed at cheerfulness , and though a sigh sometimes escaped [her]90-marianne , it never passed away without the atonement of a smile . After dinner [she]90-marianne would try [her]90-marianne piano - forte . [She]90-marianne went to it ; but the music on which [her]90-marianne eye first rested was an opera , procured for [her]90-marianne by [Willoughby]107-willoughby , containing some of [their]1837-each favourite duets , and bearing on its outward leaf [her]90-marianne own name in [his]107-willoughby hand - writing.—That would not do.—She shook [her]90-marianne head , put the music aside , and after running over the keys for a minute , complained of feebleness in [her]90-marianne fingers , and closed the instrument again ; declaring however with firmness as [she]90-marianne did so , that [she]90-marianne should in future practice much . The next morning produced no abatement in these happy symptoms . On the contrary , with a mind and body alike strengthened by rest , [she]90-marianne looked and spoke with more genuine spirit , anticipating the pleasure of [Margaret]91-margaret ’s return , and talking of the dear family party which would then be restored , of [their]1837-each mutual pursuits and cheerful society , as the only happiness worth a wish . “[0-i] When the weather is settled , and [I]0-i have recovered [my]0-i strength , ” said [she]0-i , “[0-i] [we]2525-we will take long walks together every day . [We]2525-we will walk to [the farm]2526-the farm at the edge of the down , and see how [the children]264-the children go on ; [we]2525-we will walk to [[Sir John]99-sir john ’s new plantations at [Barton Cross]79-barton cross]2528-sir john ’s new plantations at barton cross , and [the Abbeyland]2529-the abbeyland ; and [we]2525-we will often go to [the old ruins of [the Priory]2531-the priory]2530-the old ruins of the priory , and try to trace [its]2531-the priory foundations as far as [we]2525-we are told [they]2531-the priory once reached . [I]0-i know [we]2525-we shall be happy . [I]0-i know the summer will pass happily away . [I]0-i mean never to be later in rising than six , and from that time till dinner [I]0-i shall divide every moment between music and reading . [I]0-i have formed [my]0-i plan , and am determined to enter on a course of serious study . [[Our]2525-we own library]2532-our own library is too well known to [me]0-i , to be resorted to for any thing beyond mere amusement . But there are many works well worth reading at [the Park]566-the park ; and there are others of more modern production which [I]0-i know [I]0-i can borrow of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon . By reading only six hours a - day , [I]0-i shall gain in the course of a twelve - month a great deal of instruction which [I]0-i now feel [myself]0-i to want . ” [Elinor]89-elinor honoured [her]0-i for a plan which originated so nobly as this ; though smiling to see the same eager fancy which had been leading [her]0-i to the extreme of languid indolence and selfish repining , now at work in introducing excess into a scheme of such rational employment and virtuous self - control . [Her]0-i smile however changed to a sigh when [she]0-i remembered that promise to [Willoughby]107-willoughby was yet unfulfilled , and feared [she]0-i had that to communicate which might again unsettle the mind of [Marianne]90-marianne , and ruin at least for a time this fair prospect of busy tranquillity . Willing therefore to delay the evil hour , [she]0-i resolved to wait till [[her]0-i sister]336-her sister ’s health were more secure , before [she]0-i appointed it . But the resolution was made only to be broken . [Marianne]90-marianne had been two or three days at [home]565-home , before the weather was fine enough for [an invalid like [herself]90-marianne]4492-an invalid like herself to venture out . But at last a soft , genial morning appeared ; such as might tempt [the daughter]4493-the daughter ’s wishes and [the mother]1206-the mother ’s confidence ; and [Marianne]90-marianne , leaning on [Elinor]89-elinor ’s arm , was authorised to walk as long as [she]90-marianne could without fatigue , in [the lane before [the house]318-the house]4495-the lane before the house . [The sisters]1282-the sisters set out at a pace , slow as the feebleness of [Marianne]90-marianne in an exercise hitherto untried since [her]90-marianne illness required ; and [they]1282-the sisters had advanced only so far beyond [the house]318-the house as to admit a full view of [the hill]718-the hill , [the important hill]4500-the important hill behind , when pausing with [her]0-i eyes turned towards [it]718-the hill , [Marianne]90-marianne calmly said , — “[0-i] There , exactly there,”—pointing with one hand , “[0-i] on that projecting mound,—there [I]0-i fell ; and there [I]0-i first saw [Willoughby]107-willoughby . ” [Her]90-marianne voice sunk with the word , but presently reviving [she]90-marianne added , “[107-willoughby] [I]0-i am thankful to find that [I]0-i can look with so little pain on the spot ! shall [we]2534-we ever talk on that subject , [Elinor]89-elinor ? ” hesitatingly it was said . “[89-elinor] Or will it be wrong ? [I]0-i _ can _ talk of it now , [I]0-i hope , as [I]0-i ought to do . ” [Elinor]89-elinor tenderly invited [her]90-marianne to be open . “[0-i] As for regret , ” said [Marianne]90-marianne , “[0-i] [I]0-i have done with that , as far as _ [he]107-willoughby _ is concerned . [I]0-i do not mean to talk to [you]89-elinor of what [my]0-i feelings have been for [him]107-willoughby , but what they are _ now _ . At present , if [I]0-i could be satisfied on one point , if [I]0-i could be allowed to think that [he]107-willoughby was not _ always _ acting a part , not _ always _ deceiving [me]0-i ; but above all , if [I]0-i could be assured that [he]107-willoughby never was so _ very _ wicked as [my]0-i fears have sometimes fancied [him]107-willoughby , since the story of [that unfortunate girl]2395-that unfortunate girl — ” [She]0-i stopt . [Elinor]89-elinor joyfully treasured [her]89-elinor words as [she]89-elinor answered , “[2395-that unfortunate girl] If [you]89-elinor could be assured of that , [you]89-elinor think [you]89-elinor should be easy . ” “[89-elinor] Yes . [My]0-i peace of mind is doubly involved in it ; for not only is it horrible to suspect [a person]1351-a person , who has been what _ [he]107-willoughby _ has been to _ [me]0-i _ , of such designs , but what must it make [me]0-i appear to [myself]0-i ? What in a situation like [mine]0-i , but a most shamefully unguarded affection could expose [me]0-i to — ” “[0-i] How then , ” asked [[her]0-i sister]336-her sister , “[0-i] would [you]0-i account for [his]107-willoughby behaviour ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i would suppose him,—Oh , how gladly would [I]0-i suppose [him]107-willoughby , only fickle , very , very fickle . ” [Elinor]89-elinor said no more . [She]89-elinor was debating within [herself]89-elinor on the eligibility of beginning [her]89-elinor story directly , or postponing it till [Marianne]90-marianne were in stronger health;—and [they]4502-they crept on for a few minutes in silence . “[107-willoughby] [I]0-i am not wishing [him]107-willoughby too much good , ” said [Marianne]90-marianne at last with a sigh , “[0-i] when [I]0-i wish [his]107-willoughby secret reflections may be no more unpleasant than [my]0-i own . [He]107-willoughby will suffer enough in them . ” “[0-i] Do [you]0-i compare [your]0-i conduct with [his]107-willoughby ? ” “[0-i] No . [I]0-i compare it with what it ought to have been ; [I]0-i compare it with [yours]2537-yours . ” “[0-i] [Our]2538-our situations have borne little resemblance . ” “[0-i] They have borne more than [our]2538-our conduct . Do not , [[my]0-i dearest]3507-my dearest [Elinor]89-elinor , let [your]89-elinor kindness defend what [I]0-i know [your]89-elinor judgment must censure . [My]0-i illness has made [me]0-i think . It has given [me]0-i leisure and calmness for serious recollection . Long before [I]0-i was enough recovered to talk , [I]0-i was perfectly able to reflect . [I]0-i considered the past : [I]0-i saw in [my]0-i own behaviour , since the beginning of [our]2538-our acquaintance with [him]2540-him last autumn , nothing but a series of imprudence towards [myself]0-i , and want of kindness to [others]2961-others . [I]0-i saw that [my]0-i own feelings had prepared [my]0-i sufferings , and that [my]0-i want of fortitude under them had almost led [me]0-i to the grave . [My]0-i illness , [I]0-i well knew , had been entirely brought on by [myself]0-i by such negligence of [my]0-i own health , as [I]0-i had felt even at the time to be wrong . Had [I]0-i died , it would have been self - destruction . [I]0-i did not know [my]0-i danger till the danger was removed ; but with such feelings as these reflections gave [me]0-i , [I]0-i wonder at [my]0-i recovery,—wonder that the very eagerness of [my]0-i desire to live , to have time for atonement to [[my]0-i God]2542-my god , and to [you]2543-you all , did not kill [me]0-i at once . Had [I]0-i died , in what peculiar misery should [I]0-i have left [you]2543-you , [[my]0-i nurse]2544-my nurse , [[my]0-i friend]4026-my friend , [[my]0-i sister]2818-my sister ! [You]2543-you , who had seen all the fretful selfishness of [my]0-i latter days ; who had known all the murmurings of [my]0-i heart ! How should [I]0-i have lived in _ [your]2543-you _ remembrance ! [[My]0-i mother]2771-my mother too ! How could [you]2543-you have consoled [her]2771-my mother ! [I]0-i can not express [my]0-i own abhorrence of [myself]0-i . Whenever [I]0-i looked towards the past , [I]0-i saw some duty neglected , or some failing indulged . [Every body]581-every body seemed injured by [me]0-i . The kindness , the unceasing kindness of [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings , [I]0-i had repaid with ungrateful contempt . To [the Middletons]102-the middletons , to [the Palmers]126-the palmers , [the Steeles]137-the miss steeles , to [every common acquaintance even]2549-every common acquaintance even , [I]0-i had been insolent and unjust ; with a heart hardened against [their]2550-their merits , and a temper irritated by [their]2550-their very attention . To [John]99-sir john , to [Fanny]93-fanny , yes , even to [them]2550-their , little as [they]2550-their deserve , [I]0-i had given less than [their]2550-their due . But [you]2551-you , [you]2551-you above all , above [[my]0-i mother]2771-my mother , had been wronged by [me]0-i . [I]0-i , and only [I]0-i , knew [your]2551-you heart and its sorrows ; yet to what did it influence [me?—not]2553-me?—not to any compassion that could benefit [you]2551-you or myself.—Your example was before [me]0-i ; but to what avail ? Was [I]0-i more considerate of [you]2551-you and [your]2551-you comfort ? Did [I]0-i imitate [your]2551-you forbearance , or lessen [your]2551-you restraints , by taking any part in those offices of general complaisance or particular gratitude which [you]2551-you had hitherto been left to discharge alone ? No ; not less when [I]0-i knew [you]2551-you to be unhappy , than when [I]0-i had believed [you]2551-you at ease , did [I]0-i turn away from every exertion of duty or friendship ; scarcely allowing sorrow to exist but with [me]0-i , regretting only _ that _ heart which had deserted and wronged [me]0-i , and leaving [you]2551-you , for whom [I]0-i professed an unbounded affection , to be miserable for [my]0-i sake . ” Here ceased the rapid flow of [her]0-i self - reproving spirit ; and [Elinor]89-elinor , impatient to soothe , though too honest to flatter , gave [her]0-i instantly that praise and support which [her]0-i frankness and [her]0-i contrition so well deserved . [Marianne]90-marianne pressed [her]0-i hand and replied , — “[2551-you] [You]2551-you are very good.—The future must be [my]0-i proof . [I]0-i have laid down [my]0-i plan , and if [I]0-i am capable of adhering to it — [my]0-i feelings shall be governed and [my]0-i temper improved . [They]2554-they shall no longer worry [others]2961-others , nor torture [myself]0-i . [I]0-i shall now live solely for [[my]0-i family]3220-my family . [You]2551-you , [[my]0-i mother]2771-my mother , and [Margaret]91-margaret , must henceforth be all [the world]2778-the world to [me]0-i ; [you]2551-you will share [my]0-i affections entirely between [you]2551-you . From [you]2551-you , from [[my]0-i home]2559-my home , [I]0-i shall never again have the smallest incitement to move ; and if [I]0-i do mix in other society , it will be only to show that [my]0-i spirit is humbled , [my]0-i heart amended , and that [I]0-i can practise the civilities , the lesser duties of life , with gentleness and forbearance . As for [Willoughby]107-willoughby — to say that [I]0-i shall soon or that [I]0-i shall ever forget [him]107-willoughby , would be idle . [His]107-willoughby remembrance can be overcome by no change of circumstances or opinions . But it shall be regulated , it shall be checked by religion , by reason , by constant employment . ” [She]0-i paused — and added in a low voice , “[107-willoughby] If [I]0-i could but know _ [his]107-willoughby _ heart , everything would become easy . ” [Elinor]89-elinor , who had now been for some time reflecting on the propriety or impropriety of speedily hazarding [her]89-elinor narration , without feeling at all nearer decision than at first , heard this ; and perceiving that as reflection did nothing , resolution must do all , soon found [herself]89-elinor leading to the fact . [She]0-i managed the recital , as [she]0-i hoped , with address ; prepared [[her]0-i anxious listener]4503-her anxious listener with caution ; related simply and honestly the chief points on which [Willoughby]107-willoughby grounded [his]107-willoughby apology ; did justice to [his]107-willoughby repentance , and softened only [his]107-willoughby protestations of present regard . [Marianne]90-marianne said not a word.—She trembled , [her]90-marianne eyes were fixed on the ground , and [her]90-marianne lips became whiter than even sickness had left them . A thousand inquiries sprung up from [her]0-i heart , but [she]0-i dared not urge one . [She]0-i caught every syllable with panting eagerness ; [her]0-i hand , unknowingly to [herself]0-i , closely pressed [[her]0-i sister]336-her sister ’s , and tears covered [her]90-marianne cheeks . [Elinor]89-elinor , dreading [her]89-elinor being tired , led [her]89-elinor towards [home]565-home ; and till [they]4506-they reached the door of [the cottage]507-the cottage , easily conjecturing what [her]89-elinor curiosity must be though no question was suffered to speak it , talked of nothing but [Willoughby]107-willoughby , and [their]4506-they conversation together ; and was carefully minute in every particular of speech and look , where minuteness could be safely indulged . As soon as [they]4506-they entered [the house]318-the house , [Marianne]90-marianne with a kiss of gratitude and these two words just articulate through [her]90-marianne tears , “[2826-mama] Tell [mama]2826-mama , ” withdrew from [[her]90-marianne sister]336-her sister and walked slowly up [stairs]933-stairs . [Elinor]89-elinor would not attempt to disturb a solitude so reasonable as what [she]89-elinor now sought ; and with a mind anxiously pre - arranging its result , and a resolution of reviving the subject again , should [Marianne]90-marianne fail to do it , [she]89-elinor turned into [the parlour]726-the parlour to fulfill [her]89-elinor parting injunction . CHAPTER XLVII . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood did not hear unmoved the vindication of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood former favourite]4512-her former favourite . [She]88-mrs. dashwood rejoiced in [his]4512-her former favourite being cleared from some part of [his]4512-her former favourite imputed guilt;—she was sorry for [him;—she]88-mrs. dashwood wished [him]4512-her former favourite happy . But the feelings of the past could not be recalled.—Nothing could restore [him]4512-her former favourite with a faith unbroken — a character unblemished , to [Marianne]90-marianne . Nothing could do away the knowledge of what [the latter]325-the latter had suffered through [his]4512-her former favourite means , nor remove the guilt of [his]4512-her former favourite conduct towards [Eliza]150-eliza . Nothing could replace [him]4512-her former favourite , therefore , in [her]90-marianne former esteem , nor injure the interests of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon . Had [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , like [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughter]404-her daughter , heard [Willoughby]107-willoughby ’s story from [himself]4512-her former favourite — had [she]88-mrs. dashwood witnessed [his]4512-her former favourite distress , and been under the influence of [his]4512-her former favourite countenance and [his]4512-her former favourite manner , it is probable that [her]88-mrs. dashwood compassion would have been greater . But it was neither in [Elinor]89-elinor ’s power , nor in [her]88-mrs. dashwood wish , to rouse such feelings in another , by [her]88-mrs. dashwood retailed explanation , as had at first been called forth in [herself]88-mrs. dashwood . [Reflection]231-reflection had given calmness to [her]88-mrs. dashwood judgment , and sobered [her]88-mrs. dashwood own opinion of [Willoughby]107-willoughby ’s deserts;—she wished , therefore , to declare only the simple truth , and lay open such facts as were really due to [his]4512-her former favourite character , without any embellishment of tenderness to lead the fancy astray . In the evening , when [they]2561-you were all three together , [Marianne]90-marianne began voluntarily to speak of [him]4512-her former favourite again;—but that it was not without an effort , the restless , unquiet thoughtfulness in which [she]90-marianne had been for some time previously sitting — [her]90-marianne rising colour , as [she]90-marianne spoke,—and [her]90-marianne unsteady voice , plainly showed . “[2826-mama] [I]0-i wish to assure [you]2561-you both , ” said [she]90-marianne , “[0-i] that [I]0-i see every thing — as [you]2561-you can desire [me]0-i to do . ” [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood would have interrupted [her]0-i instantly with soothing tenderness , had not [Elinor]89-elinor , who really wished to hear [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister ’s unbiased opinion , by an eager sign , engaged [her]0-i silence . [Marianne]90-marianne slowly continued , — “[89-elinor] It is a great relief to [me]0-i — what [Elinor]89-elinor told [me]0-i this morning — [I]0-i have now heard exactly what [I]0-i wished to hear . ”—For some moments [her]90-marianne voice was lost ; but recovering [herself]90-marianne , [she]90-marianne added , and with greater calmness than before—“I[89-elinor] am now perfectly satisfied , [I]0-i wish for no change . [I]0-i never could have been happy with [him]2562-him , after knowing , as sooner or later [I]0-i must have known , all this.—I should have had no confidence , no esteem . Nothing could have done it away to [my]0-i feelings . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i know it — [I]0-i know it , ” cried [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother . “[0-i] Happy with [a man of libertine]2563-a man of libertine practices!—With one who so injured the peace of [the dearest of [[our]2565-our friends]2860-our friends]2564-the dearest of our friends , and the best of men!—No — [[my]0-i Marianne]2833-my marianne has not a heart to be made happy with such a man!—Her conscience , [her]2833-my marianne sensitive conscience , would have felt all that the conscience of [[her]2833-my marianne husband]319-her husband ought to have felt . ” [Marianne]90-marianne sighed , and repeated , “[0-i] [I]0-i wish for no change . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i consider the matter , ” said [Elinor]89-elinor , “[0-i] exactly as a good mind and a sound understanding must consider it ; and [I]0-i dare say [you]0-i perceive , as well as [myself]0-i , not only in this , but in many other circumstances , reason enough to be convinced that [your]0-i marriage must have involved [you]0-i in many certain troubles and disappointments , in which [you]0-i would have been poorly supported by an affection , on [his]319-her husband side , much less certain . Had [you]0-i married , [you]0-i must have been always poor . [His]319-her husband expensiveness is acknowledged even by [himself]319-her husband , and [his]319-her husband whole conduct declares that self - denial is a word hardly understood by [him]319-her husband . [His]319-her husband demands and [your]0-i inexperience together , on a small , very small income , must have brought on distresses which would not be the _ less _ grievous to [you]0-i , from having been entirely unknown and unthought of before . _ [Your]0-i _ sense of honour and honesty would have led [you]0-i , [I]0-i know , when aware of [your]0-i situation , to attempt all the economy that would appear to [you]0-i possible : and , perhaps , as long as [your]0-i frugality retrenched only on [your]0-i own comfort , [you]0-i might have been suffered to practice it , but beyond that — and how little could the utmost of [your]0-i single management do to stop the ruin which had begun before [your]0-i marriage ? Beyond _ that _ , had [you]0-i endeavoured , however reasonably , to abridge _ [his]319-her husband _ enjoyments , is it not to be feared , that instead of prevailing on feelings so selfish to consent to it , [you]0-i would have lessened [your]0-i own influence on [his]319-her husband heart , and made [him]319-her husband regret the connection which had involved [him]319-her husband in such difficulties ? ” [Marianne]90-marianne ’s lips quivered , and [she]90-marianne repeated the word “[0-i] Selfish ? ” in a tone that implied—“do[0-i] [you]0-i really think [him]319-her husband selfish ? ” “[0-i] The whole of [his]319-her husband behaviour , ” replied [Elinor]89-elinor , “[0-i] from the beginning to the end of the affair , has been grounded on selfishness . It was selfishness which first made [him]319-her husband sport with [your]0-i affections ; which afterwards , when [his]319-her husband own were engaged , made [him]319-her husband delay the confession of it , and which finally carried [him]319-her husband from [Barton]8-barton . [His]319-her husband own enjoyment , or [his]319-her husband own ease , was , in every particular , [his]319-her husband ruling principle . ” “[319-her husband] It is very true . _ [My]0-i _ happiness never was [his]319-her husband object . ” “[319-her husband] At present , ” continued [Elinor]89-elinor , “[319-her husband] [he]319-her husband regrets what [he]319-her husband has done . And why does [he]319-her husband regret it?—Because [he]319-her husband finds it has not answered towards [himself]319-her husband . It has not made [him]319-her husband happy . [His]319-her husband circumstances are now unembarrassed — [he]319-her husband suffers from no evil of that kind ; and [he]319-her husband thinks only that [he]319-her husband has married [a woman of a less amiable temper]2569-a woman of a less amiable temper than [yourself]2570-yourself . But does it follow that had [he]319-her husband married [you]2570-yourself , [he]319-her husband would have been happy?—The inconveniences would have been different . [He]319-her husband would then have suffered under the pecuniary distresses which , because they are removed , [he]319-her husband now reckons as nothing . [He]319-her husband would have had [a wife of whose temper]2571-a wife of whose temper [he]319-her husband could make no complaint , but [he]319-her husband would have been always necessitous — always poor ; and probably would soon have learned to rank the innumerable comforts of a clear estate and good income as of far more importance , even to domestic happiness , than the mere temper of [a wife]2876-a wife . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have not a doubt of it , ” said [Marianne]90-marianne ; “[0-i] and [I]0-i have nothing to regret — nothing but [my]0-i own folly . ” “[2781-your mother] Rather say [[your]2570-yourself mother]2781-your mother ’s imprudence , [[my]0-i child]2574-my child , ” said [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood ; “[2781-your mother] _ [she]2781-your mother _ must be answerable . ” [Marianne]90-marianne would not let [her]0-i proceed;—and [Elinor]89-elinor , satisfied that [each]1837-each felt [their]1837-each own error , wished to avoid any survey of the past that might weaken [[her]89-elinor sister]336-her sister ’s spirits ; [she]0-i , therefore , pursuing the first subject , immediately continued , “[2781-your mother] _ One _ observation may , [I]0-i think , be fairly drawn from the whole of the story — that all [Willoughby]107-willoughby ’s difficulties have arisen from the first offence against virtue , in [his]107-willoughby behaviour to [Eliza Williams]150-eliza . That crime has been the origin of [every lesser one]2575-every lesser one , and of all [his]107-willoughby present discontents . ” [Marianne]90-marianne assented most feelingly to the remark ; and [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother was led by it to an enumeration of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ’s injuries and merits , warm as friendship and design could unitedly dictate . [[Her]332-her mother daughter]404-her daughter did not look , however , as if much of it were heard by [her]332-her mother . [Elinor]89-elinor , according to [her]89-elinor expectation , saw on the two or three following days , that [Marianne]90-marianne did not continue to gain strength as [she]90-marianne had done ; but while [her]90-marianne resolution was unsubdued , and [she]90-marianne still tried to appear cheerful and easy , [[her]90-marianne sister]336-her sister could safely trust to the effect of time upon [her]90-marianne health . [Margaret]91-margaret returned , and [the family]303-the family were again all restored to [each other]338-each other , again quietly settled at [the cottage]507-the cottage ; and if not pursuing [their]303-the family usual studies with quite so much vigour as when [they]303-the family first came to [Barton]8-barton , at least planning a vigorous prosecution of [them]303-the family in future . [Elinor]89-elinor grew impatient for some tidings of [Edward]147-edward . [She]89-elinor had heard nothing of [him]147-edward since [her]89-elinor leaving [London]24-london , nothing new of [his]147-edward plans , nothing certain even of [[his]147-edward present abode]4525-his present abode . Some letters had passed between [her]89-elinor and [[her]89-elinor brother]339-her brother , in consequence of [Marianne]90-marianne ’s illness ; and in the first of [John]88-mrs. dashwood ’s , there had been this sentence:—“We[0-i] know nothing of [[our]2576-our unfortunate [Edward]147-edward]2577-our unfortunate edward , and can make no enquiries on so prohibited a subject , but conclude [him]147-edward to be still at [Oxford]29-oxford ; ” which was all the intelligence of [Edward]147-edward afforded [her]89-elinor by the correspondence , for [his]147-edward name was not even mentioned in any of the succeeding letters . [She]89-elinor was not doomed , however , to be long in ignorance of [his]147-edward measures . [[Their]2576-our man - servant]4527-their man - servant had been sent one morning to [Exeter]10-exeter on business ; and when , as [he]147-edward waited at table , [he]147-edward had satisfied the inquiries of [[his]147-edward mistress]1706-his mistress as to the event of [his]147-edward errand , this was [his]147-edward voluntary communication , — “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [you]0-i know , [ma’am]2974-ma’am , that [Mr. Ferrars]144-robert is married . ” [Marianne]90-marianne gave a violent start , fixed [her]90-marianne eyes upon [Elinor]89-elinor , saw [her]89-elinor turning pale , and fell back in [her]90-marianne chair in hysterics . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , whose eyes , as [she]88-mrs. dashwood answered [the servant]818-the servant ’s inquiry , had intuitively taken the same direction , was shocked to perceive by [Elinor]89-elinor ’s countenance how much [she]89-elinor really suffered , and a moment afterwards , alike distressed by [Marianne]90-marianne ’s situation , knew not on which child to bestow [her]88-mrs. dashwood principal attention . [The servant]818-the servant , who saw only that [Miss Marianne]90-marianne was taken ill , had sense enough to call one of [the maids]504-the maids , who , with [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood ’s assistance , supported [her]90-marianne into [the other room]4532-the other room . By that time , [Marianne]90-marianne was rather better , and [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother leaving [her]90-marianne to the care of [Margaret]91-margaret and [the maid]4329-the maid , returned to [Elinor]89-elinor , who , though still much disordered , had so far recovered the use of [her]89-elinor reason and voice as to be just beginning an inquiry of [Thomas]189-thomas , as to the source of [his]189-thomas intelligence . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood immediately took all that trouble on [herself]88-mrs. dashwood ; and [Elinor]89-elinor had the benefit of the information without the exertion of seeking it . “[0-i] Who told [you]2579-you that [Mr. Ferrars]144-robert was married , [Thomas]189-thomas ? ” “[189-thomas] [I]0-i see [Mr. Ferrars]144-robert [myself]0-i , [ma’am]2974-ma’am , this morning in [Exeter]10-exeter , and [[his]144-robert lady]593-his lady too , [Miss Steele]138-lucy as was . [They]2582-they was stopping in a chaise at the door of [the New London Inn]2583-the new london inn , as [I]0-i went there with a message from [Sally]232-sally at [the Park]566-the park to [[her]232-sally brother]339-her brother , who is [one of [the post - boys]2587-the post - boys]2586-one of the post - boys . [I]0-i happened to look up as [I]0-i went by the chaise , and so [I]0-i see directly it was the youngest [Miss Steele]138-lucy ; so [I]0-i took off [my]0-i hat , and [she]232-sally knew [me]0-i and called to [me]0-i , and inquired after [you]2588-you , [ma’am]2974-ma’am , and [the young ladies]628-the young ladies , especially [Miss Marianne]90-marianne , and bid [me]0-i [I]0-i should give [her]232-sally compliments and [Mr. Ferrars]144-robert ’s , [their]628-the young ladies best compliments and service , and how sorry [they]628-the young ladies was [they]628-the young ladies had not time to come on and see [you]2588-you , but [they]628-the young ladies was in a great hurry to go forwards , for [they]628-the young ladies was going further down for a little while , but howsever , when [they]628-the young ladies come back , [they]628-the young ladies ’d make sure to come and see [you]2588-you . ” “[628-the young ladies] But did [she]232-sally tell [you]2588-you [she]232-sally was married , [Thomas]189-thomas ? ” “[232-sally] Yes , [ma’am]2974-ma’am . [She]232-sally smiled , and said how [she]232-sally had changed [her]232-sally name since [she]232-sally was in these parts . [She]232-sally was always [a very affable and free - spoken young lady]2592-a very affable and free - spoken young lady , and very civil behaved . So , [I]0-i made free to wish [her]232-sally joy . ” “[0-i] Was [Mr. Ferrars]144-robert in [the carriage]1118-the carriage with [her]232-sally ? ” “[144-robert] Yes , [ma’am]2974-ma’am , [I]0-i just see [him]144-robert leaning back in it , but [he]144-robert did not look up;—he never was [a gentleman]985-a gentleman much for talking . ” [Elinor]89-elinor ’s heart could easily account for [his]144-robert not putting [himself]144-robert forward ; and [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood probably found the same explanation . “[985-a gentleman] Was there [no one else]1104-no one else in [the carriage]1118-the carriage ? ” “[1104-no one else] No , [ma’am]2974-ma’am , only [they]2599-they two . ” “[1104-no one else] Do [you]0-i know where [they]2599-they came from ? ” “[0-i] [They]2599-they come straight from [town]2984-town , as [Miss Lucy]138-lucy — [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward told [me]0-i . ” “[138-lucy] And are [they]2599-they going farther westward ? ” “[2599-they] Yes , [ma’am]2974-ma’am — but not to bide long . [They]2599-they will soon be back again , and then [they]2599-they ’d be sure and call here . ” [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood now looked at [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughter]404-her daughter ; but [Elinor]89-elinor knew better than to expect [them]2599-they . [She]89-elinor recognised [the whole of [Lucy]138-lucy]4536-the whole of lucy in the message , and was very confident that [Edward]98-edward would never come near [them]2599-they . [She]89-elinor observed in a low voice , to [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother , that [they]2599-they were probably going down to [Mr. Pratt]145-mr. pratt ’s , near [Plymouth]26-plymouth . [Thomas]189-thomas ’s intelligence seemed over . [Elinor]89-elinor looked as if [she]89-elinor wished to hear more . “[2599-they] Did [you]2602-you see [them]2603-them off , before [you]2602-you came away ? ” “[2602-you] No , [ma’am]2974-ma’am — the horses were just coming out , but [I]0-i could not bide any longer ; [I]0-i was afraid of being late . ” “[0-i] Did [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward look well ? ” “[98-edward] Yes , [ma’am]2974-ma’am , [she]98-edward said how [she]98-edward was very well ; and to [my]0-i mind [she]98-edward was always [a very handsome young lady]2606-a very handsome young lady — and [she]98-edward seemed vastly contented . ” [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood could think of no other question , and [Thomas]189-thomas and the tablecloth , now alike needless , were soon afterwards dismissed . [Marianne]90-marianne had already sent to say , that [she]90-marianne should eat nothing more . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood ’s and [Elinor]89-elinor ’s appetites were equally lost , and [Margaret]91-margaret might think [herself]91-margaret very well off , that with so much uneasiness as both [[her]91-margaret sisters]334-her sisters had lately experienced , so much reason as [they]334-her sisters had often had to be careless of [their]334-her sisters meals , [she]91-margaret had never been obliged to go without [her]91-margaret dinner before . When the dessert and the wine were arranged , and [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood and [Elinor]89-elinor were left by [themselves]334-her sisters , [they]334-her sisters remained long together in a similarity of thoughtfulness and silence . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood feared to hazard any remark , and ventured not to offer consolation . [She]88-mrs. dashwood now found that [she]88-mrs. dashwood had erred in relying on [Elinor]89-elinor ’s representation of [herself]89-elinor ; and justly concluded that every thing had been expressly softened at the time , to spare [her]89-elinor from an increase of unhappiness , suffering as [she]89-elinor then had suffered for [Marianne]90-marianne . [She]88-mrs. dashwood found that [she]88-mrs. dashwood had been misled by the careful , the considerate attention of [[her]88-mrs. dashwood daughter]404-her daughter , to think the attachment , which once [she]88-mrs. dashwood had so well understood , much slighter in reality , than [she]88-mrs. dashwood had been wo nt to believe , or than it was now proved to be . [She]88-mrs. dashwood feared that under this persuasion [she]88-mrs. dashwood had been unjust , inattentive , nay , almost unkind , to [her]88-mrs. dashwood Elinor;—that [Marianne]90-marianne ’s affliction , because more acknowledged , more immediately before [her]88-mrs. dashwood , had too much engrossed [her]88-mrs. dashwood tenderness , and led [her]88-mrs. dashwood away to forget that in [Elinor]89-elinor [she]88-mrs. dashwood might have [a daughter]4540-a daughter suffering almost as much , certainly with less self - provocation , and greater fortitude . CHAPTER XLVIII . [Elinor]89-elinor now found the difference between the expectation of an unpleasant event , however certain the mind may be told to consider it , and certainty itself . [She]89-elinor now found , that in spite of [herself]89-elinor , [she]89-elinor had always admitted a hope , while [Edward]98-edward remained single , that something would occur to prevent [his]4541-he marrying [Lucy]138-lucy ; that some resolution of [his]4541-he own , some mediation of [friends]3231-friends , or some more eligible opportunity of establishment for [the lady]370-the lady , would arise to assist the happiness of all . But [he]4541-he was now married ; and [she]89-elinor condemned [her]89-elinor heart for the lurking flattery , which so much heightened the pain of the intelligence .
