That [he]4541-he should be married soon , before ( as [she]89-elinor imagined ) [he]4541-he could be in [orders]4544-orders , and consequently before [he]4541-he could be in possession of the living , surprised [her]89-elinor a little at first . But [she]89-elinor soon saw how likely it was that [Lucy]138-lucy , in [her]138-lucy self - provident care , in [her]138-lucy haste to secure [him]4541-he , should overlook every thing but the risk of delay . [They]4545-they were married , married in [town]2984-town , and now hastening down to [[her]138-lucy uncle]3772-her uncle ’s . What had [Edward]98-edward felt on being within four miles from [Barton]8-barton , on seeing [[[her]138-lucy mother]332-her mother ’s servant]4549-her mother ’s servant , on hearing [Lucy]138-lucy ’s message ! [They]4545-they would soon , [she]89-elinor supposed , be settled at [Delaford.—Delaford,—that place in which so much conspired to give [her]89-elinor an interest ; which [she]89-elinor wished to be acquainted with , and yet desired to avoid]4550-delaford.—delaford,—that place in which so much conspired to give her an interest ; which she wished to be acquainted with , and yet desired to avoid . [She]89-elinor saw [them]4545-they in an instant in [[their]4545-they parsonage - house]4551-their parsonage - house ; saw in [Lucy]138-lucy , [the active , contriving manager]4552-the active , contriving manager , uniting at once a desire of smart appearance with the utmost frugality , and ashamed to be suspected of half [her]138-lucy economical practices;—pursuing [her]138-lucy own interest in every thought , courting the favour of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon , of [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings , and of [every wealthy friend]4553-every wealthy friend . In [Edward]98-edward — [she]89-elinor knew not what [she]89-elinor saw , nor what [she]89-elinor wished to see;—happy or unhappy,—nothing pleased [her]89-elinor ; [she]89-elinor turned away [her]89-elinor head from every sketch of [him]104-colonel brandon . [Elinor]89-elinor flattered [herself]89-elinor that [some one of [their]4555-their connections in [London]24-london]4554-some one of their connections in london would write to [them]4555-their to announce the event , and give farther particulars,—but day after day passed off , and brought no letter , no tidings . Though uncertain that [any one]659-any one were to blame , [she]89-elinor found fault with [every absent friend]4557-every absent friend . [They]4555-their were all thoughtless or indolent . “[98-edward] When do [you]2607-you write to [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon , [ma’am]2974-ma’am ? ” was an inquiry which sprung from the impatience of [her]89-elinor mind to have something going on . “[2607-you] [I]0-i wrote to [him]104-colonel brandon , [[my]0-i love]2785-my love , last week , and rather expect to see , than to hear from [him]104-colonel brandon again . [I]0-i earnestly pressed [his]104-colonel brandon coming to [us]2610-us , and should not be surprised to see [him]104-colonel brandon walk in today or tomorrow , or any day . ” This was gaining something , something to look forward to . [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon _ must _ have some information to give . Scarcely had [she]89-elinor so determined it , when the figure of [a man on horseback]984-a man on horseback drew [her]89-elinor eyes to the window . [He]984-a man on horseback stopt at [their]2610-us gate . It was [a gentleman]985-a gentleman , it was [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon [himself]984-a man on horseback . Now [she]89-elinor could hear more ; and [she]89-elinor trembled in expectation of it . But it was _ not [_ Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ; neither [his]984-a man on horseback air , nor [his]984-a man on horseback height . Were it possible , [she]89-elinor must say it must be [Edward]98-edward . [She]89-elinor looked again . [He]2611-he had just dismounted : [she]89-elinor could not be mistaken,—it _ was _ [Edward]98-edward . [She]89-elinor moved away and sat down . “[2611-he] [He]2611-he comes from [Mr. Pratt]145-mr. pratt ’s purposely to see [us]2612-us . [I]0-i _ will _ be calm ; [I]0-i _ will _ be [mistress of [myself]0-i]2613-mistress of myself . ” In a moment [she]89-elinor perceived that [the others]539-the others were likewise aware of the mistake . [She]89-elinor saw [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother and [Marianne]90-marianne change colour ; saw [them]539-the others look at [herself]89-elinor , and whisper a few sentences to [each other]338-each other . [She]89-elinor would have given [the world]2778-the world to be able to speak — and to make [them]539-the others understand that [she]89-elinor hoped no coolness , no slight , would appear in [their]539-the others behaviour to him;—but [she]89-elinor had no utterance , and was obliged to leave all to [their]539-the others own discretion . Not a syllable passed aloud . [They]539-the others all waited in silence for the appearance of [[their]539-the others visitor]1005-their visitor . [His]1005-their visitor footsteps were heard along [the gravel path]4565-the gravel path ; in a moment [he]1005-their visitor was in [the passage]2862-the passage , and in another [he]1005-their visitor was before [them]539-the others . [His]1005-their visitor countenance , as [he]1005-their visitor entered [the room]2842-the room , was not too happy , even for [Elinor]89-elinor . [His]1005-their visitor complexion was white with agitation , and [he]1005-their visitor looked as if fearful of [his]1005-their visitor reception , and conscious that [he]1005-their visitor merited [no kind one]4568-no kind one . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , however , conforming , as [she]88-mrs. dashwood trusted , to the wishes of [that daughter]4569-that daughter , by whom [she]88-mrs. dashwood then meant in the warmth of [her]88-mrs. dashwood heart to be guided in every thing , met [him]1005-their visitor with a look of forced complacency , gave [him]1005-their visitor [her]88-mrs. dashwood hand , and wished [him]1005-their visitor joy . [He]1005-their visitor coloured , and stammered out an unintelligible reply . [Elinor]89-elinor ’s lips had moved with [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother ’s , and , when the moment of action was over , [she]89-elinor wished that [she]89-elinor had shaken hands with [him]1005-their visitor too . But it was then too late , and with a countenance meaning to be open , [she]89-elinor sat down again and talked of the weather . [Marianne]90-marianne had retreated as much as possible out of sight , to conceal [her]90-marianne distress ; and [Margaret]91-margaret , understanding some part , but not the whole of the case , thought it incumbent on [her]89-elinor to be dignified , and therefore took a seat as far from [him]1005-their visitor as [she]89-elinor could , and maintained a strict silence . When [Elinor]89-elinor had ceased to rejoice in the dryness of the season , a very awful pause took place . It was put an end to by [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , who felt obliged to hope that [he]1005-their visitor had left [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward very well . In a hurried manner , [he]1005-their visitor replied in the affirmative . Another pause . [Elinor]89-elinor resolving to exert [herself]89-elinor , though fearing the sound of [her]89-elinor own voice , now said , “[0-i] Is [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward at [Longstaple]36-longstaple ? ” “[98-edward] At [Longstaple]36-longstaple ! ” [he]1005-their visitor replied , with an air of surprise . “[98-edward] No , [[my]0-i mother]2771-my mother is in [town]2984-town . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i meant , ” said [Elinor]89-elinor , taking up some work from the table , “[0-i] to enquire for [Mrs. _ Edward _ Ferrars]98-edward . ” [She]89-elinor dared not look up;—but [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother and [Marianne]90-marianne both turned [their]4572-their eyes on [him]1005-their visitor . [He]1005-their visitor coloured , seemed perplexed , looked doubtingly , and , after some hesitation , said , — “[98-edward] Perhaps [you]0-i mean — [[my]0-i brother]2962-my brother — [you]0-i mean [Mrs.—Mrs]233-mrs.—mrs . _ [Robert _ Ferrars]144-robert . ” “[144-robert] [Mrs. Robert Ferrars]234-mrs. robert ferrars ! ” was repeated by [Marianne]90-marianne and [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother in an accent of the utmost amazement ; and though [Elinor]89-elinor could not speak , even _ [her]89-elinor _ eyes were fixed on [him]1005-their visitor with the same impatient wonder . [He]1005-their visitor rose from [his]1005-their visitor seat , and walked to the window , apparently from not knowing what to do ; took up a pair of scissors that lay there , and while spoiling both them and [their]4574-their sheath by cutting [the latter]325-the latter to pieces as [he]1005-their visitor spoke , said , in a hurried voice , — “[0-i] Perhaps [you]0-i do not know : [you]0-i may not have heard that [[my]0-i brother]2962-my brother is lately married to — to [the youngest]1227-the youngest — to [Miss Lucy Steele]138-lucy . ” [His]1005-their visitor words were echoed with unspeakable astonishment by all but [Elinor]89-elinor , who sat with [her]89-elinor head leaning over [her]89-elinor work , in a state of such agitation as made [her]89-elinor hardly know where [she]89-elinor was . “[138-lucy] Yes , ” said [he]1005-their visitor , “[138-lucy] [they]2619-they were married last week , and are now at [Dawlish]59-dawlish . ” [Elinor]89-elinor could sit it no longer . [She]89-elinor almost ran out of [the room]2842-the room , and as soon as the door was closed , burst into tears of joy , which at first [she]89-elinor thought would never cease . [Edward]98-edward , who had till then looked any where , rather than at [her]89-elinor , saw [her]89-elinor hurry away , and perhaps saw — or even heard , [her]89-elinor emotion ; for immediately afterwards [he]1005-their visitor fell into a reverie , which no remarks , no inquiries , no affectionate address of [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood could penetrate , and at last , without saying a word , quitted [the room]2842-the room , and walked out towards [the village]3190-the village — leaving [the others]539-the others in the greatest astonishment and perplexity on a change in [his]1005-their visitor situation , so wonderful and so sudden;—a perplexity which [they]539-the others had no means of lessening but by [their]539-the others own conjectures . CHAPTER XLIX . Unaccountable , however , as the circumstances of [his]1005-their visitor release might appear to [the whole family]1013-the whole family , it was certain that [Edward]98-edward was free ; and to what purpose that freedom would be employed was easily pre - determined by all;—for after experiencing the blessings of _ one _ imprudent engagement , contracted without [[his]1005-their visitor mother]270-his mother ’s consent , as [he]1005-their visitor had already done for more than four years , nothing less could be expected of [him]1005-their visitor in the failure of _ that _ , than the immediate contraction of another . [His]1005-their visitor errand at [Barton]8-barton , in fact , was a simple one . It was only to ask [Elinor]89-elinor to marry [him;—and]1005-their visitor considering that [he]1005-their visitor was not altogether inexperienced in such a question , it might be strange that [he]1005-their visitor should feel so uncomfortable in the present case as [he]1005-their visitor really did , so much in need of encouragement and fresh air . How soon [he]1005-their visitor had walked [himself]1005-their visitor into the proper resolution , however , how soon an opportunity of exercising it occurred , in what manner [he]1005-their visitor expressed [himself]1005-their visitor , and how [he]1005-their visitor was received , need not be particularly told . This only need be said;—that when [they]539-the others all sat down to table at four o’clock , about three hours after [his]1005-their visitor arrival , [he]1005-their visitor had secured [[his]1005-their visitor lady]593-his lady , engaged [[her]593-his lady mother]332-her mother ’s consent , and was not only in the rapturous profession of [the lover]4584-the lover , but , in the reality of reason and truth , [one of the happiest of [men]2910-men]4585-one of the happiest of men . [His]1005-their visitor situation indeed was more than commonly joyful . [He]1005-their visitor had more than the ordinary triumph of accepted love to swell [his]1005-their visitor heart , and raise [his]1005-their visitor spirits . [He]1005-their visitor was released without any reproach to [himself]1005-their visitor , from an entanglement which had long formed [his]1005-their visitor misery , from [a woman whom [he]1005-their visitor had long ceased to love;—and]4587-a woman whom he had long ceased to love;—and elevated at once to that security with another , which [he]1005-their visitor must have thought of almost with despair , as soon as [he]1005-their visitor had learnt to consider it with desire . [He]1005-their visitor was brought , not from doubt or suspense , but from misery to happiness;—and the change was openly spoken in such a genuine , flowing , grateful cheerfulness , as [[his]1005-their visitor friends]2872-his friends had never witnessed in [him]1005-their visitor before . [His]1005-their visitor heart was now open to [Elinor]89-elinor , all its weaknesses , all its errors confessed , and [his]1005-their visitor first boyish attachment to [Lucy]138-lucy treated with all the philosophic dignity of twenty - four . “[138-lucy] It was a foolish , idle inclination on [my]0-i side , ” said [he]1005-their visitor , “[138-lucy] the consequence of ignorance of [the world]2778-the world , and want of employment . Had [[my]0-i mother]2771-my mother given [me]0-i some active profession when [I]0-i was removed at eighteen from the care of [Mr. Pratt]145-mr. pratt , [I]0-i think , nay , [I]0-i am sure , it would never have happened ; for though [I]0-i left [Longstaple]36-longstaple with what [I]0-i thought , at the time , a most unconquerable preference for [[his]36-longstaple niece]293-his niece , yet had [I]0-i then had any pursuit , any object to engage [my]0-i time and keep [me]0-i at a distance from [her]293-his niece for a few months , [I]0-i should very soon have outgrown the fancied attachment , especially by mixing more with [the world]2778-the world , as in such case [I]0-i must have done . But instead of having any thing to do , instead of having any profession chosen for [me]0-i , or being allowed to chuse any [myself]0-i , [I]0-i returned [home]565-home to be completely idle ; and for the first twelvemonth afterwards [I]0-i had not even the nominal employment , which belonging to [the university]2625-the university would have given [me]0-i ; for [I]0-i was not entered at [Oxford]29-oxford till [I]0-i was nineteen . [I]0-i had therefore nothing in [the world]2778-the world to do , but to fancy [myself]0-i in love ; and as [[my]0-i mother]2771-my mother did not make [[my]0-i [home]565-home]2559-my home in every respect comfortable , as [I]0-i had [no friend]2630-no friend , no companion in [[my]0-i brother]2962-my brother , and disliked new acquaintance , it was not unnatural for [me]0-i to be very often at [Longstaple]36-longstaple , where [I]0-i always felt [myself]0-i at [home]565-home , and was always sure of a welcome ; and accordingly [I]0-i spent the greatest part of [my]0-i time [there]354-there from eighteen to nineteen : [Lucy]138-lucy appeared everything that was amiable and obliging . [She]138-lucy was pretty too — at least [I]0-i thought so _ then ; _ and [I]0-i had seen so little of [other women]2634-other women , that [I]0-i could make no comparisons , and see no defects . Considering everything , therefore , [I]0-i hope , foolish as [our]2635-our engagement was , foolish as it has since in every way been proved , it was not at the time an unnatural or an inexcusable piece of folly . ” The change which a few hours had wrought in the minds and the happiness of [the Dashwoods]92-the miss dashwoods , was such — so great — as promised [them]4589-them all , the satisfaction of a sleepless night . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , too happy to be comfortable , knew not how to love [Edward]98-edward , nor praise [Elinor]89-elinor enough , how to be enough thankful for [his]4590-his release without wounding [his]4590-his delicacy , nor how at once to give [them]4589-them leisure for unrestrained conversation together , and yet enjoy , as [she]88-mrs. dashwood wished , the sight and society of both . [Marianne]90-marianne could speak _ [her]90-marianne _ happiness only by tears . Comparisons would occur — regrets would arise ; and [her]90-marianne joy , though sincere as [her]90-marianne love for [[her]90-marianne sister]336-her sister , was of a kind to give [her]90-marianne neither spirits nor language . But [Elinor]89-elinor — how are _ [her]89-elinor _ feelings to be described ? From the moment of learning that [Lucy]138-lucy was married to [another]3834-another , that [Edward]98-edward was free , to the moment of [his]4590-his justifying the hopes which had so instantly followed , [she]89-elinor was every thing by turns but tranquil . But when the second moment had passed , when [she]88-mrs. dashwood found every doubt , every solicitude removed , compared [her]88-mrs. dashwood situation with what so lately it had been,—saw [him]4590-his honourably released from [his]4590-his former engagement,—saw [him]4590-his instantly profiting by the release , to address [herself]88-mrs. dashwood and declare an affection as tender , as constant as [she]88-mrs. dashwood had ever supposed it to be,—she was oppressed , [she]88-mrs. dashwood was overcome by [her]88-mrs. dashwood own felicity ; and happily disposed as is [the human mind]4593-the human mind to be easily familiarized with any change for the better , it required several hours to give sedateness to [her]88-mrs. dashwood spirits , or any degree of tranquillity to [her]88-mrs. dashwood heart . [Edward]98-edward was now fixed at [the cottage]507-the cottage at least for a week;—for whatever other claims might be made on [him]4590-his , it was impossible that less than a week should be given up to the enjoyment of [Elinor]89-elinor ’s company , or suffice to say half that was to be said of the past , the present , and the future;—for though a very few hours spent in the hard labor of incessant talking will despatch more subjects than can really be in common between [any two rational creatures]4595-any two rational creatures , yet with [lovers]643-lovers it is different . Between _ [them]643-lovers _ no subject is finished , no communication is even made , till it has been made at least twenty times over . [Lucy]138-lucy ’s marriage , the unceasing and reasonable wonder among [them]643-lovers all , formed of course one of the earliest discussions of the lovers;—and [Elinor]89-elinor ’s particular knowledge of each party made it appear to [her]88-mrs. dashwood in every view , as one of the most extraordinary and unaccountable circumstances [she]88-mrs. dashwood had ever heard . How [they]643-lovers could be thrown together , and by what attraction [Robert]144-robert could be drawn on to marry [a girl]4597-a girl , of whose beauty [she]88-mrs. dashwood had [herself]88-mrs. dashwood heard [him]144-robert speak without any [admiration,—a girl too already engaged to [[his]144-robert brother]3045-his brother , and on whose account [that brother]4195-that brother had been thrown off by [[his]144-robert family]564-his family]4598-admiration,—a girl too already engaged to his brother , and on whose account that brother had been thrown off by his family — it was beyond [her]88-mrs. dashwood comprehension to make out . To [her]88-mrs. dashwood own heart it was a delightful affair , to [her]88-mrs. dashwood imagination it was even a ridiculous one , but to [her]88-mrs. dashwood reason , [her]88-mrs. dashwood judgment , it was completely a puzzle . [Edward]98-edward could only attempt an explanation by supposing , that , perhaps , at first accidentally meeting , the vanity of [the one]1931-the one had been so worked on by the flattery of the other , as to lead by degrees to all the rest . [Elinor]89-elinor remembered what [Robert]144-robert had told [her]89-elinor in [Harley Street]56-harley street , of [his]144-robert opinion of what [his]144-robert own mediation in [[his]144-robert brother]3045-his brother ’s affairs might have done , if applied to in time . [She]89-elinor repeated it to [Edward]98-edward . “[144-robert] _ That _ was exactly like [Robert]144-robert , ” was [his]144-robert immediate observation . “[144-robert] And _ that _ , ” [he]144-robert presently added , “[144-robert] might perhaps be in _ [his]144-robert _ head when the acquaintance between [them]2636-them first began . And [Lucy]138-lucy perhaps at first might think only of procuring [his]144-robert good offices in [my]0-i favour . Other designs might afterward arise . ” How long it had been carrying on between [them]2636-them , however , [he]144-robert was equally at a loss with [herself]138-lucy to make out ; for at [Oxford]29-oxford , where [he]144-robert had remained for choice ever since [his]144-robert quitting [London]24-london , [he]144-robert had had no means of hearing of [her]138-lucy but from [herself]138-lucy , and [her]138-lucy letters to the very last were neither less frequent , nor less affectionate than usual . Not the smallest suspicion , therefore , had ever occurred to prepare [him]144-robert for what followed;—and when at last it burst on [him]144-robert in a letter from [Lucy]138-lucy [herself]138-lucy , [he]144-robert had been for some time , [he]144-robert believed , half stupified between the wonder , the horror , and the joy of such a deliverance . [He]144-robert put the letter into [Elinor]89-elinor ’s hands . “[138-lucy] [DEAR SIR]235-dear sir , “ Being very sure [I]235-dear sir have long lost [your]235-dear sir affections , [I]235-dear sir have thought [myself]235-dear sir at liberty to bestow [my]235-dear sir own on [another]3834-another , and have no doubt of being as happy with [him]3834-another as [I]235-dear sir once used to think [I]235-dear sir might be with [you]235-dear sir ; but [I]235-dear sir scorn to accept a hand while the heart was another ’s . Sincerely wish [you]235-dear sir happy in [your]235-dear sir choice , and it shall not be [my]235-dear sir fault if [we]4605-we are not always [good friends]4606-good friends , as [our]4605-we near relationship now makes proper . [I]235-dear sir can safely say [I]235-dear sir owe [you]235-dear sir no ill - will , and am sure [you]235-dear sir will be too generous to do [us]4605-we any ill offices . [[Your]235-dear sir brother]3364-your brother has gained [my]235-dear sir affections entirely , and as [we]4605-we could not live without [one another]1089-one another , [we]4605-we are just returned from the altar , and are now on [our]4605-we way to [Dawlish]59-dawlish for a few weeks , which place [[your]235-dear sir dear brother]4609-your dear brother has great curiosity to see , but thought [I]235-dear sir would first trouble [you]235-dear sir with these few lines , and shall always remain , “[235-dear sir] [[Your]2637-he sincere well - wisher]2638-your sincere well - wisher , [friend]2639-friend , and [sister]438-sister , “ [LUCY FERRARS]236-lucy . “[235-dear sir] [I]0-i have burnt all [your]2637-he letters , and will return [your]2637-he picture the first opportunity . Please to destroy [my]0-i scrawls — but the ring with [my]0-i hair [you]2637-he are very welcome to keep . ” [Elinor]89-elinor read and returned it without any comment . “[0-i] [I]0-i will not ask [your]2637-he opinion of it as a composition , ” said Edward.—“For[0-i] worlds would not [I]0-i have had a letter of [hers]2641-her seen by _ [you]2637-he _ in former days.—In [a sister]3914-a sister it is bad enough , but in a wife!—how [I]0-i have blushed over the pages of [her]2641-her writing!—and [I]0-i believe [I]0-i may say that since the first half year of [our]2643-our foolish — business — this is the only letter [I]0-i ever received from [her]2641-her , of which the substance made [me]0-i any amends for the defect of the style . ” “[2781-your mother] However it may have come about , ” said [Elinor]89-elinor , after a pause,—“they[2781-your mother] are certainly married . And [[your]2637-he mother]2781-your mother has brought on [herself]2781-your mother a most appropriate punishment . The independence [she]2781-your mother settled on [Robert]144-robert , through resentment against [you]2637-he , has put it in [his]144-robert power to make [his]144-robert own choice ; and [she]2781-your mother has actually been bribing [one son]265-one son with a thousand a - year , to do the very deed which [she]2781-your mother disinherited the other for intending to do . [She]2781-your mother will hardly be less hurt , [I]0-i suppose , by [Robert]144-robert ’s marrying [Lucy]236-lucy , than [she]2781-your mother would have been by [your]2637-he marrying [her]236-lucy . ” “[2781-your mother] [She]2781-your mother will be more hurt by it , for [Robert]144-robert always was [her]2781-your mother favourite.—She will be more hurt by it , and on the same principle will forgive [him]144-robert much sooner . ” In what state the affair stood at present between [them]4610-them , [Edward]98-edward knew not , for no communication with [any of [[his]2637-he family]564-his family]4611-any of his family had yet been attempted by [him]2637-he . [He]2637-he had quitted [Oxford]29-oxford within four and twenty hours after [Lucy]236-lucy ’s letter arrived , and with only one object before [him]2637-he , [the nearest road to [Barton]8-barton]4613-the nearest road to barton , had had no leisure to form any scheme of conduct , with which [that road]4614-that road did not hold the most intimate connection . [He]2637-he could do nothing till [he]2637-he were assured of [his]2637-he fate with [Miss Dashwood]84-miss dashwood ; and by [his]2637-he rapidity in seeking _ that _ fate , it is to be supposed , in spite of the jealousy with which [he]2637-he had once thought of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon , in spite of the modesty with which [he]2637-he rated [his]2637-he own deserts , and the politeness with which [he]2637-he talked of [his]2637-he doubts , [he]2637-he did not , upon the whole , expect a very cruel reception . It was [his]2637-he business , however , to say that [he]2637-he _ did _ , and [he]2637-he said it very prettily . What [he]2637-he might say on the subject a twelvemonth after , must be referred to the imagination of [husbands]644-husbands and [wives]4616-wives . That [Lucy]236-lucy had certainly meant to deceive , to go off with a flourish of malice against [him]2637-he in [her]236-lucy message by [Thomas]189-thomas , was perfectly clear to [Elinor]89-elinor ; and [Edward]98-edward [himself]98-edward , now thoroughly enlightened on [her]89-elinor character , had no scruple in believing [her]89-elinor capable of the utmost meanness of wanton ill - nature . Though [his]2637-he eyes had been long opened , even before [his]2637-he acquaintance with [Elinor]89-elinor began , to [her]89-elinor ignorance and a want of liberality in some of [her]89-elinor opinions — they had been equally imputed , by [him]2637-he , to [her]89-elinor want of education ; and till [her]89-elinor last letter reached [him]2637-he , [he]2637-he had always believed [her]89-elinor to be [a well - disposed , good - hearted girl]4617-a well - disposed , good - hearted girl , and thoroughly attached to [himself]2637-he . Nothing but such a persuasion could have prevented [his]2637-he putting an end to an engagement , which , long before the discovery of it laid [him]2637-he open to [[his]2637-he mother]270-his mother ’s anger , had been a continual source of disquiet and regret to [him]2637-he . “[0-i] [I]0-i thought it [my]0-i duty , ” said [he]2637-he , “[0-i] independent of [my]0-i feelings , to give [her]2646-her the option of continuing the engagement or not , when [I]0-i was renounced by [[my]0-i mother]2771-my mother , and stood to all appearance without [a friend in [the world]2778-the world]2648-a friend in the world to assist [me]0-i . In such a situation as that , where there seemed nothing to tempt the avarice or the vanity of [any living creature]2650-any living creature , how could [I]0-i suppose , when [she]2646-her so earnestly , so warmly insisted on sharing [my]0-i fate , whatever it might be , that any thing but the most disinterested affection was [her]2646-her inducement ? And even now , [I]0-i can not comprehend on what motive [she]2646-her acted , or what fancied advantage it could be to [her]2646-her , to be fettered to [a man for whom [she]2646-her had not the smallest regard , and who had only two thousand pounds in [the world]2778-the world]2651-a man for whom she had not the smallest regard , and who had only two thousand pounds in the world . [She]2646-her could not foresee that [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon would give [me]0-i a living . ” “[2646-her] No ; but [she]2646-her might suppose that something would occur in [your]2653-you favour ; that [[your]2653-you own family]2654-your own family might in time relent . And at any rate , [she]2646-her lost nothing by continuing the engagement , for [she]2646-her has proved that it fettered neither [her]2646-her inclination nor [her]2646-her actions . The connection was certainly a respectable one , and probably gained [her]2646-her consideration among [[her]2646-her friends]1633-her friends ; and , if nothing more advantageous occurred , it would be better for [her]2646-her to marry _ [you]2653-you _ than be single . ” [Edward]98-edward was , of course , immediately convinced that nothing could have been more natural than [Lucy]236-lucy ’s conduct , nor more self - evident than the motive of it . [Elinor]89-elinor scolded [him]2653-you , harshly as [ladies]3907-ladies always scold the imprudence which compliments [themselves]3907-ladies , for having spent so much time with [them]3907-ladies at [Norland]3-norland , when [he]2653-you must have felt [his]2653-you own inconstancy . “[2653-you] [Your]2653-you behaviour was certainly very wrong , ” said [she]0-i ; “[2653-you] because — to say nothing of [my]0-i own conviction , [our]2656-our relations were all led away by it to fancy and expect _ what _ , as [you]2653-you were _ then _ situated , could never be . ” [He]2653-you could only plead an ignorance of [his]2653-you own heart , and a mistaken confidence in the force of [his]2653-you engagement . “[0-i] [I]0-i was simple enough to think , that because [my]0-i _ faith _ was plighted to another , there could be no danger in [my]0-i being with [you]2653-you ; and that the consciousness of [my]0-i engagement was to keep [my]0-i heart as safe and sacred as [my]0-i honour . [I]0-i felt that [I]0-i admired [you]2653-you , but [I]0-i told [myself]0-i it was only friendship ; and till [I]0-i began to make comparisons between [yourself]2653-you and [Lucy]236-lucy , [I]0-i did not know how far [I]0-i was got . After that , [I]0-i suppose , [I]0-i _ was _ wrong in remaining so much in [Sussex]1-sussex , and the arguments with which [I]0-i reconciled [myself]0-i to the expediency of it , were no better than these:—The danger is [my]0-i own ; [I]0-i am doing no injury to [anybody]1729-anybody but [myself]0-i . ” [Elinor]89-elinor smiled , and shook [her]89-elinor head . [Edward]98-edward heard with pleasure of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ’s being expected at [the Cottage]507-the cottage , as [he]2658-he really wished not only to be better acquainted with [him]104-colonel brandon , but to have an opportunity of convincing [him]104-colonel brandon that [he]2658-he no longer resented [his]2658-he giving [him]104-colonel brandon the living of [Delaford—“Which]80-delaford—“which[2658-he] , at present , ” said [he]2658-he , “[2658-he] after thanks so ungraciously delivered as [mine]0-i were on the occasion , [he]2658-he must think [I]0-i have never forgiven [him]2658-he for offering . ” _ Now _ [he]2658-he felt astonished [himself]2658-he that [he]2658-he had never yet been to [the place]464-the place . But so little interest had [he]2658-he taken in the matter , that [he]2658-he owed all [his]2658-he knowledge of [the house]318-the house , [garden]455-garden , and glebe , extent of [the parish]2977-the parish , condition of [the land]3929-the land , and rate of the tithes , to [Elinor]89-elinor [herself]89-elinor , who had heard so much of it from [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon , and heard it with so much attention , as to be entirely [mistress of the subject]4148-mistress of the subject . One question after this only remained undecided , between [them]4627-their , one difficulty only was to be overcome . [They]4627-their were brought together by mutual affection , with the warmest approbation of [[their]4627-their real friends]4628-their real friends ; [their]4627-their intimate knowledge of each other seemed to make [their]4627-their happiness certain — and [they]4627-their only wanted something to live upon . [Edward]98-edward had two thousand pounds , and [Elinor]89-elinor one , which , with [Delaford]22-delaford living , was all that [they]4627-their could call [their]4627-their own ; for it was impossible that [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood should advance anything ; and [they]4627-their were neither of [them]4627-their quite enough in love to think that three hundred and fifty pounds a - year would supply [them]4627-their with the comforts of life . [Edward]98-edward was not entirely without hopes of some favourable change in [[his]4629-his mother]270-his mother towards [him]4629-his ; and on _ that _ [he]4629-his rested for the residue of [their]4627-their income . But [Elinor]89-elinor had no such dependence ; for since [Edward]98-edward would still be unable to marry [Miss Morton]178-miss morton , and [his]4629-his chusing [herself]178-miss morton had been spoken of in [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward ’s flattering language as only a lesser evil than [his]4629-his chusing [Lucy Steele]138-lucy , [she]89-elinor feared that [Robert]144-robert ’s offence would serve no other purpose than to enrich [Fanny]93-fanny . About four days after [Edward]98-edward ’s arrival [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon appeared , to complete [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood ’s satisfaction , and to give [her]88-mrs. dashwood the dignity of having , for the first time since [her]88-mrs. dashwood living at [Barton]8-barton , more company with [her]88-mrs. dashwood than [[her]88-mrs. dashwood house]2805-her house would hold . [Edward]98-edward was allowed to retain the privilege of [first comer]4632-first comer , and [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon therefore walked every night to [[his]104-colonel brandon old quarters at [the Park]566-the park]4633-his old quarters at the park ; from whence [he]104-colonel brandon usually returned in the morning , early enough to interrupt [the lovers]4635-the lovers ’ first tête - à - tête before breakfast . [A three weeks ’ residence at [Delaford]22-delaford]4636-a three weeks ’ residence at delaford , where , in [his]104-colonel brandon evening hours at least , [he]104-colonel brandon had little to do but to calculate the disproportion between thirty - six and seventeen , brought [him]104-colonel brandon to [Barton]8-barton in a temper of mind which needed all the improvement in [Marianne]90-marianne ’s looks , all the kindness of [her]90-marianne welcome , and all the encouragement of [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother ’s language , to make it cheerful . Among [such friends]4006-such friends , however , and such flattery , [he]104-colonel brandon did revive . No rumour of [Lucy]138-lucy ’s marriage had yet reached [him:—he]104-colonel brandon knew nothing of what had passed ; and the first hours of [his]104-colonel brandon visit were consequently spent in hearing and in wondering . Every thing was explained to [him]104-colonel brandon by [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood , and [he]104-colonel brandon found fresh reason to rejoice in what [he]104-colonel brandon had done for [Mr. Ferrars]144-robert , since eventually it promoted the interest of [Elinor]89-elinor . It would be needless to say , that [the gentlemen]1790-the gentlemen advanced in the good opinion of [each other]338-each other , as [they]1790-the gentlemen advanced in [each other]338-each other ’s acquaintance , for it could not be otherwise . [Their]1790-the gentlemen resemblance in good principles and good sense , in disposition and manner of thinking , would probably have been sufficient to unite [them]1790-the gentlemen in friendship , without any other attraction ; but [their]1790-the gentlemen being in love with [two sisters]4642-two sisters , and [two sisters]4642-two sisters fond of [each other]338-each other , made that mutual regard inevitable and immediate , which might otherwise have waited the effect of time and judgment . The letters from [town]2984-town , which a few days before would have made every nerve in [Elinor]89-elinor ’s body thrill with transport , now arrived to be read with less emotion than mirth . [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings wrote to tell the wonderful tale , to vent [her]103-mrs. jennings honest indignation against [the jilting girl]4646-the jilting girl , and pour forth [her]103-mrs. jennings compassion towards [poor Mr. Edward]94-edward , who , [she]103-mrs. jennings was sure , had quite doted upon [the worthless hussy]4647-the worthless hussy , and was now , by all accounts , almost broken - hearted , at [Oxford]29-oxford . “[0-i] [I]0-i do think , ” [she]0-i continued , “[0-i] nothing was ever carried on so sly ; for it was but two days before [Lucy]138-lucy called and sat a couple of hours with [me]0-i . [Not a soul]2659-not a soul suspected anything of the matter , not even [Nancy]143-nancy , who , [poor soul]3649-poor soul ! came crying to [me]0-i the day after , in a great fright for fear of [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward , as well as not knowing how to get to [Plymouth]26-plymouth ; for [Lucy]138-lucy it seems borrowed all [her]138-lucy money before [she]138-lucy went off to be married , on purpose [we]2661-we suppose to make a show with , and poor [Nancy]143-nancy had not seven shillings in [the world]2778-the world ; so [I]0-i was very glad to give [her]138-lucy five guineas to take [her]138-lucy down to [Exeter]10-exeter , where [she]138-lucy thinks of staying three or four weeks with [Mrs. Burgess]237-mrs. burgess , in hopes , as [I]0-i tell [her]138-lucy , to fall in with [the Doctor]3869-the doctor again . And [I]0-i must say that [Lucy]138-lucy ’s crossness not to take [them]2664-them along with [them]2664-them in the chaise is worse than all . [Poor Mr. Edward]94-edward ! [I]0-i can not get [him]94-edward out of [my]0-i head , but [you]94-edward must send for [him]94-edward to [Barton]8-barton , and [Miss Marianne]90-marianne must try to comfort [him]94-edward . ” [Mr. Dashwood]85-mr. dashwood ’s strains were more solemn . [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward was the most unfortunate of [women]4648-women — [poor Fanny]93-fanny had suffered agonies of sensibility — and [he]85-mr. dashwood considered the existence of [each , under such a blow]4649-each , under such a blow , with grateful wonder . [Robert]144-robert ’s offence was unpardonable , but [Lucy]138-lucy ’s was infinitely worse . Neither of [them]4648-women were ever again to be mentioned to [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward ; and even , if [she]98-edward might hereafter be induced to forgive [[her]98-edward son]1054-her son , [[his]85-mr. dashwood wife]280-his wife should never be acknowledged as [[her]98-edward daughter]404-her daughter , nor be permitted to appear in [her]98-edward presence . The secrecy with which everything had been carried on between [them]4648-women , was rationally treated as enormously heightening the crime , because , had any suspicion of it occurred to [the others]539-the others , proper measures would have been taken to prevent the marriage ; and [he]85-mr. dashwood called on [Elinor]89-elinor to join with [him]85-mr. dashwood in regretting that [Lucy]138-lucy ’s engagement with [Edward]98-edward had not rather been fulfilled , than that [she]138-lucy should thus be the means of spreading misery farther in [the family]303-the family . [He]85-mr. dashwood thus continued : — “[90-marianne] [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward has never yet mentioned [Edward]98-edward ’s name , which does not surprise [us]2665-us ; but , to [our]2665-us great astonishment , not a line has been received from [him]2666-him on the occasion . Perhaps , however , [he]2666-him is kept silent by [his]2666-him fear of offending , and [I]0-i shall , therefore , give [him]2666-him a hint , by a line to [Oxford]29-oxford , that [[his]2666-him sister]251-his sister and [I]0-i both think a letter of proper submission from [him]2666-him , addressed perhaps to [Fanny]93-fanny , and by [her]93-fanny shown to [[her]93-fanny mother]332-her mother , might not be taken amiss ; for [we]2665-us all know the tenderness of [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward ’s heart , and that [she]98-edward wishes for nothing so much as to be on good terms with [[her]98-edward children]495-her children . ” This paragraph was of some importance to the prospects and conduct of [Edward]98-edward . It determined [him]2666-him to attempt a reconciliation , though not exactly in the manner pointed out by [[their]2670-their brother]329-their brother and [sister]438-sister . “[98-edward] A letter of proper submission ! ” repeated [he]2666-him ; “[2670-their] would [they]2670-their have [me]0-i beg [[my]0-i mother]2771-my mother ’s pardon for [Robert]144-robert ’s ingratitude to _ [her]2771-my mother _ , and breach of honour to _ [me]0-i ? _ [I]0-i can make no submission . [I]0-i am grown neither humble nor penitent by what has passed . [I]0-i am grown very happy ; but that would not interest . [I]0-i know of no submission that _ is _ proper for [me]0-i to make . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i may certainly ask to be forgiven , ” said [Elinor]89-elinor , “[0-i] because [you]0-i have offended;—and [I]0-i should think [you]0-i might _ now _ venture so far as to profess some concern for having ever formed the engagement which drew on [you]0-i [[your]0-i mother]2781-your mother ’s anger . ” [He]144-robert agreed that [he]144-robert might . “[2781-your mother] And when [she]2781-your mother has forgiven [you]0-i , perhaps a little humility may be convenient while acknowledging a second engagement , almost as imprudent in _ [her]2781-your mother _ eyes as the first . ” [He]144-robert had nothing to urge against it , but still resisted the idea of a letter of proper submission ; and therefore , to make it easier to [him]144-robert , as [he]144-robert declared a much greater willingness to make mean concessions by word of mouth than on paper , it was resolved that , instead of writing to [Fanny]93-fanny , [he]144-robert should go to [London]24-london , and personally intreat [her]93-fanny good offices in [his]144-robert favour . “[2673-they] And if [they]2673-they really _ do _ interest [themselves]2673-they , ” said [Marianne]90-marianne , in [her]90-marianne new character of candour , “[2673-they] in bringing about a reconciliation , [I]0-i shall think that even [John]88-mrs. dashwood and [Fanny]93-fanny are not entirely without merit . ” After a visit on [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon ’s side of only three or four days , [the two gentlemen]4260-the two gentlemen quitted [Barton]6-barton park together . [They]4260-the two gentlemen were to go immediately to [Delaford]22-delaford , that [Edward]98-edward might have some personal knowledge of [[his]144-robert future home]4658-his future home , and assist [[his]144-robert patron]4659-his patron and [friend]2639-friend in deciding on what improvements were needed to it ; and from thence , after staying there a couple of nights , [he]144-robert was to proceed on [his]144-robert journey to [town]2984-town . CHAPTER L. After a proper resistance on the part of [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward , just so violent and so steady as to preserve [her]98-edward from that reproach which [she]98-edward always seemed fearful of incurring , the reproach of being too amiable , [Edward]98-edward was admitted to [her]98-edward presence , and pronounced to be again [[her]98-edward son]1054-her son . [[Her]98-edward family]391-her family had of late been exceedingly fluctuating . For many years of [her]98-edward life [she]98-edward had had [two sons]4664-two sons ; but the crime and annihilation of [Edward]98-edward a few weeks ago , had robbed [her]98-edward of one ; the similar annihilation of [Robert]144-robert had left [her]98-edward for a fortnight without any ; and now , by the resuscitation of [Edward]98-edward , [she]98-edward had one again . In spite of [his]144-robert being allowed once more to live , however , [he]144-robert did not feel the continuance of [his]144-robert existence secure , till [he]144-robert had revealed [his]144-robert present engagement ; for the publication of that circumstance , [he]144-robert feared , might give a sudden turn to [his]144-robert constitution , and carry [him]144-robert off as rapidly as before . With apprehensive caution therefore it was revealed , and [he]144-robert was listened to with unexpected calmness . [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward at first reasonably endeavoured to dissuade [him]144-robert from marrying [Miss Dashwood]84-miss dashwood , by every argument in [her]98-edward power;—told [him]144-robert , that in [Miss Morton]178-miss morton [he]144-robert would have [a woman of higher rank and larger fortune;—and]4665-a woman of higher rank and larger fortune;—and enforced the assertion , by observing that [Miss Morton]178-miss morton was [the daughter of [a nobleman with thirty thousand pounds]4667-a nobleman with thirty thousand pounds]4666-the daughter of a nobleman with thirty thousand pounds , while [Miss Dashwood]84-miss dashwood was only [the daughter of [a private gentleman with no more than _ three]4669-a private gentleman with no more than _ three]4668-the daughter of a private gentleman with no more than _ three ; _ but when [she]98-edward found that , though perfectly admitting the truth of [her]98-edward representation , [he]144-robert was by no means inclined to be guided by it , [she]98-edward judged it wisest , from the experience of the past , to submit — and therefore , after such an ungracious delay as [she]98-edward owed to [her]98-edward own dignity , and as served to prevent every suspicion of good - will , [she]98-edward issued [her]98-edward decree of consent to the marriage of [Edward]98-edward and [Elinor]89-elinor . What [she]98-edward would engage to do towards augmenting [their]4670-their income was next to be considered ; and here it plainly appeared , that though [Edward]98-edward was now [[her]98-edward only son]4671-her only son , [he]4671-her only son was by no means [[her]98-edward eldest]4672-her eldest ; for while [Robert]144-robert was inevitably endowed with a thousand pounds a - year , not the smallest objection was made against [Edward]98-edward ’s taking orders for the sake of two hundred and fifty at the utmost ; nor was anything promised either for the present or in future , beyond the ten thousand pounds , which had been given with [Fanny]93-fanny . It was as much , however , as was desired , and more than was expected , by [Edward]98-edward and [Elinor]89-elinor ; and [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward [herself]98-edward , by [her]98-edward shuffling excuses , seemed the only person surprised at [her]98-edward not giving more . With an income quite sufficient to [their]4670-their wants thus secured to [them]4670-their , [they]4670-their had nothing to wait for after [Edward]98-edward was in possession of [the living]4673-the living , but the readiness of [the house]318-the house , to which [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon , with an eager desire for the accommodation of [Elinor]89-elinor , was making considerable improvements ; and after waiting some time for [their]4670-their completion , after experiencing , as usual , a thousand disappointments and delays from the unaccountable dilatoriness of [the workmen]4675-the workmen , [Elinor]89-elinor , as usual , broke through the first positive resolution of not marrying till every thing was ready , and the ceremony took place in [Barton church]4676-barton church early in the autumn . The first month after [their]4670-their marriage was spent with [[their]4670-their friend]1882-their friend at [the Mansion - house]2275-the mansion - house ; from whence [they]4670-their could superintend the progress of [the Parsonage]2274-the parsonage , and direct every thing as [they]4670-their liked on the spot;—could chuse papers , project shrubberies , and invent a sweep . [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings ’s prophecies , though rather jumbled together , were chiefly fulfilled ; for [she]103-mrs. jennings was able to visit [Edward]98-edward and [[his]104-colonel brandon wife]280-his wife in [[their]4670-their Parsonage]4681-their parsonage by [Michaelmas]216-michaelmas , and [she]103-mrs. jennings found in [Elinor]89-elinor and [[her]89-elinor husband]319-her husband , as [she]103-mrs. jennings really believed , [one of [the happiest couples in [the world]2778-the world]4684-the happiest couples in the world]4683-one of the happiest couples in the world . [They]4670-their had in fact nothing to wish for , but the marriage of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon and [Marianne]90-marianne , and rather better pasturage for [their]4670-their cows . [They]4670-their were visited on [their]4670-their first settling by almost all [[their]4670-their relations]4686-their relations and [friends]3231-friends . [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward came to inspect the happiness which [she]98-edward was almost ashamed of having authorised ; and even [the Dashwoods]92-the miss dashwoods were at the expense of a journey from [Sussex]1-sussex to do [them]4670-their honour . “[0-i] [I]0-i will not say that [I]0-i am disappointed , [[my]0-i dear sister]3621-my dear sister , ” said [John]88-mrs. dashwood , as [they]4688-they were walking together one morning before the gates of [Delaford House]81-delaford house , “[0-i] _ that _ would be saying too much , for certainly [you]3621-my dear sister have been [one of [the most fortunate young women in [the world]2778-the world]2676-the most fortunate young women in the world]2675-one of the most fortunate young women in the world , as it is . But , [I]0-i confess , it would give [me]0-i great pleasure to call [[Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon brother]2678-colonel brandon brother . [[His]104-colonel brandon property here]2679-his property here , [[his]104-colonel brandon place]2680-his place , [[his]104-colonel brandon house]515-his house , every thing is in such respectable and excellent condition ! And [[his]104-colonel brandon woods,—I]2682-his woods,—i have not seen such timber any where in [Dorsetshire]45-dorsetshire , as there is now standing in [Delaford Hanger]82-delaford hanger ! And though , perhaps , [Marianne]90-marianne may not seem exactly the person to attract [him]104-colonel brandon , yet [I]0-i think it would altogether be advisable for [you]2683-you to have [them]2684-them now frequently staying with [you]2683-you , for as [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon seems a great deal at [home]565-home , [nobody]2922-nobody can tell what may happen ; for , when [people]2770-people are much thrown together , and see little of [anybody else,—and]2688-anybody else,—and it will always be in [your]2683-you power to set [her]90-marianne off to advantage , and so forth . In short , [you]2683-you may as well give [her]90-marianne a chance : [you]2683-you understand [me]0-i . ” But though [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward _ did _ come to see [them]2684-them , and always treated [them]2684-them with the make - believe of decent affection , [they]2684-them were never insulted by [her]98-edward real favour and preference . _ That _ was due to the folly of [Robert]144-robert , and the cunning of [[his]144-robert wife]280-his wife ; and it was earned by [them]2684-them before many months had passed away . The selfish sagacity of [the latter]325-the latter , which had at first drawn [Robert]144-robert into the scrape , was the principal instrument of [his]144-robert deliverance from it ; for [her]98-edward respectful humility , assiduous attentions , and endless flatteries , as soon as the smallest opening was given for [their]2684-them exercise , reconciled [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward to [his]144-robert choice , and re - established [him]144-robert completely in [her]98-edward favour . The whole of [Lucy]138-lucy ’s behaviour in the affair , and the prosperity which crowned it , therefore , may be held forth as a most encouraging instance of what an earnest , an unceasing attention to self - interest , however its progress may be apparently obstructed , will do in securing every advantage of fortune , with no other sacrifice than that of time and conscience . When [Robert]144-robert first sought [her]138-lucy acquaintance , and privately visited [her]138-lucy in [[Bartlett]182-bartlett ’s Buildings]4083-bartlett ’s buildings , it was only with the view imputed to [him]144-robert by [[his]144-robert brother]3045-his brother . [He]144-robert merely meant to persuade [her]138-lucy to give up the engagement ; and as there could be nothing to overcome but the affection of both , [he]144-robert naturally expected that one or two interviews would settle the matter . In that point , however , and that only , [he]144-robert erred ; for though [Lucy]138-lucy soon gave [him]144-robert hopes that [his]144-robert eloquence would convince [her]138-lucy in _ time _ , another visit , another conversation , was always wanted to produce this conviction . Some doubts always lingered in [her]138-lucy mind when [they]2693-they parted , which could only be removed by another half hour ’s discourse with [himself]144-robert . [His]144-robert attendance was by this means secured , and the rest followed in course . Instead of talking of [Edward]98-edward , [they]2693-they came gradually to talk only of [Robert,—a]239-robert,—a subject on which [he]144-robert had always more to say than on any other , and in which [she]138-lucy soon betrayed an interest even equal to [his]144-robert own ; and in short , it became speedily evident to [both]2892-both , that [he]144-robert had entirely supplanted [[his]144-robert brother]3045-his brother . [He]144-robert was proud of [his]144-robert conquest , proud of tricking [Edward]98-edward , and very proud of marrying privately without [[his]144-robert mother]270-his mother ’s consent . What immediately followed is known . [They]2693-they passed some months in great happiness at [Dawlish]59-dawlish ; for [she]138-lucy had many relations and [old acquaintances]2697-old acquaintances to cut — and [he]144-robert drew several plans for [magnificent cottages;—and]2698-magnificent cottages;—and from thence returning to [town]2984-town , procured the forgiveness of [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward , by the simple expedient of asking it , which , at [Lucy]138-lucy ’s instigation , was adopted . The forgiveness , at first , indeed , as was reasonable , comprehended only [Robert]144-robert ; and [Lucy]138-lucy , who had owed [[his]144-robert mother]270-his mother no duty and therefore could have transgressed none , still remained some weeks longer unpardoned . But perseverance in humility of conduct and messages , in self - condemnation for [Robert]144-robert ’s offence , and gratitude for the unkindness [she]138-lucy was treated with , procured [her]138-lucy in time the haughty notice which overcame [her]138-lucy by its graciousness , and led soon afterwards , by rapid degrees , to the highest state of affection and influence . [Lucy]138-lucy became as necessary to [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward , as either [Robert]144-robert or [Fanny]93-fanny ; and while [Edward]98-edward was never cordially forgiven for having once intended to marry [her]138-lucy , and [Elinor]89-elinor , though superior to [her]138-lucy in fortune and birth , was spoken of as [an intruder]2701-an intruder , _ [she]89-elinor _ was in every thing considered , and always openly acknowledged , to be [a favourite child]1564-a favourite child . [They]2703-they settled in [town]2984-town , received very liberal assistance from [Mrs. Ferrars]98-edward , were on the best terms imaginable with [the Dashwoods]92-the miss dashwoods ; and setting aside the jealousies and ill - will continually subsisting between [Fanny]93-fanny and [Lucy]138-lucy , in which [[their]2703-they husbands]2705-their husbands of course took a part , as well as the frequent domestic disagreements between [Robert]144-robert and [Lucy]138-lucy [themselves]2703-they , nothing could exceed the harmony in which [they]2703-they all lived together . What [Edward]98-edward had done to forfeit the right of [eldest son]2706-eldest son , might have puzzled [many people]3201-many people to find out ; and what [Robert]144-robert had done to succeed to it , might have puzzled [them]3201-many people still more . It was an arrangement , however , justified in its effects , if not in its cause ; for nothing ever appeared in [Robert]144-robert ’s style of living or of talking to give a suspicion of [his]144-robert regretting the extent of [his]144-robert income , as either leaving [[his]144-robert brother]3045-his brother too little , or bringing [himself]144-robert too much;—and if [Edward]98-edward might be judged from the ready discharge of [his]144-robert duties in every particular , from an increasing attachment to [[his]144-robert wife]280-his wife and [[his]144-robert home]252-his home , and from the regular cheerfulness of [his]144-robert spirits , [he]144-robert might be supposed no less contented with [his]144-robert lot , no less free from every wish of an exchange . [Elinor]89-elinor ’s marriage divided [her]89-elinor as little from [[her]89-elinor family]391-her family as could well be contrived , without rendering [the cottage at [Barton]8-barton]2712-the cottage at barton entirely useless , for [[her]89-elinor mother]332-her mother and [sisters]301-sisters spent much more than half [their]2715-their time with [her]89-elinor . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood was acting on motives of policy as well as pleasure in the frequency of [her]89-elinor visits at [Delaford]22-delaford ; for [her]89-elinor wish of bringing [Marianne]90-marianne and [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon together was hardly less earnest , though rather more liberal than what [John]88-mrs. dashwood had expressed . It was now [her]89-elinor darling object . Precious as was the company of [[her]89-elinor daughter]404-her daughter to [her]89-elinor , [she]89-elinor desired nothing so much as to give up its constant enjoyment to [[her]89-elinor valued friend]2717-her valued friend ; and to see [Marianne]90-marianne settled at [the mansion - house]2275-the mansion - house was equally the wish of [Edward]98-edward and [Elinor]89-elinor . [They]2719-they each felt [his]2720-his sorrows , and [their]2719-they own obligations , and [Marianne]90-marianne , by general consent , was to be the reward of all . With such a confederacy against [her]90-marianne — with a knowledge so intimate of [his]2720-his goodness — with a conviction of [his]2720-his fond attachment to [herself]90-marianne , which at last , though long after it was observable to [everybody else]1726-everybody else — burst on [her]90-marianne — what could [she]90-marianne do ? [Marianne Dashwood]90-marianne was born to an extraordinary fate . [She]90-marianne was born to discover the falsehood of [her]90-marianne own opinions , and to counteract , by [her]90-marianne conduct , [her]90-marianne most favourite maxims . [She]90-marianne was born to overcome an affection formed so late in life as at seventeen , and with no sentiment superior to strong esteem and lively friendship , voluntarily to give [her]90-marianne hand to another!—and _ that _ other , [a man who had suffered no less than [herself]90-marianne under the event of a former attachment , whom , two years before , [she]90-marianne had considered too old to be married,—and who still sought the constitutional safeguard of a flannel waistcoat]2722-a man who had suffered no less than herself under the event of a former attachment , whom , two years before , she had considered too old to be married,—and who still sought the constitutional safeguard of a flannel waistcoat ! But so it was . Instead of falling a sacrifice to an irresistible passion , as once [she]90-marianne had fondly flattered [herself]90-marianne with expecting,—instead of remaining even for ever with [[her]90-marianne mother]332-her mother , and finding [her]90-marianne only pleasures in retirement and study , as afterwards in [her]90-marianne more calm and sober judgment [she]90-marianne had determined on,—she found [herself]90-marianne at nineteen , submitting to new attachments , entering on new duties , placed in [a new home]2751-a new home , [a wife]2876-a wife , [the mistress of [a family]3155-a family]2726-the mistress of a family , and [the patroness of [a village]2729-a village]2728-the patroness of a village . [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon was now as happy , as [all those who best loved [him]104-colonel brandon]2730-all those who best loved him , believed [he]104-colonel brandon deserved to be;—in [Marianne]90-marianne [he]104-colonel brandon was consoled for every past affliction;—her regard and [[her]90-marianne society]3519-her society restored [his]104-colonel brandon mind to animation , and [his]104-colonel brandon spirits to cheerfulness ; and that [Marianne]90-marianne found [her]90-marianne own happiness in forming [his]104-colonel brandon , was equally the persuasion and delight of [each observing friend]2732-each observing friend . [Marianne]90-marianne could never love by halves ; and [her]90-marianne whole heart became , in time , as much devoted to [[her]90-marianne husband]319-her husband , as it had once been to [Willoughby]107-willoughby . [Willoughby]107-willoughby could not hear of [her]90-marianne marriage without a pang ; and [his]107-willoughby punishment was soon afterwards complete in the voluntary forgiveness of [Mrs. Smith]120-mrs. smith , who , by stating [his]107-willoughby marriage with [a woman of character]2734-a woman of character , as the source of [her]120-mrs. smith clemency , gave [him]107-willoughby reason for believing that had [he]107-willoughby behaved with honour towards [Marianne]90-marianne , [he]107-willoughby might at once have been happy and rich . That [his]107-willoughby repentance of misconduct , which thus brought its own punishment , was sincere , need not be doubted;—nor that [he]107-willoughby long thought of [Colonel Brandon]104-colonel brandon with envy , and of [Marianne]90-marianne with regret . But that [he]107-willoughby was for ever inconsolable , that [he]107-willoughby fled from [society]2735-society , or contracted an habitual gloom of temper , or died of a broken heart , must not be depended on — for [he]107-willoughby did neither . [He]107-willoughby lived to exert , and frequently to enjoy [himself]107-willoughby . [[His]107-willoughby wife]280-his wife was not always out of humour , nor [[his]107-willoughby home]252-his home always uncomfortable ; and in [his]107-willoughby breed of horses and dogs , and in sporting of every kind , [he]107-willoughby found no inconsiderable degree of domestic felicity . For [Marianne]90-marianne , however , in spite of [his]107-willoughby incivility in surviving [her]90-marianne loss , [he]107-willoughby always retained that decided regard which interested [him]107-willoughby in every thing that befell [her]90-marianne , and made [her]90-marianne [his]107-willoughby secret standard of perfection in [woman]2738-woman ; and [many a rising beauty]2739-many a rising beauty would be slighted by [him]107-willoughby in after - days as bearing no comparison with [Mrs. Brandon]169-mrs. brandon . [Mrs. Dashwood]88-mrs. dashwood was prudent enough to remain at [the cottage]507-the cottage , without attempting a removal to [Delaford]22-delaford ; and fortunately for [Sir John]99-sir john and [Mrs. Jennings]103-mrs. jennings , when [Marianne]90-marianne was taken from [them]2741-them , [Margaret]91-margaret had reached an age highly suitable for dancing , and not very ineligible for being supposed to have [a lover]2821-a lover . Between [Barton]6-barton park and [Delaford]22-delaford , there was that constant communication which strong family affection would naturally dictate ; and among the merits and the happiness of [Elinor]89-elinor and [Marianne]90-marianne , let it not be ranked as the least considerable , that though [sisters]301-sisters , and living almost within sight of [each other]338-each other , [they]301-sisters could live without disagreement between [themselves]301-sisters , or producing coolness between [[their]301-sisters husbands]2705-their husbands . THE END * * * [END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG]240-end of the project gutenberg EBOOK SENSE AND SENSIBILITY * * *
